Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: TIG Insurance Company v. Republic of Argentina
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: A contract may be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Agreement was made by sovereign, within meaning of FSIA's arbitration exception, if it legally bound sovereign to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, individual who paid to set up funding companies and continued to fund them exercised requisite level of control over companies with respect to two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which companies purchased healthcare facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments of specified amounts over set period of time, thus supporting piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility; although he was not on-paper owner or named director of companies, he made decisions on how and when MCA deals were made by companies that did not follow corporate formalities and effectively existed on paper only.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, manager of two entities that funded and provided management services for two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which funding companies purchased healthcare facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments of specified amounts over set period of time, did not exercise requisite level of control over companies to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory in order to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility; although he signed settlement agreements on behalf of companies, at most he was companies' authorized representative, and his receipt of profits as syndicate member on some MCA deals did not equate to controlling companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, individual who exercised requisite level of control over funding companies used his control to perpetrate fraud or wrongdoing against healthcare facility with respect to two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which companies purchased facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments, thus supporting piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility; companies were formed for fraudulent purpose, companies and transactions had no connection to Connecticut, and he intentionally structured companies to obfuscate his control implicitly to avoid liability for any wrongful act under their name.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under the instrumentality rule for determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, ordinarily, breach of contract standing alone is insufficient to prove the element of using control over the corporate entity to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; however, a breach of contract coupled with a showing that a the corporation was formed for an improper purpose, such as forming a corporation to shelter oneself from personal obligations incurred prior to the formation of the corporation or to commit or to avoid liability for any personal wrongful act, is sufficient.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, individual who exercised requisite level of control over funding companies and used his control to perpetrate fraud or wrongdoing against healthcare facility with respect to two merchant cash advance (MCA) agreements, under which companies purchased facility's future receivables in exchange for providing immediate cash to facility and facility's promise of repayments, proximately caused facility's monetary injury from companies' breach of agreements by over-collecting from facility, thus justifying piercing corporate veil under alter ego theory to impose joint and several liability for companies' breach, with result that he was liable for $50,071.77 that facility was over-charged on one agreement and for $170,000 that facility was over-charged on another agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Chubb Capital I Limited v. New Orleans City
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, a corporation may be bound by an agreement entered into by its subsidiary regardless of the agreement's structure or the subsidiary's attempts to bind itself alone to its terms, when their conduct demonstrates a virtual abandonment of separateness.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Arbitration and Appraisal. Insurers, who were non-signatories to arbitration agreement, did not agree to arbitrate city's claims against insureds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pentacon BV v. Vanderhaegen
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law permits non-signatories to be held liable for breach of contract under limited circumstances, namely, where the non-signatory (1) is the alter ego of the signatory, (2) manifests an intent to be bound by the contract, or (3) acts so as to show they are in privity of contract or assumed obligations under the contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Alleged sale of start-up after no sale period, which was planned during such period, did not violate no sale clause of share redemption agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, while it is generally true that only parties to contract are liable for its breach, traditional principles of law allow contract to be enforced by or against nonparties through, among other things, theory of alter ego.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, alter ego is not a claim for substantive relief, but rather a remedial theory in equity under which the corporate entity is disregarded and individuals or entities are held liable on the obligations of the corporation, including those obligations arising from breach of contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ward
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Valdosta Division.
Headnote: Creditors failed to pierce the corporate veil under Georgia law in nondischargeability proceeding so as to hold Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for his businesses' debts arising from contracts to build pools at creditors' residences; there was no evidence that debtor abused the corporate forms to perpetuate alleged fraud against creditors, but rather, businesses filed their own consolidated tax returns, maintained balance sheets and other corporate accounting records, had their own bank accounts separate from debtor, maintained their own business address not at debtor's personal address, used form contracts with the name of the company on the header, and had many employees other than debtor. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditors failed to pierce the corporate veil under Georgia law so as to hold Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for his businesses' debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute fraud or wrong warranting piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. v. 29-33 Ninth Avenue, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law provides that a court may pierce the veil and bind a non-signatory to a contract's terms in certain circumstances.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Interpleader. Bank accounts frozen after bank received notice of conflict concerning them constituted identifiable res, as required for interpleader action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a breach of contract is sufficient to satisfy the fraud or wrong element of an alter ego claim.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mohawk Construction and Supply Company, Inc. v. Walsh/Consigli JV
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was not warranted to hold limited liability company (LLC) and company, which were related to joint venture but were not themselves part of the joint venture, liable for joint venture's alleged breach of construction subcontract, absent showing that LLC and company dominated the entities involved in the joint venture or that such domination was used to wrong the subcontractor.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Limited liability company and company related to joint venture were not liable for breach of subcontract between joint venture and subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Compass Concierge, LLC v. 142 Duane Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Authorized signatory for property owner, a corporation, in a renovation-services agreement between owner and real estate brokerage was not himself a party to the contract, and thus brokerage could not recover for breach of contract against signatory, absent either a showing that the contract suggested that the parties intended to bind signatory personally or a showing of facts supporting the piercing of the corporate veil to hold signatory personally liable for owner's alleged breach of the contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Real estate brokerage could not recover for breach of contract against authorized signatory for corporation in brokerage's contract with corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Plan B Holdings, LLC v. RSLLP
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: There are limited circumstances under which nonparty to contract may nonetheless be bound by it, including under an alter-ego theory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Law firm could pierce the corporate veil to hold sole owner of LLCs personally liable for unpaid attorney's fees under an alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations requires plaintiff to show that shareholder or affiliate caused corporation to be used to perpetrate and did perpetrate actual fraud on obligee, and that fraud was primarily for direct personal benefit of holder, beneficial owner, subscriber, or affiliate. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: "Actual fraud," as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law, is distinct from the tort of fraud and only requires a plaintiff to show dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: In assessing whether there was actual fraud, as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law, courts may deduce fraudulent intent from all of the facts and circumstances. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: In assessing whether there was actual fraud, as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law, courts generally look at the totality of a shareholder's actions to determine whether he committed actual fraud. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: If funds are only used for corporation's benefit or are diverted to other ventures, limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations under Texas law applies, and plaintiff's claim against shareholder or affiliate fails. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Greathouse v. Capital Plus Financial LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in business-transaction context that might be routine in vacuum, actual fraud, as ground for evading shareholder or affiliate's limited liability for corporation's contractual obligations, can be inferred from proximity or volume of transactions in context with other circumstances. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Borrowers could proceed with contract claims against lender for failure to disburse funds under payroll protection program during COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rogers v. Tug Hill Operating, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Circumstances in which a nonparty to a contract may be entitled to enforce it under standard contract principles include assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Arbitration. Oil and gas operator was not a third party beneficiary entitled to enforce arbitration agreement to which it was not a party in foreman's FLSA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Riverview Carpet & Flooring, Inc. v. Presbyterian SeniorCare
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Facilities management company's employee, who performed work for senior living facility operator, and employee's friends, who were architect and certified public accountant (CPA), created and used general contractor to perpetrate fraud, and thus, justice demanded piercing general contractor's corporate veil and holding CPA, as its 20% shareholder, directly liable for general contractor's breach of contractual obligations to pay renovation subcontractors; general contractor was formed solely as part of fraudulent scheme to overcharge operator for renovations, general contractor itself did no work and was never used for legitimate business ends, corporate and personal affairs were intermingled, and defrauded parties could not recover damages from general contractor, which was insolvent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Senior living facility operator's oral guaranty of general contractor's debts to subcontractors was enforceable under leading object rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly alleged that another factoring company was the "mere instrumentality" of assignor and the two entities were thus a single entity, for purposes of liability for breach of assignment agreement under Michigan law, by alleging that assignor and its alleged alter ego shared principal offices and staff, as alleged alter ego had no employees of its own but instead relied on assignor's employees to act on its behalf, and assignor and alleged alter ego did business under the same name and the entities transferred dealer's funds between one another.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in an appropriate case, one company's conduct may be attributed to another for the purposes of establishing breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt adequately alleged an injurious fraud or wrong for veil-piercing liability under Michigan law by alleging that assignor received the benefits of its alleged alter ego's contract with dealer, despite being prohibited by terms of assignment agreement from entering its own contract with dealer, and that assignor knowingly used alleged alter ego to avoid the assignment and take funds from dealer that should have been paid to assignee.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt adequately alleged an unjust loss or injury from breach of contract for veil-piercing liability under Michigan law by alleging that assignor used alleged alter ego to obtain funds from dealer that should have been paid to assignee, in violation of assignment agreement.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York, Connecticut, or Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) law, at time he transferred holding company's assets to family trust and others, holding company's owner lacked specific intent to evade company's liability for margin calls bank made upon discovering insufficient collateral for company's risky trading, weighing against piercing corporate veil and holding owner personally liable for judgment that English court entered against company in bank's underlying breach-of-contract action, where owner reasonably believed, based on information then available to him, that he left enough money in company's accounts at bank to cover company's potential loss exposure, and owner expressed genuine shock upon learning of shortfall in company's accounts at bank after he made transfers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York, Connecticut, or Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) law, losses bank incurred when holding company failed to pay final margin call bank issued resulted directly and in large part from bank's own negligence and incompetence, weighing against piercing corporate veil and holding company's owner personally liable for judgment that English court entered against company in bank's underlying breach-of-contract action, where bank agreed to provide back-office services for company's risky derivatives trading without obtaining personal guarantee from company's owner and without being able to understand and accurately value company's trades or margin its accounts, resulting in bank failing to notice company's massive loss exposure and shortfall in company's accounts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Brandsway Hospitality, LLC. v. Delshah Capital LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There is no independent cause of action to pierce the corporate veil, and a breach of contract claim, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. Trial court providently denied plaintiff's motion for leave to amend to add a cause of action to pierce the corporate veil of defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: G & Y Maintenance Corp. v. Core Continental Construction LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Using one's domination and control to cause another to breach its contractual obligations is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil, as necessary to support a claim against the person exercising domination and control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Corporation failed to allege basis to pierce corporate veil and assert claim against limited liability company (LLC) president for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kitchen Winners NY Inc. v. Rock Fintek LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a parent corporation can be held liable for the breach of a contract signed by its subsidiary if (1) its intent to be bound by the contract were inferable from the parent's participation in the negotiation of the contract, (2) if the subsidiary is a dummy for the parent, or (3) if the subsidiary is controlled by the parent for the parent's own purposes.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Company's signature on sales agreement gave rise to plausible inference of its intent to be bound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kitchen Winners NY Inc. v. Rock Fintek LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil and allow suit against a non-party parent as an alter ego of a signatory to a contract, a court assesses whether (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Company's signature on sales agreement gave rise to plausible inference of its intent to be bound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kitchen Winners NY Inc. v. Rock Fintek LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, an ordinary breach of contract, without evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct, is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Company's signature on sales agreement gave rise to plausible inference of its intent to be bound.

Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to contract through assumption, piercing corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, whether a plaintiff may pierce an entity's veil pursuant to either the alter ego theory or the sham to perpetrate a fraud theory depends on whether the plaintiff's claims sound in tort or contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, whereas a tort claimant may freely pierce the veil under either the alter ego theory or the sham to perpetrate a fraud theory, a contract claimant may only pierce the veil if the defendant has also committed an actual fraud against the plaintiff for the defendant's direct personal benefit. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, exclusive licensee of disinfectant adequately alleged that licensor was organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of founding company, so they were part of single business enterprise, as required to treat licensor as company's alter ego and pierce corporate veil for breach of contract claim; licensee alleged that company's owners created licensor as shell entity mere weeks before negotiating with licensee to knowingly sell defective product and insulate company from liability, while sales revenue went directly to company, that licensor communicated with licensee via company's officers and employees using company's email accounts and signature blocks, and that company intended to deceive licensee as to product's quality and ability to destroy COVID-19 virus. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "actual fraud" required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims is defined as involving dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in the context of piercing the corporate veil for contract claims, actual fraud is not equivalent to the tort of fraud; indeed, the requirements for showing actual fraud are less burdensome than those for establishing fraud. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in practice, courts may deduce fraudulent intent required to establish actual fraud necessary to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims from all of the facts and circumstances of a given case. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the appropriate counterpart to actual fraud required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims is not fraud but constructive fraud. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "actual fraud" required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims involves dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive, whereas "constructive fraud" is the breach of some legal or equitable duty which, irrespective of moral guilt, the law declares fraudulent because of its tendency to deceive others, to violate confidence, or to injure public interests. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the very purpose of the intent inquiry in assessing actual fraud required to pierce the corporate veil for contract claims is to determine whether the defendant used otherwise legitimate corporate structures and procedures to achieve dishonest ends. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.
