Title: Etage Real Estate LLC v. Stern
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: A simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor was not entitled to summary judgment on veil-piercing claim against 50% owners of nonparty judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hamilton v. Young Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil was not warranted under Massachusetts law in order to bring within the jurisdiction of the district court either the successor to booking agent with which vacationer and her husband booked travel or an allegedly related partnership, in action brought by vacationer and husband, asserting claims for negligence and breach of contract, stemming from vacationer's injury at resort, despite their argument that agent, its successor, and partnership were alter egos of each other; although such entities had a common owner, shared an address, and had the common purpose of supporting owner's hotels, there was no evidence that owner disregarded corporate formalities, mixed assets among entities, or operated the companies as a front to perpetrate fraud or escape jurisdiction.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Booking agent availed itself of the privilege of conducting activities in forum state, thus subjecting it to jurisdiction in injured traveler's suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A breach of contract is not the type of fraud or wrongful act that will support an alter ego claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Estate of parent LLC succeeded to LLC's membership in special-purpose vehicle LLC, so automatic dissolution was not triggered for lack of members.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hill International, Inc. v. JTS Realty Corporation
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported trial court's finding that real estate corporation and affiliated limited liability company were operating in a single business enterprise with property developer bound by forensic accounting services contract with auditor, who was hired to conduct in-depth audit of costs billed to property developer by construction contractor, in auditor's open account action arising from unpaid invoices; entities had substantial identity of ownership, with same manager, office, in-house accountant, and corporate representative in open account action, all entities were in real estate business, whether in construction, development, or management, and it appeared entities were operating interchangeably.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. Sufficient evidence supported trial court's finding that real estate corporation was operating in single business enterprise with property developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the veil and bind a non-signatory to a contract's terms where the non-signatory exercised complete control over a signatory and employed that domination to injure another signatory to the agreement.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts generally consider the following factors in determining whether domination over signatory by a non-signatory is present, for purposes of piercing of corporate veil to bind non-signatory to contract's terms: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, that is, issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiff may bring breach of contract claim against counterparty-signatory's parent entity where the counterparty-signatory has been so dominated and its separate identity so disregarded that the counterparty-signatory primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, ordinary breach of contract, without evidence of fraud or corporate misconduct, is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re All Year Holdings Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, allegations of complete ownership, common officers and personnel, and shared office space are, without more, insufficient to impose contractual liability on a parent for its subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Under New York law, plaintiff failed to adequately allege Chapter 11 debtor's intent to be bound by its subsidiary's contract with plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Maritime vessel operator adequately alleged that United States company was alter ego of Dubai company sufficient to pierce the corporate veil of United States company in action for breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment alleging companies wrongfully retained payment for bunker; operator alleged overlapping leadership and ownership of companies, as same individual acted as manager of Dubai company and director and registered agent for United States company and he acted as legal advisor to both companies, companies conducted the same type of business and sold same type of products under same terms and conditions, and parties used identical communication and use of web services.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual, a Greek citizen who acted as director and sole shareholder of Singapore company, manager of related Dubai company, and director and registered agent for related United States company, was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils in action for breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment alleging companies wrongfully retained payment for bunker; individual's cross-involvement in companies did not justify disregarding corporate form of the entities, as there was no allegation that individual intermingled personal assets with the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Product Solutions International, Inc. v. Aldez Containers, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Company that provided new-product-development services did not plausibly allege any wrongdoing by purported affiliate of new-product developer, and thus, failed to state claims under Michigan law against affiliate for breach of contract, promissory estoppel, and non-acceptance of conforming goods under the Uniform Commercial Code; company alleged that new-product developer was agent, alter ego, and mere instrumentality of affiliate, but did not allege that purported affiliate was party to any contract, and piercing corporate veil was not cause of action under Michigan law.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Res judicata did not bar contract claims by company that provided new-product-development services against purported affiliate of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Highland Crusader Offshore Partners, L.P. v. Celtic Pharma Phinco B.V.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Bermuda law, veil piercing is not allowed where a counterparty knowingly contracts with a company rather than with an individual or other entity affiliated with the company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff did not satisfy Bermuda-law requirements for piercing corporate veil of issuer and guarantors of notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: President of Canadian industrial equipment seller did not create new company, into which president transferred his 50% ownership interest in seller, with intent to make seller judgment-proof, and, thus, mere creation of new company did not constitute wrong sufficient under New York law to pierce corporate veil between seller on the one hand and president or new company on the other, where company was created for investment and tax planning purposes using structure common for such purposes in Canada.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, shareholder's creation of security interest in corporation's assets at time that shareholder sold half its shares in corporation to holding company did not constitute wrong sufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil in equipment buyer's breach-of-contract action against corporation, shareholder, and individual who owned shareholder and holding company and was president of corporation, where corporation remained profitable at time of security interest's creation, and no evidence suggested interest was created to render corporation judgment-proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, operation of nearly-insolvent corporation by its president and 50% shareholder, which was owned by president, did not constitute fraud or wrong justifying piercing corporate veil in buyer's action against corporation, president, and shareholder for breach of contract premised on corporation's sale of industrial equipment to buyer, where president and shareholder did not remove assets from corporation to render it judgment-proof, but, rather, shareholder repeatedly lent money to corporation to keep it at least temporarily solvent despite having no obligation to do so.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporation's president and 50% shareholder, which was owned by president, did not exercise complete control over corporation with respect to its sale of industrial equipment to buyer, and, thus, under New York law, corporate veil could not be pierced in buyer's action against corporation, president, and shareholder for breach of contract for equipment sale, where at time of sale, president was not active in corporation and had backed away from involvement in transaction due to personal obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporation's breach of contract for sale of industrial equipment to buyer, in and of itself, did not constitute fraud or wrong that would support piercing corporate veil between corporation and its president and shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Any wrong against equipment buyer that arose when corporation's president and its shareholder, which was owned by president and held security interest in corporation, allegedly threatened to call shareholder's loans to corporation and use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof in response to buyer's action against corporation for breach of contract did not cause buyer's injury, namely, inability to recover on default judgment entered against corporation, and, thus, under New York law, such wrong did not support piercing corporate veil between corporation and president or shareholder, where corporation always had superior claim to corporation's funds, having created security interest long before buyer entered into contract and before corporation's financial struggles.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, the element fraud, wrongdoing, or misuse that is required to pierce the corporate veil is generally satisfied by showing of a breach of contract by the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability could not be imposed against parent by piercing corporate veil based on parent-subsidiary relationship in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U.S. Bank National Association v. MMCO, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: A simple breach of contract, in the absence of a more substantial factual predicate indicative of some corporate malfeasance, with direct bearing on the plaintiff's injury, is insufficient to meet the second prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil from Belvedere v. R.E. Roark, 617 N.E.2d 1075, which requires proof of control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity.
Document Preview: TORTS  Damages. Tenant failed to present evidence of actual damages for fraud in addition to those claimed for breach of guaranty in action against co-trustee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Flooring Depot FTL, Inc., v. Wurtzebach
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Customers' allegations against president of retail corporation were insufficient to show that president engaged in any improper conduct, and thus trial court could not pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on president for corporation's breach of contract and fraud; customers merely alleged that president commingled his business and personal assets and used business monies to make personal purchases, president did not use corporation for improper purpose, and trial court specifically found that president's actions were not fraudulent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Customers' allegations against president of retail corporation were insufficient to show that president engaged in any improper conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Reeves v. Enterprise Products Partners, LP
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Arbitration. Employees were subject to arbitration clause in employment contracts with third-party staffing companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Americore Drilling & Cutting, Inc. v. EMB Contracting Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Limited liability company (LLC) that owned property on which hotel was being built was not alter ego of general contractor for hotel construction, precluding piercing of contractor's corporate veil to hold LLC liable for nonpayment of subcontractor for work on hotel balconies, absent showing that LLC exercised complete domination over contractor in the transaction with subcontractor; one of the owners of contractor, who was father of the owners of LLC, requested balcony work, subcontractor was paid from checking account in contractor's name, and, while one of LLC's owners approved some invoices on behalf of contractor, she did not approve any invoices regarding subcontractor and had not heard of subcontractor until dispute over its invoices arose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Site owner was not contractor's alter ego, precluding piercing of contractor's corporate veil to hold owner liable for nonpayment of subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Americore Drilling & Cutting, Inc. v. EMB Contracting Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Limited liability company (LLC) that owned property where hotel was being built did not use its alleged domination of general contractor to commit fraud or wrong against subcontractor, precluding piercing of corporate veil to hold LLC liable for contractor's nonpayment of subcontractor, despite fact that lots that formed property were all owned by same family, lots were transferred to one family member to repay work done by contractor while she was contractor's sole owner, and she later transferred ownership of property to LLC, of which she and her siblings were only owners; transfers which resulted in LLC's acquisition of property occurred before contractor retained subcontractor, and neither LLC nor any members of family prevented contractor from meeting obligations to subcontractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Site owner was not contractor's alter ego, precluding piercing of contractor's corporate veil to hold owner liable for nonpayment of subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Grupo HGM Tecnologias Submarina, S.A. v. Energy Subsea, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In contract cases, fraud is an essential element of an alter-ego finding.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Alter-ego theory applied to hold LLC's managing member jointly and severally liable with LLC for breach of maritime contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Financial Oversight and Management Board for Puerto Rico
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in action challenging validity of six fuel supply contracts and seeking rescission of the contracts and recovery of the full value or gross profits thereof, energy company was not the alter ego of its then-shareholder, a Swiss entity that had pled guilty to and was convicted of grand larceny in the first degree under New York law, where company was never undercapitalized, company always observed corporate formalities, shareholder never siphoned funds from company, and when company did business with shareholder, it transacted at arms-length and at fair market prices, without any special internal transfer pricing, just as when company did business with unrelated companies.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Rescission and Termination. Conviction for grand larceny in New York law was not equivalent to aggravated misappropriation under statute prohibiting future award of contracts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Humphrey v. GlaxoSmithKline PLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law govern issue of whether contract may be enforced by or against nonparties to contract through assumption, piercing corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Non-signatory to arbitration agreement could not be compelled to arbitrate its claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Judgment creditor could not have brought breach of contract action against garnishee defendants, which were judgment debtor's sister company and member, and thus judgment creditor's only option for relief was to seek to pierce the corporate veil of judgment debtor as an alleged alter ego of its sister company, even though judgment creditor wrote check for down payment for installation of safe room to sister company and was aware that sister company would be performing all work on safe room project; only judgment creditor and judgment debtor were named as parties to the contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of sister company and sister company's member, for purposes of determining whether judgment creditor could pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil in proceedings supplemental to breach of contract action stemming from the failed installation of a safe room in judgment creditor's residence, where sole member of judgment debtor admitted that he never put any money into capitalization of the company, judgment debtor had minimal business and financial records, and sister company and judgment debtor shared employees, had similar business purposes, and used same business address as judgment debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Misuse of judgment debtor's corporate form resulted in injustice to judgment creditor, arising in proceedings supplemental to breach of contract action seeking to pierce the corporate veil of judgment debtor following the failed installation of a safe room in judgment creditor's residence, where garnishee defendants, judgment debtor's sister company and member of sister company, manipulated judgment debtor's corporate form to extent that it was merely an instrumentality of garnishee defendants and misled judgment creditor into believing he was entering into a contract with a legitimate business, manipulation led judgment creditor to sue judgment debtor rather than garnishee defendants, and manipulation led to judgment creditor obtaining judgment against illegitimate company with no assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Trial court clearly erred in its conclusions regarding causation for purposes of determining whether judgment creditor would be allowed to pierce corporate veil of judgment debtor in proceedings supplemental to breach of contract action; court reached an erroneous legal conclusion to the extent it concluded that the misuse of the corporate form must be shown to cause damages, rather than injustice, and judgment creditor presented evidence of causal connection between misuse of judgment debtor's corporate form and actual harm suffered by judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of contract to purchase delivery trucks and delivery routes, unjust enrichment, and conversion, absent evidence to refute seller's evidence that owners did not observe the corporate form and that their misuse of the corporate form left sellers with little recourse but to seek to hold owners personally liable. (Per Mitchell, J., with three Justices concurring and one Justice concurring in the result.)
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that healthcare management company financed healthcare provider, that provider only did business with company, that company used provider's property as its own, or that provider failed to observe legal requirements of a corporation, and thus healthcare contractor which entered contract with provider could not prevail on claims against company for breach of contract, subterfuge/instrumentality, and fraud pursuant to alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing under Alabama law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Fact that healthcare provider and healthcare management company were owned by the same five persons did not support healthcare contractor's claims against company for breach of contract, subterfuge/instrumentality, and fraud under alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing under Alabama law, absent showing that company itself was a shareholder, officer, or director of provider.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that healthcare management company financed healthcare provider, that provider only did business with company, that company used provider's property as its own, or that provider failed to observe legal requirements of a corporation, and thus healthcare contractor could not prevail on claims against company for breach of contract, subterfuge/instrumentality, and fraud pursuant to "totality-of-the-circumstances" theory in action alleging that company and healthcare provider operated as a single corporate entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Buffalo Xerographix, Inc. v. Hartford Insurance Group
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, generally, a breach-of-contract claim cannot be asserted against a nonsignatory to the contract, unless a plaintiff pleads liability on a veil-piercing or alter-ego theory.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Property. Insured businesses could not sue subsidiary insurers' parent for subsidiaries' denial under property policies of claims related to COVID-19 pandemic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cohen's Organization v. Premier Fire Alarms and Integration Systems, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Where parent company is not party to contract, it may be held liable for its subsidiary's breach of contract only where subsidiary is shown to be alter ego of parent and was used to mislead parent's creditors or to fraudulently avoid liability.
Document Preview: TORTS  Joint and Several Liability. Property management company was not jointly and severally liable for tenant's breach of contract with fire alarm installation company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cohen's Organization v. Premier Fire Alarms and Integration Systems, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Fire alarm installation company failed to establish that tenant, which shared same president as property management company, was alter ego of management company, or that it was used to mislead or defraud installation company, which entered into contract with tenant, although cancellation letter provided management company's address, and installation company sent tenant's invoices to management company, and thus management company could not be held jointly and severally liable for tenant's breach of contract.
Document Preview: TORTS  Joint and Several Liability. Property management company was not jointly and severally liable for tenant's breach of contract with fire alarm installation company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Suverant LLC v. Brainchild, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations in apparel manufacturer's complaint for breach of contract against clothing company did not warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold apparel sales entity, venture capital firm, and owner of apparel sales entities liable, although the complaint alleged that there was overlapping ownership and common office space between clothing company and firm, apparel sales entity, and owner, where complaint did not allege that apparel sales entity, owner and firm completely dominated and controlled other apparel sales entity and that this domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong causing injury to manufacturer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Apparel manufacturer could maintain a claim of breach of contract against clothing company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Texas law enforces contracts but disfavors extra-contractual remedies, such as allowing creditors of Texas business entities to sue their owners. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2), (b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, to hold a shareholder personally liable for a corporation's alleged breach of contract, the plaintiff must show that the shareholder used the corporation to (1) perpetrate an actual fraud (2) primarily for the shareholder's direct personal benefit. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2), (b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Sole shareholder of licensee-corporation did not use corporation to perpetrate actual fraud against licensor in entering into sublicense with corporation, and thus licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil under Texas law and hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract provision requiring "commercially reasonable efforts to commercialize" the intellectual property, though licensor asserted that consideration for sublicense was grossly inadequate; shareholder's $75,000 payment did not include sublicense rights and it agreed to non-competition period, corporation had previously entered into similar transactions for no monetary fee with licensor's knowledge, and license did not require licensor's approval for sublicenses or prohibit sublicenses to affiliates. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To impose individual liability for corporate contractual obligations based on piercing the corporate veil under Texas law, a claimant must have been unable to foresee and contractually avert potential risks. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Udelhoven
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy; it is not itself a cause of action, but rather a means of imposing liability on an underlying cause of action, such as a tort or breach of contract.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising out of unperformed contract to construct home could not be excepted from discharge on fraud theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Udelhoven
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, courts are especially reluctant to pierce the corporate veil in breach of contract cases, because the party seeking relief in a contract case is presumed to have voluntarily and knowingly entered into an agreement with a corporate entity, and is expected to suffer the consequences of the limited liability associated with the corporate business form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising out of unperformed contract to construct home could not be excepted from discharge on fraud theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Clear Connection Corporation v. Comcast Cable Communications Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, breach of contract alone is insufficient to establish inequitable result for purposes of an alter ego claim: the breach must be willful.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Indemnity. Telecommunications company's rejection of cable installation company's offer of defense in underlying action did not impact right to indemnification.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a breach of contract can satisfy the "fraud or wrong" element for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trust established under confirmed plan stated actual fraudulent transfer claim based on confluence of fraud badges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Energy Conversion Devices, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: While corporate licensee may have breached its contractual obligation to pay royalties to bankrupt patent holder, liquidation trust established in patent holder's confirmed Chapter 11 plan did not state plausible claim to hold personally liable for that breach the individual who had negotiated licensing agreement on corporation's behalf, as pre-incorporation contract later ratified by it; trust did not allege that, in failing to pay the royalties, corporation had acted as mere instrumentality of the individual, nor did it allege that, with respect to the failure of corporation to pay the royalties, individual personally committed a crime or a tort or that he caused corporation to commit a crime or tort.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trust established under confirmed plan stated actual fraudulent transfer claim based on confluence of fraud badges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: ConSeal International Incorporated v. Neogen Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: While non-signatories are generally not bound by contracts under Florida law, traditional principles of state law may allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Fact issues remained as to whether manufacturer acted in good faith in setting price for chemical under contract with open price term.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: O'Quinn v. TransCanada USA Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver, and estoppel.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Jurisdiction. District Court had specific personal jurisdiction over natural pipeline company with respect to FLSA claims by out-of-state opt-in plaintiffs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pensmore Investments, LLC v. Gruppo, Levey & Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Veil piercing was appropriate against co-founders of advisory firm and others on an alter-ego theory in case in which investment company brought action against advisory firm and others for breach of the Settlement Agreement and veil piercing, where co-founders of advisory firm exercised complete dominion and control over limited partnership, management company, trust, and advisory firm trust, domination was used to commit a fraud, and advisory firm entities would have had sufficient funds to satisfy the underlying debt owed to investment company, but for advisory firm's fraud. N.Y. Debt. and Cred. Law § 273.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil piercing was appropriate against co-founders of advisory firm and others on an alter-ego theory in case in breach of settlement agreement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Array BioPharma, Inc. v. AstraZeneca AB
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: A breach of contract claim generally cannot be asserted against a non-signatory to the contract, unless a plaintiff pleads liability on veil piercing or alter ego theories.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Pharmaceutical developer was not liable for breach of contract between its subsidiary and clinical stage pharmaceutical company to develop compound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Array BioPharma, Inc. v. AstraZeneca AB
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Pharmaceutical developer was not liable for breach of contract between its subsidiary and clinical stage pharmaceutical company to develop chemical compound created by company, where there was no evidence of inequality, fraud, or malfeasance to pierce developer's corporate veil, and developer never assumed subsidiary's rights and obligations under license agreement. N.Y. CPLR § 3211(a)(1).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Pharmaceutical developer was not liable for breach of contract between its subsidiary and clinical stage pharmaceutical company to develop compound.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jass v. CherryRoad Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Under Hawai'i law, under the alter ego theory, a plaintiff may reach a second corporation or individual upon a cause of action that otherwise would have existed only against the first corporation, such as a tort or breach of contract.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Whistleblowing. Former high-ranking corporate executive stated a claim under Hawaii Whistleblower Protection Act (HWPA) against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: ED & F Man Sugar Inc., etc. v. ZZY Distributors, Inc., etc., et al.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to hold owner of sugar distribution corporation personally liable for corporation's debts was warranted in sugar manufacturer's action for goods sold and delivered and breach of contract; owner operated corporation without regard to corporate formalities, and commingled and made personal use of corporation funds by shuttling them between corporation and third parties including other closely held corporations owned by him, acts which resulted in corporation's undercapitalization and rendered it unable to pay its outstanding debt to sugar manufacturer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Distribution company's accounting records showing outstanding balance supported judgment for sugar manufacturer on claim for goods sold and delivered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Home Solutions of Mississippi LLC v. Ridge
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: To cause a court to disregard the corporate entity and justify shareholder liability, a complaining party must produce evidence showing: (1) some frustration of contractual expectations regarding the party to whom he looked for performance; (2) the flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by the defendant corporation and its principals; (3) a fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on the part of the corporate shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Homeowner's action against members of remodeling LLC to hold members individually liable for previous judgment against LLC was not barred by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Chen v. Mah
Court: Supreme Court of Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Trial court's holding of dentist personally liable in entry of default against him and his corporation in independent contractor dentist's action against him and the corporation based on claims of breach of contract and other claims could not be an improper piercing of the corporate veil, where dentist did not address the trial court's conclusion that dentist's liability did not stem from his status as a shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Default. Prospectively, motions to set aside entry of default are governed only by the good cause standard explicitly stated in the corresponding rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: TMCC, Inc. v. Jennifer Convertibles, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A simple breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Landlord failed to allege that tenant's parent company used domination of tenant to breach commercial lease, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Trial court cited correct law regarding identity theory for piercing corporate veil, found facts in support of theory, and examined issue of owner's control of corporation in addition to other factors when making its determination that corporate veil of real estate development entities should be pierced, and thus, court did not improperly apply identity theory, in action by architectural firm against real estate development entities and their owners alleging breach of contract, quantum meruit, and unjust enrichment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Trial court was not required to find that real estate development entities served no legitimate business purpose in order to determine that piercing their corporate veil was appropriate under identity theory, and thus, trial court did not err by not making such determination while piercing corporate veil under identity theory, in action by architectural firm against owners of entities alleging breach of contract and seeking damages for unpaid work that firm had performed on projects.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Breach of contract claim under Pennsylvania law premised on licensing company's principal's own conduct in relation to personal obligations he owed licensees under licensing agreement did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery, since agreement imposed obligation on principal to develop and formulate drug products using his and co-developer's liquisolid technology and he signed agreement in his individual capacity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Breach of contract claim premised on principal's own conduct did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil arises when a party seeks to hold an officer or shareholder of a corporation liable for the contractual obligations of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Breach of contract claim premised on principal's own conduct did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, piercing the corporate veil is relevant to a breach of contract claim when only the corporation is bound by the contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Breach of contract claim premised on principal's own conduct did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: ETC Texas Pipeline, Ltd. v. Addison Exploration & Development, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary pipeline companies and parent energy company shared officers did not establish agency liability on part of parent company for subsidiaries' actions with respect to alleged fraud and breach of contract with oil and gas lease development company absent evidence subsidiaries were acting on behalf of parent, as opposed to on their own behalf.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Energy company and subsidiary pipeline companies did not owe duty to development company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: ETC Texas Pipeline, Ltd. v. Addison Exploration & Development, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Oil and gas development company could not establish agency liability on part of energy company absent evidence that energy company's officers acted as agents of energy company, as opposed to agents of subsidiary pipeline companies, in signing agreements with development company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Energy company and subsidiary pipeline companies did not owe duty to development company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rose v. Different Twist Pretzel, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing licensor's corporate veil to hold its president personally liable for any breach of a master licensing agreement was not warranted, where the president had signed the agreement on behalf of the corporation rather than in his individual capacity, and there was no indication that the corporate form was intended for the commission of a fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing licensor's corporate veil to hold its president personally liable for any breach of a master licensing agreement was not warranted.

Title: Rose v. Different Twist Pretzel, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: An alleged breach of contract, without more, does not constitute a fraud or wrong warranting the piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing licensor's corporate veil to hold its president personally liable for any breach of a master licensing agreement was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Russell Barnett Ford of Tullahoma, Inc. v. H & S Bakery, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Winchester Division.
Headnote: Commercial vehicle seller's allegations that buyer and bakery business shared employees, shared the same business location, and failed to maintain an arms-length relationship among the related entities were insufficient to state claim to pierce the corporate vehicle under Tennessee law, to pursue a contract remedy against both entities, absent allegations that buyer's corporate form was used to commit fraud or wrongdoing, or that fraud or wrongdoing led to the injury from which seller sought relief.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Bakery business was not a party to contract for sale of commercial vehicles, and thus, could not be held liable for breach of that contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gristede's Foods, Inc. v. Madison Capital Holdings LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under the law of Delaware, trial court correctly dismissed plaintiff's claim to pierce corporate veil; after correct dismissal of plaintiff's fraudulent misrepresentation and negligent misrepresentation claims, plaintiff's only remaining claim was for breach of contract, which was not a claim contemplated by common law rule that piercing corporate veil would be appropriate only upon a showing of fraud or something like fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Plaintiff's complaint failed to state cause of action for negligent misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gristede's Foods, Inc. v. Madison Capital Holdings LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, while any breach of contract and any tort is, in some sense, an injustice, obviously this type of injustice is not what is contemplated by the common law rule that piercing the corporate veil is appropriate only upon a showing of fraud or something like fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Plaintiff's complaint failed to state cause of action for negligent misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: AcBel Polytech, Inc. v. Fairchild Semiconductor International, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Agency relationship existed between parent corporation and its wholly-owned international subsidiaries, as required for parent corporation to be deemed seller of voltage regulators sold by subsidiaries, as element of breach of implied warranty of merchantability claim, under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) as adopted by Massachusetts, in action brought by manufacturer of power supply units that incorporated voltage regulators, where parent corporation exercised high degree of control over its subsidiaries. Mass. Gen. Laws Ann. ch. 106, § 2-314(1).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Warranties. Parent corporation could be liable for breach of implied warranty of merchantability based on its wholly-owned subsidiaries' sale of goods.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Brown v. J&W Grading, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Allegation that subcontractor's owner was heavily involved with subcontractor's day-to-day operations, especially regarding the alleged failure of subcontractor to follow per diem agreement, was sufficient for workers, who were hired by subcontractor to assist with hurricane clean-up in Puerto Rico, to state plausible claim for piercing the corporate veil under Puerto Rico law against owner.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. No private right of action existed under Puerto Rico's time and manner of payment law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kahan Jewelry Corp. v. Coin Dealer of 47th St. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In breach of contract claim, plaintiffs failed to show that individual owners of corporate defendants could be held liable for corporation's actions; plaintiffs failed to show or even attempt to argue that owners abused corporate form in any way or engaged in any affirmative fraudulent or wrongful actions, mere fact that one of the owners was sole shareholder of alleged alter ego was not sufficient to pierce corporate veil, and, as to other owner, he was not an owner of either corporate defendant at time of alleged breach of contract, and plaintiffs failed to show that any domination he had over corporate form was abused in order to commit fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. In breach of contract claim, plaintiffs failed to show that individual owners of corporate defendants could be held liable for corporation's actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hickey v. Angelo
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Trial court's finding of no exceptional circumstance warranting piercing corporate veil to hold owner of medical corporation personally liable was not clearly wrong in action by staff physician and business manager for corporation alleging that corporation agreed to reimburse entities owned and operated by physician and manager for rent, utilities, and expenses associated with medical clinics; there was no allegation or evidence of fraud by owner or corporation or that owner commingled personal funds with corporation's funds, owner filed articles of incorporation for corporation and it remained in good standing, there was no evidence of undercapitalization, and owner stated that corporation had separate bank account from which its employees were paid wages.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Finding of no exceptional circumstance warranting piercing corporate veil to hold owner of medical corporation personally liable was not clearly wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Powers v. Caroline's Treasures Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Corporate officers were not liable for breach of contract under Arizona law based on retailer's alleged breach of license agreements with artist; officers were not parties to license agreements, and corporation did not serve as their alter ego.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS  Art and Architecture. Retailer was not liable for removal of copyright management information (CMI) in violation of Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stryker Security Group Inc. v. Elite Investigations Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil in order to reach president of security company was not warranted, in claim by investigations business that president of company breached the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, where business failed to prove that president was doing business in his individual capacity or shuttling personal funds in and out of company without regard to formality and to suit his immediate convenience.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Business could not recover profits that would have been realized had there been no fraud under out-of-pocket rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jennings v. Hunt Companies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court can infer a non-signatory parent corporation's intent to be bound by a subsidiary's contract where the subsidiary is an alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Under New York law, former employee adequately alleged former employer's non-signatory parent company had manifested intent to be bound by contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Fraud constitutes an essential element of an alter ego finding in breached contract scenario.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Diversion of assets was abuse of corporate form that supported veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Art Capital Bermuda Ltd. v. Bank of N.T. Butterfield & Son Limited
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegation by bank that director of lending and servicing companies directed borrower to repay money, not to lender or servicer of loan, but to other companies controlled by director, did not warrant piercing corporate veil of lender or servicer companies to reach director in his individual capacity for the companies' alleged breaches of contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegation that director directed a borrower to repay money to other companies director controlled did not warrant piercing corporate veil of lender.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Art Capital Bermuda Ltd. v. Bank of N.T. Butterfield & Son Limited
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Uncertainty as to whether lender and servicing companies had sufficient assets to satisfy judgment that could potentially be obtained against them, in action by bank for breach of contract, did not warrant piercing corporate veil of companies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegation that director directed a borrower to repay money to other companies director controlled did not warrant piercing corporate veil of lender.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: D'Amico Dry D.A.C. v. Primera Maritime (Hellas) Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was warranted, in judgment creditor's action against judgment debtor to enforce English court's judgment on freight forward agreement concerning future ocean freight rates, to hold liable a group of entities that were controlled by a single family that also controlled the primary judgment debtor; the group of entities were inadequately capitalized and had an overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, they shared common office space and addresses, and there was a lack of corporate formalities, intermingling of funds and property, lack of business discretion, and lack of arm's length dealing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Ship management company was liable as a successor-in-interest for judgment incurred by predecessor in English court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Peeler v. Rocky Mountain Log Homes Canada, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: A non-party may enforce a contract against a party to the contract under certain narrow exceptions to the general rule including, inter alia, third-party beneficiary theory, incorporation by reference, agency theory, corporate veil piercing, assumption, waiver, and equitable estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Question of whether home-construction company made a timely demand to arbitrate dispute with landowner was itself subject to arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Stewart
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the First Circuit.
Headnote: In Chapter 7 case filed by sole officer, director and shareholder of construction company, the record supported piercing corporate veil in order to hold debtor personally liable for injuries sustained by homeowners who had hired debtor's construction company to construct improvements to their home when, after they had paid 90% of total contract price, company walked away from project when construction was only about 45% complete; debtor had fraudulently convinced homeowners to make these prepayments at time when construction company was financially distressed in effort to keep company afloat and to allow it to continue paying debtor's salary and his wife's credit card bills and had thereby used corporate form to promote injustice against homeowners.
