Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: ProTherapy Associates, LLC v. AFS of Bastian, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Virginia, Lynchburg Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, operator's control of nursing homes was insufficient, without more, to pierce corporate veil and hold operator liable, as parent corporation, for nursing homes' breach of restrictive covenant in nursing homes' therapy services agreements with provider of physical-therapy services, which prohibited nursing homes from indirectly employing provider's therapists.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Nursing homes breached restrictive covenants in service agreements with provider of physical-therapy services.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: A finding of fact of alter ego, standing alone, creates no cause of action under Oklahoma law; it merely imposes liability against a second corporation or individual upon an underlying cause of action, such as fraud or breach of contract, brought against the first corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Postpetition actions taken against debtor's principals in state court violated automatic stay, and were void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Etex Apparel, Inc. v. Tractor Intern. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations that two defendant corporations had common owners, shared office, and that, after one corporation ceased its operations, other corporation continued in former corporation's business and, together with new licensee, sold goods to "some" of former corporation's former customers, were insufficient to satisfy heavy burden necessary to pierce corporate veil or to establish alter ego relationship between corporations, as required to sustain breach of contract claims, arising from plaintiff's relationship with former corporation, against surviving corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff did not satisfy burden to pierce corporate veil or show alter ego relationship among defendants in contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Papatheodorou v. Clark
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, control an investment company's sole member had over company was so complete that company had no separation from member, as required to hold member individually responsible for indemnifying bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release to investor money it held for her in escrow account constituted breach of escrow agreement, since member was and always had been sole member of company, member was only person authorized to direct withdrawals and transfers from company escrow account, and member exercised sole and complete control in regard to company's dealings with investor and bank.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Investment company had duty to indemnify bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release money held in escrow constituted breach of escrow agreement

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Papatheodorou v. Clark
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, investment company's sole member exercised control over company as means to perpetrate fraud against bank, as required to hold member individually responsible for indemnifying bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release to investor money it held for her in escrow account constituted breach of escrow agreement, since member, once he had engaged services of bank, sent different versions of escrow agreement attachments to bank and investor, and member intended for bank to comply with his instructions for withdrawals and transfers of funds from escrow account.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Investment company had duty to indemnify bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release money held in escrow constituted breach of escrow agreement

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Papatheodorou v. Clark
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, bank in which investor's money was held in escrow was injured by having to defend itself in lawsuit arising out of false representations investment company's sole member made to investor, and thus member could be held individually responsible for indemnifying bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release to investor money it held for her in escrow account constituted breach of escrow agreement.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Investment company had duty to indemnify bank in action alleging bank's refusal to release money held in escrow constituted breach of escrow agreement

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Trenwick America Reinsurance Corp. v. IRC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Confused intermingling did not occur, as required to pierce corporate veil under Massachusetts law, where plaintiff was not confused about identity of legal entity with which it was contracting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Reinsurer engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices in violation of Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Trenwick America Reinsurance Corp. v. IRC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: A lack of confusion on the part of the other contracting parties precludes veil-piercing under Massachusetts law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Reinsurer engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices in violation of Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kallman v. Pinecrest Modular Homes, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Principal of corporate home construction services provider, and principal of provider's consultant, could not be liable for corporations' alleged breach of verbal contract to provide home construction services, since contract was with provider, principals had acted in their corporate capacities, and there was no basis upon which to pierce the corporate veil to hold them personally liable in that principals had not abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against customer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Corporate principals could not be liable for corporations' alleged breach of verbal contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Salkin v. United Services Auto. Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, life insurer alleged to have wrongly rescinded policy was not alter ego of its parent company, despite presence of parent's logo on correspondence from its subsidiary; companies were separate and distinct legal entities with separate and distinct management and operations, and no "inequitable result" would occur if the two entities were considered to be separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Life insurer's parent company was fraudulently joined to defeat removal based on diversity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Salkin v. United Services Auto. Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, life insurer alleged to have wrongly rescinded policy was not agent of its parent company but, rather, companies were separate entities that operated independently, and parent did not exert control over its subsidiary's actions in issuing or rescinding policies.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Life insurer's parent company was fraudulently joined to defeat removal based on diversity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, for purposes of piercing corporate veil to hold developer, as managing member of corporation that owned property being developed into townhomes, individually liable for breach of contract for townhouse project, developer "controlled" the corporation, where developer directed all aspects of townhouse project, developer participated in construction meetings as an owner, developer identified itself as project owner in correspondence and in construction contract and terminated contract with general contractor, and corporation had no employees of its own and it shared same office as developer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Even though developer, as managing member of corporation that owned property being developed into townhomes, was not a signatory to contract for the construction of the townhomes, developer was liable for breach of contract, under Missouri law, to general contractor under theory of principal-agent relationship, where developer totally dominated and controlled corporation which was a mere business conduit; developer was intimately involved in all aspects of townhome project, contract stated on its face that developer was owner of the project, routine correspondence about project was on developer's letterhead and identified developer as owner, developer participated in construction meetings as owner and issued meeting notes on its letterhead, developer terminated construction contract, and corporation had no employees of its own and shared the same office as developer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced under Puerto Rico law as to owner of booking agency sued by musician for breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty, where there was no evidence that owner had committed fraud or disregarded corporate formalities; agency held annual shareholders' meetings, held business meetings exclusively at office, kept business and personal taxes separate, had independent companies keep its books, and issued shares of stock.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to owner of booking agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Colon v. Blades
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, plaintiff hoping to persuade court to pierce corporate veil must establish that directors acted with intent to defraud and that creditors cannot collect from corporation debt owed them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to owner of booking agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: American Decorative Fabrics, LLC v. Jordan Alexander, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: There was no evidence that a director/treasurer of a corporation had any domination or control of a corporation to warrant piercing the corporate veil in a case where the corporation breached a contract by failing to pay for fabric. There was no evidence that the director had any knowledge of the corporation's purchase of the fabric. Nor was there any evidence that the director benefited from the breach. The evidence demonstrated that the director had resigned as a figurehead officer prior to the contract, and that she had no involvement in the day-to-day activities of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was no evidence that a director/treasurer of a corporation had any domination or control of a corporation to warrant piercing the corporate veil in a case where the corporation breached a contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate buyer's sole owner was not personally liable under California law for the contractual obligations of corporate buyer under the alter ego doctrine; seller's only evidence of a unity of interest was the fact that owner was buyer's sole owner, and many other undisputed facts indicated that buyer and owner did not share a unity of interest-e.g., buyer's employees only did corporate work, buyer's corporate location was separate from owner's home, and buyer's finances were kept separate from owner's finances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate buyer's sole owner was not personally liable for the contractual obligations of corporate buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Port Drivers Federation 18, Inc. v. All Saints Exp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Trucking company and parent corporation sued by contracting truckers lacked sufficient alter-ego relationship to warrant piercing of corporate veil as to parent under New Jersey law; allegations that company was undercapitalized, did not pay dividends and did not have functioning board of directors did not suffice for court to find that company was mere instrumentality of parent.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Carriers. Primary business exemption to federal Truth in Leasing regulations was inapplicable to truckers' claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Latham v. Burgher
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence that roofing company owner and his wife were sole shareholders, that for a three year period the entire amount of roofing company's ordinary business income was distributed to owner and his wife, and that owner accepted a personal loan from business in the amount of $51,000, which company financial records did not indicate was paid back, was sufficient to lead a reasonable and fair minded person to conclude owner was roofing company's alter ego, in homeowner's breach of contract action.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to conclude roofing company owner was roofing company's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bank of America, N.A. v. UMB Financial Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow a contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to the contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, thirty-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Employer was not estopped from disclaiming obligation to arbitrate action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Ryan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, homeowners who executed prepetition home construction contract with corporation of which Chapter 13 debtor was president and sole shareholder failed to establish alter ego as basis for piercing corporate veil; evidence of alter ego included checks and statements properly for corporation's account that debtor received in her name, though homeowners inferred from this that debtor held herself and corporation out as one entity, there was no evidence that third parties believed that debtor and corporation were acting as one entity, debtor explained that those vendors invoicing or uttering checks in her name never did so at her instance, debtor's retention of ten-percent builder's fee did not result in personal liability, though there was some commingling of funds, there was no evidence that debtor placed funds intended for corporation into her own account, and court would not hold debtor personally responsible based on one $77.00 day care bill paid by corporation. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Homeowners failed to establish alter ego as basis for piercing corporate veil and holding debtor personally liable for debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. Reality Racing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Television network failed to show that shareholders and former officers of the reality television program corporation dominated the corporation when the corporation allegedly breached it agreement with the television network. Thus, the shareholders were not the alter ego of the corporation. The shareholders were not controlling shareholders since they only owned 40% of the shares. There were no allegations suggesting the absence of corporate formalities or that the shareholders appropriated the corporation's assets for personal uses.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Television network failed to show that shareholders of a television program corporation dominated the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hettinger v. Kleinman
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, there was such unity of interest between corporation's representatives and corporation that the corporation had no separate personality, and consequently corporate veil could be pierced and representatives held personally liable to investor for breach of contract; representatives used corporation's funds to pay over $100,000 in personal expenses, paid prices well over market to purchase the inventory of an entity in which they held an interest, failed to observe corporate formalities, and it would be unjust to allow representatives to avoid liability for fraudulently inducing investor to invest by making certain misrepresentations with respect to the funding of and prospective business opportunities for the corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Existence of parallel contract claims did not preclude investor from pursuing fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fusion Capital Fund II, LLC v. Ham
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, denying alter ego liability against controlling shareholders of shell corporation would not sanction fraud or promote manifest injustice against investor which had prevailed in litigation over failed merger and was seeking attorney fees under clause of parties' contract; investor knew that corporation was a shell, yet did not even seek guaranty of corporation's debts from shareholders. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability would not be imposed on shareholders for corporation's attorney fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Scarff Brothers, Inc. v. Bischer Farms, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: District court was required to determine whether any fraud, illegality, or injustice was perpetrated, under Michigan law, from use of corporate form to operate feedlot, as required to disregard corporate form and hold shareholders liable, as alter egos, for corporation's breach of contractual duties to cattle broker.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Animals. Any agister status of feedlot owners did not relieve owners of contractual obligations to cattle broker.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pacific Rollforming, LLC v. Trakloc North America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: An investment company was not the alter ego of a financial manager for purposes of liability in a building supply manufacturer's claim against the company and manager for breach of contract, fraud and other business torts under California law. The manager allegedly failed to perform his promise of funding the capital contribution from the company to the manufacturer. A pre-incorporation agreement, which was expressly referenced in the operative complaint, contained a provision which negated this allegation. It stated that should the manager fail to make either of two investment payments in the time prescribed, he would forfeit his entire interest in the company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. An investment company was not the alter ego of a financial manager.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tycoons Worldwide Group (Thailand) Public Co., Ltd. v. JBL Supply Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Facts that corporation's owner was the majority shareholder and an officer of the corporation, and that owner used non-corporate e-mail addresses to conduct corporate business were not sufficient bases for piercing the corporate veil in breach of contract action.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Plaintiff was entitled to summary judgment on breach of sales contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Phillips v. United Heritage Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: If laws of Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) applied to Utah securities corporation's action against officers and directors of TCI corporation to enforce breach of contract judgment, officers and directors would not be individually liable for judgment, where Utah corporation failed to produce evidence of circumstances required to pierce corporate veil under TCI law, and Utah corporation conceded it had no right of recovery against officers and directors for fraud or any other relevant cause of action because it had previously litigated these claims, unsuccessfully, in previous suit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Statute concerning governing law in shareholders' actions applies to non-shareholder directors of foreign corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Phillips v. United Heritage Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: If Texas statute requiring finding of actual fraud to pierce corporate veil when contractual obligation is involved applied to Utah securities corporation's action against officers and directors of Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) corporation to enforce breach of contract judgment, non-shareholder officers and directors were "affiliates" of TCI corporation for purposes of statute providing that any affiliate of a corporation would be under no obligation to the corporation or to its obligees; concept of an "affiliate" had been generally understood to encompass officers and directors. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A) (Expired).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Statute concerning governing law in shareholders' actions applies to non-shareholder directors of foreign corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Foundation, Inc. v. Kirksey
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Music festival sponsor failed to allege facts sufficient to show that sole shareholder was alter ego of his corporation, and thus, shareholder was not personally liable for sponsor's claimed damages in connection with his corporation's alleged breach of contract in failing to provide sponsor with rebates from ticket sales for daytime music events; the alleged breach arose out of obligations owed by corporation, and if it breached the agreement by not paying the rebates, the sponsor was required to seek redress from the corporation. LSA–R.S. 12:93.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Music sponsor's agent had no fiduciary duty in failing to disclose his own company's contract with third party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Two sole shareholders and officers of marketing corporation and sales fulfillment corporation did not use corporations as a facade for officers' operations, and therefore officers could not be held to be the alter egos of corporations absent evidence of other alter ego factors, in case involving allegations of breach of contract and various torts including fraudulent misrepresentation; although officers took money from one corporation when it was struggling to meet its other financial obligations, the money was accounted for, and there was no evidence that the accounting was done improperly. Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 56(c).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Two sole shareholders and officers of corporation did not use corporation as facade.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hinds County, Miss. v. Wachovia Bank N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Purchasers of municipal derivatives alleged sufficient facts to plead prima facie case of alter ego liability against parent corporation which allegedly guaranteed all investment contracts issued by its wholly owned subsidiary and that those guarantees were a "necessary pre-condition" of subsidiary's ability to serve as counterparty to its municipal derivatives transactions. Sherman Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Conspiracy. Purchasers alleged sufficient facts to plausibly connect investment banking and securities firm to antitrust conspiracy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ireland v. Dodson
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, existence of brokerage agreement between aircraft sales corporation and its principal's father did not justify piercing corporate veil to hold father personally liable for corporation's debts, where there was no evidence that buyers believed they were contracting with father rather than corporation or that they would suffer injustice unless father was held responsible for corporation's actions, corporation did not claim that father bore any responsibility for breach of contract, and there was no evidence that corporation was incapable of paying any judgment rendered against it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Brokerage agreement between aircraft sales corporation and its principal's father did not justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Partners Coffee Co., LLC v. Oceana Services and Products Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, shareholders, officers and directors of a corporation may be held liable for corporation's breach of contract under the equitable doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil."
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Gist of the action doctrine did not bar fraud-in-the-inducement counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shade v. Athena Equipment & Supply, Inc.
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division, District Court Department, Southern District.
Headnote: Trial court's imposition of liability on owners of acquiring corporation under doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil," in contract action by owner of acquired corporation against owners of acquiring corporation, was proper; acquiring corporation owners exercised complete control over acquired corporation and other businesses and ran them as one corporation, little evidence existed of businesses' capitalization, owners disregarded corporate formalities and failed to perform their designated offices, and owners' prioritization of debts and obligations was designed to benefit themselves personally.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of liability on owners of acquiring corporation under doctrine of piercing corporate veil was proper.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Heartland Barge Management, LLC v. Dixie Pellets, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Charter company's allegation that the alleged alter ego of a pellet company capitalized, financed, and controlled the pellet company were insufficient to state that the alleged alter ego was responsible for the pellet company's breach of contract. The charter company sued the pellet company and the alleged alter ego for breach of a contract to which only the charter and pellet companies were parties. The charter company alleged that since the alleged alter ego capitalized, financed, owned, controlled and/or managed the pellet company, it should be liable for its breach of contract. However, there were no factual allegations which could plausibly establish alter ego liability.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Charter company's allegation that corporation was the alter ego of the pellet company with whom it contracted lacked evidence of such.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Merrill Lynch Intern. Finance, Inc. v. Donaldson
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: There are five theories under which a non-signatory to an agreement may nevertheless be bound thereby: (1) incorporation by reference, (2) assumption, (3) agency, (4) veil piercing/alter ego, and (5) estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Lender affiliated with former employer was bound by former employer's arbitration agreement with broker in pursuing loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Fast Lane Car Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Where breach of contract is asserted under New York law against a corporate officer or owner, the plaintiff must show both that the officer or owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and that the domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to assert the claim.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Damages. Award of $174,193 was warranted in insurer's action against insured for breach of insurance contract and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bennett v. Itochu Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Competitor sued by health care supply companies, stemming from alleged breach of distribution agreement with third entity, was properly alleged to be liable for breach of contract under Pennsylvania law, pursuant to corporate alter ego theory, where complaint averred that competitor exercised complete dominion and control over third entity with respect to negotiations and execution of distribution agreement.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Privileges. Privilege for communications pertinent to judicial proceedings under Pennsylvania law was applicable to defamation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Insureds' claim that if parent corporation were excused from breach of contract action against parent and subsidiary property insurer, the practices complained of would persist through other subsidiaries other than the one that nominally issued the plaintiff's policy, and would thus work a grave injustice and be fundamentally unfair to the thousands of other policy holders, without additional factual support, was insufficient to impose alter ego liability on the parent under Minnesota or Indiana law.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Class Actions. Insureds could not fairly or adequately represent putative class, barring class certification in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence to indicate that parent corporation or its largest subsidiary ever manifested to a smaller subsidiary property insurer an intent that the insurer would be authorized to bind them by its transactions with insureds, as required, under New York law, to state a claim against parent corporation under actual authority theory of liability.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Class Actions. Insureds could not fairly or adequately represent putative class, barring class certification in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mirabella Foundation v. Saint Claire Livestock Investments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida, Miami Division.
Headnote: A foundation stated a claim for breach of contract against the president of a corporation. An individual assigned to the foundation his rights to a contract with the corporation providing for 50% ownership in a show horse. The foundation alleged that the corporation improperly foreclosed upon and sold the foundation's interest in the horse through an extra-judicial foreclosure sale. The foundation alleged that the corporation was only an agent acting under the control, and for the exclusive benefit, of the president with regard to the contract.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A foundation stated a claim for breach of contract against the president of a corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re HRM Holdings, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Actual fraud, as opposed to constructive fraud, is statutory requirement for entity veil-piercing in Texas, at least with regard to contractual obligations. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code §§ 21.223, 21.224, 21.225; V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21 (Expired).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Chapter 7 trustee for bankruptcy estate of debtor-limited liability company failed to adequately plead veil-piercing claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: IMG Fragrance Brands, LLC v. Houbigant, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporate parent can be held liable for a subsidiary's breach of contract if the plaintiff can show that the parent exercised complete domination of the subsidiary in respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Trademark licensor's relationship with licensee was merely contractual, not fiduciary as required to support fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Corbett v. Firstline Security, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, a party may invoke the provisions of a contract to which it is not an original party only through theories of assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver or estoppel.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Manufacturer was entitled to enforce shortened limitations period contained in contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Griffin Management Corp. v. Carlolina Power and Light Co., Inc.
Court: Superior Court of North Carolina, Wake County, Business Court.
Headnote: Claimant company was not entitled to assert that a subsidiary company of a parent company that the claimant had entered into contract with should be equitably estopped from claiming it was a separate entity and not liable under the contract. The claimant asserted that even if the subsidiary company was not part of the contract, equitable estoppel should stop it from asserting so because the employees of the parent company had communicated as if they were employees of the subsidiary and the parent company's letterhead referenced the name of the subsidiary company. Yet, the claimant should have been aware that their contract was not with the subsidiary because the subsidiary was not even formed when the contract was entered into. The claimant did not demonstrate the inability to discern with whom it was conducting business or show action or reliance on the subsidiary that changed its position prejudicially.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Claimant company, which should have been aware that it had contract only with a parent company and not its subsidiary, was not entitle to assert equitable estoppel against the subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation, as required to impose liability on German corporation for furrier's alleged breach of commission contract with sales representative; even though president of one company was also a sub-board member and consultant to the other, the corporations kept separate bank accounts, books and records, were incorporated at different times for legitimate business purposes, filed separate tax returns, there was substantial compliance with corporate formalities, transactions between the two companies were conducted at arm's length, and there was no evidence of undercapitalization.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: JNS Aviation, Inc. v. Nick Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in a breach of contract case, the corporate veil may be pierced where the defendant shareholder caused the corporation to be used for the purpose of perpetrating and did perpetrate an actual fraud on the obligee primarily for the direct personal benefit of the holder. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Bankruptcy court properly pierced debtor's corporate veil to hold nondebtor owners liable for judgment debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: J. Criss Builder, Inc. v. White
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Owner of building company, which was a corporation, was subject to individual liability to homeowners in their suit against owner and company alleging breach of warranty, negligence, and failure to disclose regarding construction of homeowners' home, which allegedly had foundation defects, as owner was a licensed residential builder, company did not have builder's license, such that it was prohibited from performing residential construction, and, thus, owner, in her individual capacity, was the licensed builder of home. West's A.M.C. §§ 73-59-1(b), 73-59-3(1), 73-59-9(3).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Trial court's grant of additur absent required statutory findings was abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Conduct of software licensee's shareholder in causing licensee to breach agreement with licensor and convert its software by decompiling source code in order to complete conversion by expiration of license did not involve any improper use of corporate form, and licensor was not entitled to piercing of corporate veil; shareholder treated licensee as valid corporation and did not deplete its assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's alleged conduct in causing licensee to decompile software did not entitle licensor to piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, causing a corporation to intentionally breach a contract or commit conversion, without more, does not mislead or defraud creditors such that the corporate veil should be pierced; however, creditors are defrauded incident to a breach of contract or act of conversion where the breaching alter ego transfers funds out of the corporation such that the corporation's creditors cannot collect on their claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's alleged conduct in causing licensee to decompile software did not entitle licensor to piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, while attitude toward judicial piercing of corporate veil is more flexible in tort, legal precepts governing both tort and contract suits are substantially the same.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in order for claimant to establish requisite unfairness caused by acts of corporation and its owners, of kind necessary for him to recover on a sham to perpetrate fraud theory, he must ordinarily demonstrate that he relied upon financial backing of corporation's owners; without such reliance, contract claimant cannot avoid risk of insolvency that it originally accepted as part of its bargain.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: KEMA, Inc. v. Koperwhats
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, licensee corporation's principal and licensee's parent company were not liable for licensee's alleged breach of license agreement, even if principal and parent benefited from contract, and principal participated in alleged breach, absent showing that there was unity of interest or ownership, and that failure to disregard corporate form would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Trade Secrets. Programmer's public disclosure of computer software program precluded him from claiming trade secret protection.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Donald Dean & Sons, Inc. v. Xonitek Systems Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporation that is a non-party to a contract may be held liable under the contract if the plaintiff is able to pierce the corporate veil and show that the nonparty is the alter ego of a contracting party.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Alleged economic pressure resulting from plaintiff's indebtedness to defendant did not result in economic duress.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: GMAC, LLC v. Hillquist
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, where a sole proprietor incorporates solely to defeat an otherwise applicable guarantee and uses the incorporation to the detriment of another, the court may hold the individual liable under the doctrine of equitable estoppel.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Sole proprietor was not liable for successor corporation's debts under theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: GMAC, LLC v. Hillquist
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: Novation and waiver were not viable affirmative defenses to lender's claim against corporation's shareholder for breach of contract by the corporation under theory that shareholder was liable because piercing the corporate veil was warranted, which would treat the shareholder and corporation as the same legal entity with the same debts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Sole proprietor was not liable for successor corporation's debts under theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Tyson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under English law, court would pierce veil of Gibraltar shell corporation involved in international distribution of boxer's professional heavyweight boxing match and would hold United Kingdom (UK) promoter, its partners, and its principals liable forcontractual obligations that they undertook in corporation's name in connection with the fight; shell corporation was not what UK defendants said it was, namely, an offshore affiliate of UK promoter used for legitimate purpose of saving taxes but, i nstead, was someone else's corporate shell, a sham without capital, management, or a business, and corporate form was used to mislead and injure, as UK defendants, though they did not think fight would be financially viable, believed it was excellentchance to advance their interest in boxer's opponent, and used shell corporation to lure Kentucky promoter and boxer into naming that person as boxer's opponent, only to repudiate and attempt to avoid all obligations after fight took pla ce.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Bankruptcy court would pierce veil of shell corporation involved in international distribution of debtor's boxing match.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: East Hampton Union Free School Dist. v. Sandpebble Builders, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: School district failed to allege that corporation owner's conduct abused privilege of doing business in corporate form as would give rise to owner's individual liability on district's breach of contract claim under theory of piercing the corporate veil; nothing in complaint suggested that owner acted other than in his capacity as president and principal owner of corporation in his dealings with the district, or that he failed to respect the separate legal existence of the corporation, or that he treated its corporate assets as his own, or that he undercapitalized the corporation, or that he did not respect corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. School district failed to allege that corporation owner's conduct gave rise to liability under theory of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rogel v. Dubrinsky
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporation's guarantor could not pierce corporate veil to invoke provision of operating agreement prohibiting limited liability entities that formed corporation from seeking contribution from each other for additional capital contributed to corporation in order to avoid contribution of his pro rata share of debt that joint guarantor had repaid, where guarantor was not party to operating agreement, and joint guarantor did not use corporate form to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's guarantor could not pierce corporate veil to avoid contribution to joint guarantor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Schutte v. Petter Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Shareholders' failure to observe many of the corporate formalities, standing alone, was insufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil in home owners' breach of contract claim against corporation's shareholders. Undisputed evidence showed that shareholders failed to comply with articles provisions by entering into loans, charging expenses to credit cards, and signing checks on behalf of the corporation without the required resolutions in place. However, no evidence supported the conclusion that the corporation was used to promote injustice or fraud. Home owners' inability to collect their judgment in the underlying breach of contract case was not enough to show fraud or injustice resulting form use of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholders' failure to observe many of the corporate formalities, standing alone, was insufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil in home owners' breach of contract claim against corporation's shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lewis v. Frazao Bldg. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Contractor was not individually liable under the piercing the corporate veil doctrine for contracting company's breach of home improvement contract; contractor did not have complete dominion over company but rather was an employee of company, did not own any shares of company, and did not have exclusive control over the company's checkbook, company did not abandon the project with the intent to defraud homeowner but rather left the project due to frustration over a number of unresolved issues, including the determination of what the building code requirements were for proposed modified bathroom and garage demising wall, and company was found responsible for a portion of the homeowner's damages for the incomplete project.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Home improvement contract was ambiguous as to the scope of the work to be performed for $43,015 price.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Marc Contracting, Inc. v. 39 Winfield Associates, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil piercing doctrine could not be utilized to bind corporate contractor to operating agreement that required principal of corporate contractor to provide his services in connection with construction of project "without compensation except for reimbursement at cost for expenses incurred" on behalf limited liability company (LLC) that had been established to purchase and renovate premises and then resell premises at profit, although LLC had consisted only of principal and another natural person.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine could not be utilized to bind corporate contractor to operating agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Arthur Andersen LLP v. Carlisle
Court: Supreme Court of the United States
Headnote: Traditional principles of state law allow contract to be enforced by or against nonparties to contract through assumption, piercing the corporate veil, alter ego, incorporation by reference, third-party beneficiary theories, waiver and estoppel.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Appeals. Sixth Circuit had jurisdiction to review denial of request for stay of district court action pending arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hamlet at Willow Creek Development Co., LLC v. Northeast Land Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: President of asphalt company was not personally liable as principal on payment and performance bonds, which were executed on behalf of asphalt company to ensure payment of $1,040,000 in environmental fund fees and related engineering costs arising from excavation of development site, in developer's action to recover funds it paid to town to satisfy fees and costs; president signed bonds in his capacity as officer of company, and not in his individual capacity, and no grounds existed to pierce corporate veil as to reach president's personal assets.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Subrogation. Developer was entitled to recover funds it paid to town for environmental fees as equitable subrogee under payment bonds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hamlet at Willow Creek Development Co., LLC v. Northeast Land Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Principals of excavator and asphalt company did not misuse corporate form for personal ends or otherwise abuse privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice in removing excess fill material from development site, and thus developer could not pierce corporate veil so as to reach principals' personal assets in action for conversion and unjust enrichment.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Subrogation. Developer was entitled to recover funds it paid to town for environmental fees as equitable subrogee under payment bonds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Echostar Satellite Corp. v. Ultraview Satellite, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: The sole shareholder of a satellite television equipment dealer was not an alter ego of the dealer, for purposes of determining liability in a contract action brought by a satellite services company. That the sole could manage the dealer's affairs as he saw fit did not deprive the dealer of its separate corporate existence. Nor could it be said that the sole shareholder commingled personal and corporate funds simply because his salary was paid by transfer from the dealer's corporate account to his family's personal account.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Sole shareholder of satellite television equipment dealer was not alter ego of dealer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Classic Maritime Inc. v. Limbungan Makmur SDN BHD
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Holdings company, which was subsidiary of guarantor of contracts of affreightment (COAs) between charterer and disponent owner, was alter ego of charterer, warranting piercing of corporate veil for purposes of owner's maritime attachment claim for $20,457,047.72 in aid of civil action filed in English court for breach of COAs; charterer was subsidiary of company, which had ability to control charterer's finances and operations, charterer was severely undercapitalized, charterer and company shared two common officers, one common director, as well as common address, telephone number, fax number, e-mail address, and website, and company had made at least four payments of charterer's debts, totaling more than $11 million, on charterer's behalf.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner asserted valid maritime claim against guarantor of charter contracts, supporting attachment of $20,457,047.72.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Arctic Ocean Intern., Ltd. v. High Seas Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporation was not alter ego of charterer, and thus vessel owner was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to extend its breach of charter agreement claim to corporation; although vessel owner received one freight payment from a third company, on behalf of charterer and containing statement that it was care of corporation, corporation and charterer did not share office space, address, or telephone number, and did not commingle funds, cross-collateralize loans, or fail to do business at arms' length.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Eleven months of failed attempts at locating funds subject to Rule B maritime attachment rendered court without jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: 1515 North Wells, L.P. v. 1513 North Wells, L.L.C.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Where there is no evidence of any misrepresentation, no attempt to conceal any facts, and the parties possess a total understanding of all of the transactions involved, state courts will not pierce the corporate veil in a breach of contract situation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Evidence was sufficient to support finding that general partner breached his fiduciary duty to limited partners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mackin v. Jila Const., LLC
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of New London.
Headnote: The homeowners' were entitled to a prejudgment remedy in the form of the attachment of the defendant's real property. The homeowners brought suit against the construction company and its sole member for the breach of a construction contract. The homeowners were able to pierce the corporate veil by showing that the sole member and the corporation comingled funds, and that business was done in the name of both of them. C.G.S. § 52-278c.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The homeowners' were entitled to a prejudgment remedy in the form of the attachment of the defendant's real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Del Monte Fresh Produce, N.A., Inc. v. Chiquita Brands Intern. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Employer's sibling corporation could not sue employer's employee for breach of confidentiality agreement between employee and employer, which imposed a contractual obligation to employer and its subsidiaries or successors.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Privacy. Copying files from employer's computer did not give rise to claim under Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sunoptic Technologies, LLC v. Integra Luxtec, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: A technology company stated a cause of action for breach of contract against the exclusive distributor of its products in Great Britain and Northern Ireland when it alleged that only a fraction of its products required to be purchased under the contract were actually purchased. The company claimed that the distributor set up a shell corporation to purchase the product and then only purchased $17,658.00 of the product when the contract required $200,000 to be purchased. Thus, the company could pierce the alleged shell corporation's veil and bring a breach of contract action against the distributor because the company alleged that the distributor used the shell corporation merely as an alter-ego to protect himself from individual liability.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A company stated a cause of action for breach of contract against a distributor of its products when it alleged the distributor failed to purchase the contractually required amount.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rainworks Ltd. v. Mill-Rose Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporation could not be held liable for breach of license agreement under Illinois or Ohio law, absent evidence that grounds for piercing corporate veil existed.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Assignments and Licensing. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on patentee's false marking claims against licensee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sirrah Companies, Inc. v. Budget Rent-A-Car Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: A rental car corporation did not breach an exclusivity provision in a licensing agreement with rental car business. The business' exclusive right to use the corporation's name to rent cars in its surrounding area did not cover another car rental business being operated under a different corporation's name. Further, the two corporations were not one corporate entity even though they were owned by the same parent corporation. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A rental car corporation did not breach an exclusivity provision in a licensing agreement with rental car business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bogopa Service Corp. v. Shulga
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
Headnote: A default judgment could not be entered against the president of a bankrupt corporation who did not act in any manner other than under the protection of the corporate veil. The plaintiff corporation brought an action alleging the breach of a settlement agreement which was signed by the defendant, in his capacity as the president of his corporation. Because the complaint contained no allegations relating to the elements of piercing the corporate veil or the factors courts consider when deciding whether to pierce that veil, the president could not be found personally liable and default judgment could not be entered against him.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A default judgment could not be entered against the president of a bankrupt corporation who did not act in any manner other than under the protection of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Green v. Ziegelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Circuit court in supplementary proceedings, to enforce judgment against judgment debtor corporation found to have breached architectural agreement, lacked authority to find sole shareholder liable on judgment by piercing debtor's corporate veil; shareholder was not a party previously subject to judgment on claim, and there were no allegations of unlawful transfer of property from corporation to shareholder in avoidance of attempts to collect on judgment, or allegations that shareholder possessed assets legally belonging to corporation. MCR 2.621; M.C.L.A. §§ 600.6104(5), 600.6110, 600.6116, 600.6119, 600.6122, 600.6134.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Circuit court in supplementary proceedings lacked authority to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Priddy v. Rawson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine applies to hold an owner of a corporation liable for the corporation's contractual obligations when there is such unity between corporation and the owner that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(2).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Association's current board acted in good faith when they assessed lots owned by declarant's successor at reduced rate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Zendler Const. Co., Inc. v. First Adjustment Group, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Company, which prepared real property damage estimates for public adjusters, could not maintain causes of action against officers of public adjusting corporations to recover unpaid fees based upon account stated and conversion; claims sounded in breach of contract and not in tort, and there was no basis in the record to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Company did not have immediate right of possession of funds it claimed as unpaid fees, precluding conversion claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Good Hope, Inc. v. Westlake
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Western Division.
Headnote: A corporation claiming that a second corporation breached their oral contract regarding the provision of disaster relief services did not meet its burden to "pierce the corporate veil" and hold two individual employees of the second corporation personally liable. The suing corporation could not demonstrate frustration of contractual expectations or flagrant disregard for company formalities. There was no proof that the two employees personally guaranteed anything in connection with the agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A corporation did not meet its burden to pierce the corporate veil" and hold two individual employees of another company liable in breach of contract suit."

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nassau County v. Richard Dattner Architect, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for alleged breach of contract and negligence of contractor acquired by its subsidiary was not warranted, absent showing that parent dominated and controlled the activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold parent liable for subsidiary's breach of contract

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Indest-Guidry, Ltd. v. Key Office Equipment, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to find president of office equipment corporation personally liable was proper in suit by printing company against equipment corporation for fraud, conversion, and breach of contract, even though there was no evidence introduced at trial to dispute the distinction between the equipment corporation and the president as a natural person; printing company alleged fraud and deceit against president and named him individually in its petition, and president breached the duty of care through personal fault by his negotiations and personal representations. LSA–R.S. 12:93(B), 12:95.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Printing company was a consumer within meaning of the Louisiana Unfair Trade Practices Act (LUTPA).
