Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Even if corporate owner of nursing home could have drawn on its line of credit with bank, to pay invoices from nursing home's therapy services contractor, failure to make such draws did not establish that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against contractor, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable to contractor; shareholder was not legally required to draw on line of credit, failure to make draws avoided increasing corporation's debt to a secured creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nursing Home Group Rehab. Servs., Inc. v. Suncrest Health Care, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Even if failure of corporate owner of nursing home to draw on its line of credit with bank, to pay invoices from nursing home's therapy services contractor, allowed shareholder, as guarantor of corporation's debt to bank, to avoid increasing his personal liability to bank, such conduct did not establish that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against contractor, as element for piercing the corporate veil so as to hold shareholder personally liable to contractor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of nursing home owner would not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Music Express Broadcasting Corp. v. Aloha Sports, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Geauga County.
Headnote: Company demonstrated that control of corporation was exercised in such a manner as to commit illegal act against person seeking to pierce the corporate veil, as element of Belvedere test to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on majority shareholder; majority shareholder benefited from trades that were made with company's stations, deposited funds in his personal account without proper accounting, misrepresented corporation's ability to perform terms of contract entered into with company, and ceased operations without notice to company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. That other persons exercised management authority did not preclude finding that corporation was shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re National Audit Defense Network
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Parent corporation of company with which Chapter 7 debtor had contracted to process its customers' credit card payments could not be sued for breach of contract under the credit card processing agreement executed by debtor and company; as a subagent hired without debtor's express or implicit authority, the parent corporation was not in contractual privity with debtor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee had no turnover claim against company that processed credit card payments made by debtor's customers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Maroun v. Wyreless Systems, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2005 Term.
Headnote: Refusing to pierce the corporate veil of employer, to make shareholders personally liable to employee who joined the start-up company as chief executive officer (CEO), would not result in injustice; employee had been warned that the business was justgetting off the ground, that the business would need to be developed, that more funds needed to be raised, that the business was not yet organized, and that failure of fundraising efforts was possible.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Employer's representations were not actionable as fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish, in breach of contract class action lot purchasers brought against corporate developer, developer's corporate owner and principal behind both corporations after lake in development failed to hold water, that principal was the alter ego of the corporate developer and thus liable for judgment rendered against developer; there was evidence that, while controversy over the breach of contract was pending, developer at the request of principal transferred $2.4 million worth of land contracts to its corporate owner in return for a promissory note without requesting any security for the note, principal never appeared in court or at depositions to explain the transfer, there was evidence that corporate owner of developer subsequently transferred over $5 million in assets to principal such that there were no assets to pay note to developer, and there was no evidence of any transfers of funds from principal back to the corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Foamex, L.P. v. Superior Products Sales, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, seller failed to provide proof of fraud or equivalent misfeasance, as required to pierce corporate buyer's veil and hold its sole shareholder liable, in breach of contract action, for payment allegedly due for products that buyer purchased prior to going out of business, even though shareholder undertook to personally pay some of debts buyer owed to seller, where seller and buyer were each sophisticated business entities sharing a business relationship spanning several years, during which time seller could have required a written guarantee from shareholder personally.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, absent proof of fraud or equivalent misfeasance on part of shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, allegations that corporate seller's shareholder was the "prime mover" in timber agreement, which corporation allegedly breached, and "knew and assisted" in fraudulent sale of corporation's property by unauthorized individual purporting to be corporation's agent were insufficient to show that shareholder engaged in improper conduct, as would support buyer's claim for piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on shareholder, where buyer did not rely on any representation by shareholder in entering into timber agreement with corporation, and there was nothing in the record to refute shareholder's deposition testimony that he did not know of unauthorized individual's representation of corporation and transfer of corporation's property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, shareholder's initial capitalization of corporation with only $2,500, when compared to corporation's later agreement to sell $170,000 worth of timber, was not gross undercapitalization, as would support buyer's claim for piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability for alleged breach of timber contract on shareholder, where there was no showing that shareholder formed corporation without due regard for projected internal costs; unauthorized fraudulent sale of timber land by individual who purported to be corporation's agent was not a reasonably foreseeable liability, nor a risk associated with corporation's normal operating costs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, fact that administratively dissolved corporation was now out of business and could not pay judgment against it was not a sufficient basis on which to conclude that it was undercapitalized when formed, as would support claim for piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability for alleged breach of contract on shareholder who formed corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, allegations that corporation's shareholder improperly drained corporation's assets by making distributions, loans, racehorse purchases, and payments were insufficient to show that shareholder engaged in improper "milking" of corporation, as would warrant piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on shareholder for corporation's alleged breach of contract, where there was no evidence supporting allegations, and purported milking did not cause corporation to breach contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, even if corporation's shareholder improperly drained corporation's assets by making distributions, loans, racehorse purchases, and payments, buyer had adequate statutory remedy for corporation's alleged breach of timber sales contract, and thus, extraordinary remedy of piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on shareholder for corporation's alleged breach was not warranted; statute allowed for enforcement of default judgment that buyer obtained against corporation by potentially recouping any shareholder distributions made to shareholder during liquidation of corporation's assets. West's Or.Rev. Stat. Ann. § 60.645.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Perry v. Unum Life Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold disability insurer's parent company liable for insurer's alleged breach of contract resulting from denial of benefits; parent company was not party to contract, and insured did not allege that insurer had insufficient assets to satisfy her claim.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Disability. Parent of disability insurer was not liable for tortious interference with insurance contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Moses v. Martin
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, celebrity wardrobe stylist's allegations that managing agency with which she had contract acted as alter-ego, business conduit and instrumentality of its principal, and that principal used proceeds from alleged racketeering activity for personal purposes, were sufficient to state claims against principal, including breach of contract and fraud, based on piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. A managing agency could not be held vicariously liable under RICO for acts of its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wafra Leasing Corp. 1999-A-1 v. Prime Capital Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, an exception to the general rule that an officer is not liable for his corporation's breach of contract exists when facts are proven sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Damages. Investor could not seek unjust enrichment or disgorgement damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rimade Ltd. v. Hubbard Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in order to pierce corporate veil in cases based on claims of breach of contract, plaintiff must demonstrate that defendant shareholder caused corporation to be used for purpose of perpetrating, and that shareholder did perpetrate an actual fraud on plaintiff primarily for direct personal benefit of shareholder. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil could not be pierced based on shareholder's alleged fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veils of affiliated corporations could not be pierced, in order to hold them liable for corporate defendant's alleged breach of contract, upon theory that they had knowingly and intentionally procured corporate defendant's breach; other party to contract failed to allege any facts, apart from ownership of corporate defendant's stock and control that these affiliated corporations thereby had over corporate defendant, to support its veil-piercing claim.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: University Medical Associates of Medical University of S.C. v. UnumProvident Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, insured could not pierce corporate veil to hold parent holding company liable for disability insurer's alleged breach of contract and bad faith, even though claims forms and correspondences sent out by insurer had parent's name on letterhead and referenced business of insurer, and insurer had no employees of its own, absent evidence that insurer was undercapitalized, that corporate formalities were not observed, that dividends were not paid, that insurer was insolvent, that there was any siphoning of funds, that there was any non-functioning of officers or directors, or that there was any absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs sufficiently articulated their intent to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fluorine On Call, Ltd. v. Fluorogas Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, licensor's parent corporation could not be liable, under alter ego or single business enterprise theory, for damages resulting from licensor's termination of license agreement, where it had no relationship with licensor at time licensor terminated agreement.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence did not support award of lost asset damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Geiger v. King
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Corporate president was not entitled to use a theory of reverse piercing of the corporate veil to hold parties that contracted with corporation personally liable to president.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not entitled to use a theory of reverse piercing to hold parties liable to him personally.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: DeWitt v. Hutchins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, president of closely-held corporation was not individually liable for corporation's alleged violation of patent law and breach of contract, even though she was dominant shareholder and was exclusively responsible for management and marketing of corporation's products, where contracting party was aware that president was acting on behalf of corporation, and there was no evidence that corporation operated as mere instrumentality or alter ego of president.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not individually liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Unique Envelope Corp. v. GS America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Although he lacked official control over buyer during the relevant period, individual defendant, who had actual control, was the alter ego of buyer and therefore was liable under Illinois law for buyer's breach of contract with envelope supplier and fraud against supplier; the ever domineering presence and authoritarian hand of individual defendant in every business dealing resulted in supplier not getting paid for goods shipped to buyer at the same time that buyer's assets were being transferred to another corporation controlled by defendant for inadequate consideration in violation supplier's rights as buyer's creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual defendant was alter ego of buyer despite lack of official control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Midwest Fuels, Inc. v. JP & K, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Fuel supplier could not pierce corporate veil of company that operated gas station to hold corporate officer liable for nonpayment under supply contract, even though accountant alleged in general terms that company was on verge of insolvency and was operating on a negative case flow, where company had adequate funds available at the inception of the corporation to purchase a gas station and convenience store, there was a corporate bank account, individual and corporate funds were not commingled, and separate books were kept.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fuel supplier could not pierce corporate veil of company that operated gas station.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boswell v. Primary Care Professionals, P.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: President of corporation formed solely for purpose of purchasing medical practice was not individually liable for corporation's default on contract, even though president formed another corporation to operate medical practice after defaulting corporation ceased operation, because of its financial condition, and took leased equipment and medical files from clinic operated by defaulting corporation to clinic operated by new corporation, in view of testimony that corporate president was not party to contract for sale of medical practice between plaintiffs and corporation, corporation president had nothing to do with corporate or financial operations because administrator handled those matters, plaintiffs produced no evidence that debt owed to them by corporation was president's debt, and there was no evidence that president disregarded separateness of legal entities by commingling assets of the two corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation president was not individually liable for corporation's default on contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boswell v. Primary Care Professionals, P.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Possession of patient files belonging to corporation, which had defaulted on contract to purchase medical practice, by newly-formed corporation established by president of defaulting corporation was insufficient to establish disregard of corporate form and commingling of corporate assets, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold president of defaulting corporation individually liable for contractual default by corporation, in view of fact that two corporations were not operating at the same time, and, even if medical files were assets, there was no evidence to show that defaulting corporation's patient files were being utilized by new corporation, or that defaulting corporation's former patients were being treated by new corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation president was not individually liable for corporation's default on contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boswell v. Primary Care Professionals, P.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Fact that newly-formed corporation operating medical practice used certain equipment and employees formerly belonging to corporation that defaulted on contract to purchase medical practice and ceased operations was insufficient to establish that president of defaulting corporation, who had formed second corporation, personally commingled assets of both corporations for his own benefit, as required to impose individual liability on president of defaulting corporation, where, in both corporations, president hired administrator to handle corporate affairs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation president was not individually liable for corporation's default on contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pikewood Manor, Inc. v. Monterrey Concrete Const.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Lorain County.
Headnote: Corporate veil of subcontracting company could be pierced to hold shareholder liable for breach of contract to home contractor, where husband and wife were sole shareholders of company, husband made all the decisions, company held no meetings, maintained no corporate minute books, and took no formal actions, and husband had sole control over company.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Subcontractor was liable to home contractor for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Days Inn Worldwide, Inc. v. Sai Baba, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, franchisees could not justify piercing of their own corporate veil so that they could obtain protection of the Indiana Deceptive Franchise Practices Act from possible liquidated damages for allegedly breaching franchise agreement. West's A.I.C. 23–2–2.7–1.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Parol evidence rule precluded equitable reformation of franchise agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: University Medical Associates of Medical University of South Carolina v. UnumProvident Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, insured could not pierce corporate veil to hold parent holding company liable for disability insurer's alleged breach of contract and bad faith, even though claims forms and correspondences sent out by insurer had parent's name on letterhead and referenced business of insurer, and insurer had no employees of its own, absent evidence that insurer was undercapitalized, that corporate formalities were not observed, that dividends were not paid, that insurer was insolvent, that there was any siphoning of funds, that there was any non-functioning of officers or directors, or that there was any absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Fact that insurer had paid all amounts due under policy did not bar insured's bad faith claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Matheson v. Virgin Islands Community Bank, Corp.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Contract, tort and ERISA claims may be leveled against corporate shareholder or officer if it can be shown that shareholder or officer is doing business in his or her individual capacity without regard to corporate formality,that is, if it is appropriate to "pierce the corporate veil." Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Virgin Islands bank officer's wrongful discharge cause of action accrued before statutory amendment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rosen v. Watermill Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff could not pierce corporate veil so as to impose personal liability on corporation's president for breach of contract, where president entered into contract in his corporate capacity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's president was not personally liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Spanierman Gallery, PSP v. Love
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In action arising from company's sale of artwork to third party before having paid for it in accordance with its contract with gallery, mere fact that officer of company allegedly had decision-making power with respect to both signatory and non-signatory companies was not enough, under New York law, absent showing specific wrongful conduct by non-signatories, to pierce corporate veil, for purpose of stating breach of contract claim against officer and other non-signatories.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Allegations involving breach of contract failed to give rise to tort claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine, a corporation may be bound by an agreement entered into by its subsidiary regardless of the agreement's structure or the subsidiary's attempts to bind itself alone to its terms, when their conduct demonstrates a virtual abandonment of separateness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory Turkmenistan government could not be compelled to arbitrate a contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Miller v. Guimaraes
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Contractor was personally liable to homeowners for breach of contract; contractor had treated his development and construction companies as if they were the same entity, the construction company had no bank account or assets in its name, and contractor had exercised complete domination over the policy and business of construction company.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contractor was personally liable to homeowners for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Spectra Securities Software, Inc. v. MuniBEX.com, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff, which executed a letter of intent pursuant to which the parties agreed to negotiate a mutually acceptable agreement in good faith to provide software, services and support to facilitate principals' establishment of an Internet-based municipal bond trading network, failed to show that principals used their alleged domination of corporation formed to operate the Internet trading network to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold principals liable for breach of definitive agreement executed by corporation; definitive agreement was the product of substantial negotiations, which included discussions on the very issue of corporation executing the definitive agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Showing was insufficient to warrant piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Leber Associates, LLC v. Entertainment Group Fund, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: It was not necessary, under Delaware law, for promoter of singer to proceed against concert promoter with which it had contract, following cancellation of singer's concert, and not receive compensation allegedly due under contract, before proceeding against affiliated limited liability company and owner of both, on theory that concert promoter was their alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Formation request did not establish de facto limited liability corporation

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: S & S Elec., Ltd. v. St. Francis Manor, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: "Piercing the corporate veil" of property owner was not warranted regarding construction contract entered into with general contractor by owner's lessee, which was related corporate entity to owner, although boards of both owner and lessee were identical, and although boards held back-to-back meetings, since there was no commingling of assets, and entities maintained separate checking accounts, books, minutes, records, and financial reports.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. Inherent-agency doctrine did not apply to bind property owner regarding construction contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Iceland Telecom, Ltd. v. Information Systems and Networks Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, Internet provider could not pierce the corporate veil of a telecommunications company's subsidiary on a breach of contract claim in order to hold the founder and parent company liable for the debts of the subsidiary, absent showing of fraud by subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced in order to hold the founder and parent company liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mid America Title Co. v. Transnation Title Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, there was insufficient evidence that title insurance underwriter's two sister companies were its alter egos, precluding piercing of sisters' corporate veils in action against underwriter and parent company by agent having exclusive agency contract with underwriter, alleging that sisters' direct issuance of policies in geographic area covered by contract constituted breach; although three underwriters had overlapping corporate officers and had consolidated their operations after coming under parent's common ownership, and no longer dealt with each other at arm's length, there was no showing that sisters were sham corporations formed to siphon off underwriter's and agent's business, that underwriters neglected any corporate formalities, that policyholders were confused about which underwriter they dealt with, or that underwriters held themselves out as being single entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Common ownership and consolidation of operations was insufficient to allow veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: John T. Callahan & Sons, Inc. v. Dykeman Elec. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Newly formed corporation was not liable for other corporation's alleged breach of contract on alter ego, disregarding corporate entities, or piercing of corporate veil theories under Massachusetts law, although both corporations had same management, ownership, purpose, address, telephone and facsimile numbers; other corporation was in receivership and under control of receiver before new corporation was formed, and other corporation was insolvent before new corporation purchased its assets through judicial sale of which creditor was aware.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creditor failed to show that new corporation was liable on mere continuation theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Binder v. National Life of Vermont
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, an insured who was denied disability insurance benefits failed to state a claim for breach of contract against the alleged "parent or controlling entity" of the insurer on a theory that the parent was the insurer's alter ego, such that the corporate veil could be pierced to reach it, absent any allegation that the parent completely dominated the insurer; the only allegation that directly dealt with the relationship between the two corporations was the conclusory statement that the parent was the "parent or controlling entity" of the insurer, and the only other allegations with respect to the parent's role in a claim denial stated that it and its employees handled the insured's appeal.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Insured failed to state claim for breach of contract against insurer's alleged parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Oncology Therapeutics Network Joint Venture, L.P. v. Olympia Fields Internal Medicine Associates, S.C. (Inc.)
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Customer of medical products supplier was not liable for products ordered by independent company located across street, which placed orders using customer's account number, in absence of any showing of affiliation, or authorization.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Defendant had not waived service of complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cary Oil Co., Inc. v. MG Refining & Marketing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish claim for piercing of corporate veil between seller of petroleum products and its indirect owner under New York law, buyers were required to show that indirect owner's control and domination over seller was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured buyers, as parties seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Experts. Plaintiffs were not entitled to examine compensation of opposing party's experts for bias.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ohio City Orthopedics, Inc. v. Medical Billing And Receivables, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Mere fact that medical billing corporation's president was the sole shareholder and officer of the corporation was not sufficient to demonstrate that she had absolute, complete and final authority over the corporation, such that the corporate veil could be pierced in customer's breach of contract action.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. There is no tort claim for negligent performance of a contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Precision, Inc. v. Kenco/Williams, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under both Michigan and Delaware law, parent corporation was not alter ego of its subsidiary, and therefore was not liable for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract; subsidiary maintained its own office and records, had its own bylaws, maintained its own board of directors, and was not created for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not alter ego of its subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cardone v. Pereze
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate veil of business corporation which provided management services for fertility center would not be pierced to reach sole not-for-profit corporate member of not-for-profit health care corporation which was sole stockholder of business corporation, as to physician's claim against business corporation for breach of contract; physician alleged that individual who was both president of not-for-profit corporate member and officer of business corporation represented, when negotiating the contract, that not-for-profit corporation was part of "large corporate structure" and "[h]ospital family" and that business corporation "has all the support from the hospital and has all the financial backing of the hospital."
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Physician satisfied requirement of pleading fraud with particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Traverso v. Clear Channel Communications, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, corporate veil of company that purchased corporation would not be pierced to hold purchasing company responsible for corporation's contract with plaintiff, where corporation remained viable, and purchasing company had not plundered or commingled its assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Purchasing company would not be held responsible for purchased corporation's contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Acree v. McMahan
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil concept may be applied in reverse to impose contractual liability upon corporation not a party to contract in issue by showing that its principal shareholder had merged individual identity into that of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Issue of whether shareholder breached buyout agreement by failing to make payments was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hunt v. Stephens
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support order piercing the corporate veil, in home owner's damages action against home builder; home builder testified that the home building corporation bearing his name no longer existed that it had no assets, that he was now building home under a limited partnership that bore his name, and that the limited partnership was paying for all of his legal fees and for all of the legal fees of the home building corporation. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support order piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: McVeigh v. Unumprovident Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, insured could not pierce corporate veil to impose liability on insurance company's parent in bad faith action to recover benefits under disability income policy, even if parent held itself out on its website to be integrated with insurer, and parent's stationary was used in correspondence with insured, where parent did not exert complete domination over insurer's finances, policy and business practices, insurer was adequately capitalized, and parent observed corporate formalities.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Disability. Insurer acted in bad faith in denying claim for residual disability benefits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Worldcom, Inc. v. Prepay USA Telecom, Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Alleged commingling of corporation's funds, with those of principals, amounting at most to few thousand dollars, was insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil by claimants alleging millions of dollars in damages in breach of contract case.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced in contract breach case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Parent holding company of disability insurer could not be held liable, under alter ego theory, for insurer's alleged breach of contract and covenant of good faith and fair dealing, arising out of its denial of disability benefits to insured; although claims forms and correspondences sent out by insurer had parent's name on letterhead and referenced business of insurer, using pronouns such as "we," "us" or "our," companies shared corporate officers and directors, and exchanged money via loans, there was no unity of interest, and no inequitable result would follow from not applying alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Parent holding company could not be held liable for insurer's actions under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shaw v. Maddox Metal Works, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Without allegation of fraud, fact that corporate employer was undercapitalized did not in any way create issue of material fact as to whether owner used employer as alter ego, so as to render him individually liable to surviving spouse on claim that employer breached oral agreement to pay surviving spouse lifetime annuity following employee's death, even though undercapitalization was factor to be considered in determining whether corporation was being operated as alter ego, given that surviving spouse indicated that she did not believe that owner used employer to engage in fraud, and without fraud, claim was not sufficient for imposition of individual liability. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subds. A, B.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Without fraud allegation, employee's surviving spouse could not use alter ego theory against owner of employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: VSS Sales, Inc. v. Uni-Seal Valve Co.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 7, California.
Headnote: Seller of defective valves was alter ego of its parent, allowing buyer to pierce corporate veil and obtain judgment against parent; seller never issued stock, and had no capitalization, existing only on infusions from parent when necessary, had common director with parent, and failed to observe many corporate formalities
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil on non-capitalized subsidiary could be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: United Feature Syndicate, Inc. v. Miller Features Syndicate, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York choice of law rules, Canadian law governed question whether corporate veil of Canadian corporation could be pierced, to allow contract and tort suit by New York distributor of newspaper features against officers of corporation which had acted as its agent.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Computers and Online Services. Unauthorized Internet display was potential copyright violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shelton v. Clements
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Builder's corporation was operated as alter ego of builder, allowing trial court to pierce builder's corporate veil in homeowner's action against builder for fraud and breach of contract associated with builder's failure to complete construction of home; corporation had no assets, builder used construction loan account to pay some of his own minor personal expenses, had billed owner for certain equipment and labor related to projects for other customers, purchased certain materials for the construction of owner's house on his personal credit cards, and, when he did not pay those debts, he later instructed those creditors to place liens on owner's house.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence was sufficient to support finding that builder breached contract to construct log cabin.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Quantum Color Graphics, LLC v. Fan Association Event Photo GmbH
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In Illinois, corporate alter egos are jointly and severally liable for breach of contract.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Allegations were sufficient to support exercise of specific jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: H & R Project Associates, Inc. v. City of Syracuse
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: City and school district were not owners of redevelopment corporation, and corporation was not their alter egos, precluding piercing of corporate veil to hold city and district liable for corporation's breach of contract for redevelopment of buildings.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Statute noncompliance barred contract action against school district.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kellers Systems, Inc. v. Transport Intern. Pool, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Pursuant to internal affairs doctrine, Illinois' choice-of-law principle in cases alleging impropriety of corporate governance, Illinois law governed buyer's claim that seller's purported alter-ego was liable for seller's alleged breach of agreement for sale of seller's semi-trailer leasing business, notwithstanding purported alter-ego's contention that Pennsylvania law applied pursuant to agreement's choice-of-law provision, given that purported alter-ego was incorporated in Illinois, was not party to agreement, and was not involved in sale.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contract's indemnification provisions did not encompass fee-shifting in lawsuit between parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: UST Corp. v. General Road Trucking Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Parent of soil reclamation processing company ratified joint venture agreement between its subsidiary and management company, and, thus, was liable for subsidiary's breach of contract, even though parent was not a signatory to the agreement, where parent's president signed agreement as subsidiary's president despite fact that he was not a corporate officer of subsidiary, all money due the subsidiary was deposited in parent's account without any payment or consideration to subsidiary, and parent controlled the policies and practices of subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Joint venturer was entitled to a new trial to determine its lost profits from breach of the agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kelsey v. A & A Metal Fabricating, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: President and sole shareholder, who exercised complete domination over corporation, could not hide behind corporate veil and was bound by covenant not to compete in stock purchase agreement in which corporation represented to buyer that president would not compete with corporation for three years following sale of corporation to buyer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President and sole shareholder was bound by covenant not to compete in corporation's stock purchase contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wausau Business Ins. Co. v. Turner Const. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to pierce the corporate veil between a subsidiary and its parent company, the plaintiff need not show that the relationship between the two companies had any causal relationship to the contract dispute between the plaintiff and the subsidiary; rather, disregard for the corporate form is itself sufficient to warrant piercing the corporate veil for equitable reasons.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Intermingling of funds and sharing of officers raised fact issue on whether to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fiumetto v. Garrett Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: When a party enters into a contractual relationship with a corporation, a relevant consideration in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is whether the party is misled into believing a shareholder or director is also a party; however, tort victims do not choose to become victims of particular tortfeasors or rely upon the tortfeasor's ability to compensate them.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Private right of action for retaliatory discharge for claiming unemployment compensation could be implied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Artech Information Systems, L.L.C. v. Tee
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Computer consultant could bring breach of professional services agreement suit against principal of putative corporation that was providing services, under Connecticut law, on grounds that putative corporation was alter ego of principal, pursuant to either instrumentality or identity rules, when provider made showing that principal maintained corporation as "assetless shell," which transmitted all revenues to principal without regard to any corporate formalities.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Noncompete terms of computer services agreement were reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Artech Information Systems, L.L.C. v. Tee
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, failure to incorporate subjected owner of corporation to liability for breach of professional services agreement.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Noncompete terms of computer services agreement were reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: A. Servidone Inc. v. Bridge Technologies LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporation related to dissolved subcontractor, which had legally distinct and independent existence apart from subcontractor, had no claim against prime contractor for alleged nonperformance or against its surety on bond, where sister corporation was not party to subcontract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent of dissolved subcontractor had no authority to sue to enforce subcontract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: A. Servidone Inc. v. Bridge Technologies LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation of subcontractor did not have authority to enforce subcontract by virtue of its status as parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent of dissolved subcontractor had no authority to sue to enforce subcontract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. CMC Steel Fabricators, Inc. v. Harrop Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Corpus Christi Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced under Texas law so as to hold parent liable for affiliate's breach of contracts for the fabrication and delivery of steel for three construction projects since there was insufficient evidence to conclude that corporate parent participated in either contract formation or nonperformance with contractor; however, corporate veil would be pierced with respect to contractor's tort claims since an alter ego relationship existed between parent and affiliate.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Supplier was not liable for consequential damages caused by breach of contract and fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rio Grande Valley Gas Co. v. City of Edinburg
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Liability for natural gas franchisee's conduct in violation of franchise agreement with city was not limited to franchisee, but extended throughout franchisee's corporate family, and was not extinguished by another corporation's purchase of franchisee.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Liability for franchisee's conduct extended throughout natural gas suppliers' corporate family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Louisiana Lift & Equipment, Inc. v. Eizel
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of buyer of forklift could not be pierced to hold owner of corporation liable for judgment arising out of purchase; bill of sale showed that the buyer was corporation as represented by owner, invoice/receipt for transaction was signed by owner with no indication of his representative capacity, but block on invoice specifying "Sold To:" provided corporation's name, and certificate from Secretary of State showed that no certificate of dissolution had been issued.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Sales. Sale of forklift by lessee could not be aned by lessor on ground that sale increased lessee's indebtedness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: T & S Products, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: A parent corporation and a subsidiary are in law separate and distinct entities, and under ordinary circumstances a contract in terms and in name with one corporation cannot be treated as that of both, and a parent will not be liable for the obligations of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS - Bidding. Contracting agency could consider parent company's promised resources in evaluating bid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dews v. Ratterree
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Question of whether corporate veil of garage door company should be pierced in tort action was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ross v. Jill Stuart Intern. Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Finding of liability as against the codefendant was not prerequisite to asserting breach of contract claims against defendants based on their alleged alter-ego relationship with codefendant.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Finding of codefendant's liability was not prerequisite to contract claims against defendants based on alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: City of Dearborn v. DLZ Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, fact that city was aware at time of contracting that engineering design firm's affiliates were involved in wastewater project precluded it from piercing corporate veil to hold affiliates liable for firm's obligations under contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. City could not pierce corporate veil to get at contractor's affiliates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Beverly Enterprises, Inc. v. Herman
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Relationship between parent and subsidiary alone is not enough to render subsidiary liable on parent's contract.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS - Preferences and Set-Asides. Selection of contractor for affirmative action compliance review did not violate Fourth Amendment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hollowell v. Orleans Regional Hosp. LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, a finding of fraud is not required in order to pierce the corporate veil in a contract action.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Defendant was an employer subject to WARN notification requirement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Farmers Ins. Exchange v. Sorenson
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced, to impose noncompetition commitments of insurance agent toward insurer on sole shareholder of corporate agent, who was former agent of insurer; shareholder admitted that corporation was formed for purpose of evading preexisting noncompetition obligations toward insurer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Noncompete Agreements. Noncompete agreement supported injunction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mid-Missouri Telephone Co. v. Alma Telephone Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Agency theory or principles governing piercing of the corporate veil did not apply to make parent company of cellular telephone subsidiary comply with right of first refusal provision of limited partnership agreement between its subsidiary and other cellular subsidiaries of other telephone companies, absent allegation that parent exerted such control that subsidiary was alter ego of parent or that subsidiaries either acted as agents on behalf of parents, or destroyed distinction between corporations.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Right of first refusal did not apply to proposed sale of parent company of cellular phone company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Garrett v. Women's Health Care of Gwinnett, P.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Conduct of incorporated clinic's owner in ordering accountant to deduct operating costs in calculating clinic's gross profits for purposes of determining amount of physician's production bonus did not justify piercing corporate veil in order to hold owner individually liable for breach of contract in connection with calculation of bonus, where accountant determined method of calculating physician's bonus.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Conduct of clinic's owner did not justify piercing corporate veil in physician's breach of contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Garrett v. Women's Health Care of Gwinnett, P.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Conduct of incorporated clinic's owner in loaning corporation money did not justify piercing corporate veil to hold owner individually liable, in physician's claim for breach of contract in connection with calculation of production bonus, absent showing that owner disregarded corporate form or acted as though corporation were her alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Conduct of clinic's owner did not justify piercing corporate veil in physician's breach of contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re RBGSC Inv. Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that defendant corporations which signed management, license and consulting, or settlement agreements were all related to each other because they shared a common corporate parent did not mean that each corporation could be considered a signatory to each agreement, in absence of specific circumstances which called for a piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Leases and Contracts. Debtor's rejection of executory contract terminated its obligations thereunder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re RBGSC Inv. Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Division.
Headnote: Defendant's status as parent corporation of one of the parties to license and consulting agreement did not render it liable for this party's undertakings under agreement, in absence of a successful alter ego or veil-piercing claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Leases and Contracts. Debtor's rejection of executory contract terminated its obligations thereunder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Automated Salvage Transport, Inc. v. NV Koninklijke KNP BT
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Suppliers of recycled paper could bring breach of contract claim against packaging materials manufacturer, despite argument that any contractual relationship was with subsidiary which supplied raw materials to manufacturer; when record indicated that subsidiary was both actual and apparent agent of manufacturer.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. There was fact issue regarding agency status of waste paper buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stockacre Ltd. v. PepsiCo, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced in a breach of contract action brought against a corporate bottler and its parent corporation by a buyer/reseller of carbonated beverages from the bottler, absent evidence demonstrated that the parent exercised sufficient dominion and control over the bottler.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Denmark was better forum than New York for British company's contract action against Danish bottler.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Transportation broker which had contracted with freight forwarding corporation failed to show that second forwarder, which had its corporate headquarters at same address as corporation, exercised such dominance that corporation was its mere instrumentality, or, even if such dominance occurred, that second forwarder abused privilege of incorporation to perpetrate a fraud or injustice or otherwise circumvent the law, as required to pierce corporate veil under New Jersey law; agreement made no reference to second forwarder, corporations kept separate books, records, accounts, facilities, and employees, and single inter-corporate transaction did not show requisite control.
Document Preview: Transportation broker brought suit in state court against freight forwarders, alleging breach of contract. After action was removed, and order was entered with respect to discovery disputes, 181 F.R.D. 229, defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Arcara, J., adopted the report and recommendation of Foschio, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) fact that transportation broker had failed to obtain license from Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) to perform brokering services did not render agreement unenforceable; (2) fact issues as to whether contractual agreement existed, and if so, nature of relationship created, precluded summary judgment; and (3) broker failed to establish basis to pierce corporate veil of forwarder which was not party to agreement. Report and recommendation adopted, and motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Quinn v. Thomas H. Lee Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no showing of domination of weight loss clinic franchisor, which would allow franchisee claiming breach of contract to pierce corporate veils and reach assets of shareholder of corporate parent of franchisor; franchisor was operated separately from parent.
Document Preview: Terminated weight loss clinic franchisee sued franchisor, its parent company, shareholders of parent, and surety issuing bond covering conservator and trustee of assets of franchisee and her husband in divorce proceeding, alleging conspiracy, breach of contract, negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. Defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Sprizzo, J., held that: (1) franchisee would not be granted additional time in which to complete discovery; (2) franchisee failed to establish existence of conspiracy between franchisor and subfranchisee to launder money; (3) shareholders of franchisor did not owe franchisee duty to ensure that franchisor did not collect excessive sums from subfranchisee; (4) corporate veil would not be pierced to allow franchisee to satisfy her claims against shareholders of parent of franchisor; (5) purchaser of assets of franchisor at foreclosure sale had not participated in de facto merger, so as to be liable for debts of franchisor; (6)...
