Headnote: Under Illinois law, corporate veil could not be pierced in order to hold hotel management companies liable for hotels' alleged breach of their contracts with telecommunications company, though principal officers of management companies were also part owners of hotels, and though management companies had represented themselves to telecommunications company as entities responsible for operation of hotels.
Document Preview: Telecommunications services company brought suit against hotels and hotel management companies for their alleged breach of contract.  The District Court, Aspen, J., held that telecommunications company was collaterally estopped from denying that it had breached its contracts with hotels based on judgment previously entered against it by bankruptcy court at trial of bankrupt hotel's objection to company's claim. Partial summary judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Oregon RSA No. 6, Inc. v. Castle Rock Cellular of Oregon Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Corporate structure may not be used to avoid contractual obligations and defeat legitimate expectations of other parties under Oregon law.
Document Preview: Limited partner brought action against another limited partner being sold, its parent corporations, and buyer to establish right of first refusal to purchase limited partner's interest.  Plaintiff moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Panner, J., held that: (1) sale of limited partner without offering right of first refusal to plaintiff violated covenant of good faith and fair dealing implied in limited partnership agreement, and (2) limited partner and its parent corporations could be treated as single entity so that parent corporation was subject to plaintiff's right to first refusal. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: St. Katherine Ins. Co. Ltd. v. Insurance Co. of North America, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, unless there was evidence to suggest that separate corporate existence of parent and subsidiary was illusory and that they were not dealing at arms-length, but were, in effect, abusing corporate form, corporate form ought not to be disregarded in determining coverage under general liability policy's completed operations hazard clause for injuries sustained by parent's employee on completed operation built by subsidiary on parent's property.
Document Preview: Umbrella insurers brought diversity action against general liability insurer and insureds, seeking declaration that loss was not a completed operations hazard loss under general liability policy.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Harry D. Leinenweber, J., entered judgment for defendants, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that loss resulting from fall by employee of parent corporation into sulphur pit built by subsidiary on parent's property was completed operations hazard loss covered by general liability policy insuring both parent and subsidiary. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Ripple, Circuit Judge, filed dissenting opinion and would grant petition for rehearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wilson v. DelPapa
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Attachment of individual's property in suit for breach of contract to sell business operated by corporation was not improper act of corporate veil piercing; given evidence that individual appeared to be acting in his personal capacity in bargaining with buyers, it was reasonable for court to infer, for purposes of attachment motion, that individual was either acting in his own behalf or on behalf of corporation as undisclosed corporate principal.
Document Preview: In suit for breach of contract, order of attachment was entered by the Superior Court, Hancock County, Mead, J., and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Judicial Court, Clifford, J., held that: (1) given ample competent evidence supporting finding as to plaintiffs' likelihood of success, order would not be disturbed even though plaintiffs made certain factual assertions at hearing going beyond the affidavits; (2) underlying contract was not barred by the statute of frauds; and (3) there was sufficient evidence for trial court to have been convinced that it was more likely than not that plaintiffs would recover at least the $150,000 amount attached. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mills v. USA Mobile Communications, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Because contract with corporation is contract with that legal entity and not with individual shareholders, courts are even more reluctant to disregard corporate entity when dispute involves contract as opposed to tort. Code, 31-1-89.
Document Preview: Seller of corporation brought suit against purchasing corporation and its shareholders.  The Circuit Court, Mingo County, Elliott E. Maynard, J., granted summary judgment for all defendants except selling corporation and its representative, and struck damages to be awarded for malicious prosecution. Seller appealed.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, Miller, J., held that seller failed to show the type of conduct by shareholders of purchasing corporation necessary to warrant imposing shareholder liability on verdict against corporation, though there may have been inflated promises made to seller. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mills v. USA Mobile Communications, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced if complaining party demonstrates some frustration of contractual expectations regarding party to whom he looked for performance, flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by defendant corporation and its principals, or fraud or other equivalent malfeasance on part of corporate shareholder. Code, 31-1-89.
Document Preview: Seller of corporation brought suit against purchasing corporation and its shareholders.  The Circuit Court, Mingo County, Elliott E. Maynard, J., granted summary judgment for all defendants except selling corporation and its representative, and struck damages to be awarded for malicious prosecution. Seller appealed.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, Miller, J., held that seller failed to show the type of conduct by shareholders of purchasing corporation necessary to warrant imposing shareholder liability on verdict against corporation, though there may have been inflated promises made to seller. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Capital Parks, Inc. v. Southeastern Advertising & Sales System, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, Waco Division.
Headnote: Veil of corporation would not be pierced to hold one shareholder liable with respect to shareholders' sale of their stock to third party, despite plaintiff's claim that such sale violated plaintiff's right of first refusal with respect to purchase of corporation's subsidiary; plaintiff's option contract bound only corporation and plaintiff, not corporation's shareholders, offer to purchase stock and assets of corporation did not violate option contract, which was only triggered by bona fide offer to purchase subsidiary, and, because corporation would be merged into purchaser, right of first refusal would continue to be liability binding upon purchaser.
Document Preview: Optionee sued corporation for specific performance of agreement granting optionee right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of corporation's subsidiary.  Corporation moved to dismiss for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., held that offer to purchase corporation's stock did not violate optionee's right of first refusal. Motion granted. Affirmed 30 F.3d 627.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Capital Parks, Inc. v. Southeastern Advertising & Sales System, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, Waco Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, optionee, which sought specific performance of agreement with parent corporation granting optionee right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of subsidiary corporation, failed to establish that subsidiary corporation was alter ego of parent, as required to pierce corporate veil of subsidiary, so that offer to purchase stock and assets of parent was not offer to purchase stock and assets of subsidiary; contract was binding only upon parent, and there was no evidence that any of parent's shareholders created parent as corporate fiction to avoid any liability under contract.
Document Preview: Optionee sued corporation for specific performance of agreement granting optionee right of first refusal with respect to purchase of stock or assets of corporation's subsidiary.  Corporation moved to dismiss for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Walter S. Smith, Jr., J., held that offer to purchase corporation's stock did not violate optionee's right of first refusal. Motion granted. Affirmed 30 F.3d 627.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jiffy Lube Intern., Inc. v. Weiss Bros., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Individuals signing covenant not to compete ancillary to franchise agreement on behalf of their corporation were personally bound by covenant; enforcement against individuals was required to protect legitimate interests of franchisor, since corporation was essentially alter ego of individuals.
Document Preview: Quick-lube franchisor brought motion for preliminary injunction to prevent franchisee from using its trademarks or violating noncompetition agreement after franchise agreement was terminated for underreported sales figures.  The District Court, Irenas, J., held that: (1) New Jersey Franchise Practices Act applied based on franchisee's place of business within state, and its gross sales exceeding $35,000, more than 20% of which were derived from franchise; (2) franchisor had good cause for terminating agreement; (3) franchisor was entitled to preliminary injunction to prevent franchisee from using its trademarks; and (4) covenant not to compete was enforceable, subject to further temporal and geographic limitations. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Franchisee which had obtained arbitration award against franchisor was entitled to pierce corporate veil and collect judgment from franchisor's parent corporation where, at time of breach, franchisor had observed no corporate formalities for at least two years, had no assets or paid employees or functioning board of directors, and its operations and assets had been absorbed into the parent and where the action which breached the franchise agreement was taken in name of the parent and not the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Franchisee brought suit to compel parent corporation of franchisor to satisfy judgment obtained against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement, pursuant to arbitration.  Piercing the corporate veil was denied by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 802 F.Supp. 1006, and franchisee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that piercing of corporate veil was appropriate as franchisor had ceased to function as separate entity and its operations and assets had been absorbed into parent, and act constituting breach of franchise agreement was taken in the name of the parent. Reversed and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Greater Kansas City Roofing
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Showing of inequity necessary to satisfy the second prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil must flow from the misuse of the corporate form, and mere fact that corporation commits unfair labor practice, breaches a contract or commits a tort does mean individual shareholders of corporation should personally be liable.
Document Preview: The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) brought action seeking enforcement of supplemental order holding individual shareholder as well as successor corporation liable for unfair labor practice judgment.  The Court of Appeals, Ebel, Circuit Judge, held that NLRB was not entitled to pierce corporate veil even though shareholder disregarded corporate employer as separate entity, absent evidence that shareholder used corporate structure to promote fraud or that disregard of independent corporate existence led to injustice or evasion of legal obligations. Enforcement denied as to shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Matter of Sims
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In absence of fraud, alter ego doctrine is inapplicable to case in which corporations' claims sound in contract rather than tort.
Document Preview: Related corporations filed involuntary bankruptcy petitions against debtors.  The Bankruptcy Court granted relief, and appeal was taken.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Charles Schwartz, Jr., J., reversed, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Barksdale, Circuit Judge, held that separate identity of corporations affiliated with fast-food franchisor would not be disregarded, for purposes of determining number of creditors filing involuntary bankruptcy petition. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Statesville Stained Glass, Inc. v. T.E. Lane Const. & Supply Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: In contract action, corporate entities of dissolved corporation and newly formed corporation, which had common sole shareholder, were not disregarded and sole shareholder was not held individually liable on dissolved corporation's contract, as there was no evidence that shareholder was party to contract, that shareholder used dissolved corporation to conduct personal business or for personal profit, or that shareholder used dissolved corporation to defraud plaintiff, and plaintiff did not contract with newly formed corporation.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate entities of dissolved corporation and newly formed corporation were not disregarded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Trust Fund Detroit and Vicinity v. Lange
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego is treated as single continuous employer, and contractual obligations of one element of alter ego are binding on the others.
Document Preview: Unions brought action under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) to enforce arbitration award granted under collective bargaining agreement. Cross motions for summary judgment were made.  The District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) owner of corporate employer was collaterally estopped from denying personal liability; (2) separately formed corporation was alter ego of corporate employer; and (3) unions were entitled to attorney fees and costs incurred in ERISA enforcement action. Arbitration award enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kaeser & Blair, Inc. v. Willens
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, corporate obligee may not avoid its contractual obligations by continuing its operation under different corporate name.
Document Preview: Corporation which purchased list of commissioned, independent sales agents from two other corporations that were subsequently dissolved sued son of owners of former corporations and his newly established corporation alleging breach of fiduciary duty and breach of contract as result of son's use of names on list to generate business for his new corporation.  Son and his corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Aspen, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact as to whether son usurped protected property interest from purchaser of list precluded summary judgment in favor of son on Illinois law breach of fiduciary duty claim; (2) genuine issue of material fact as to whether son's new corporation was continuation of dissolved corporations under different corporate name precluded summary judgment in favor of corporation on Illinois law breach of contract claim; and (3) court would defer ruling on issue of whether unity of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ruti v. Knapp
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff did not allege or demonstrate any reason to disregard corporate entity or the rule of shareholder immunity, and, thus, trial court properly dismissed breach of contract complaint against individual defendant; plaintiff conceded that individual signed contract as president on behalf of corporation, and plaintiff did not allege that individual exceeded scope of his authority in acting on behalf of corporation, or that individual committed separate tort from that of corporation. McKinney's CPLR 3211; McKinney's Business Corporation Law § 715.
Document Preview: Arbitration. Foreign corporation could move to compel arbitration, even though it did business in state without authority.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stephens v. American Home Assur. Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Retrocessionaires seeking to hold parent corporation of reinsurance company liable for any losses retrocessionaires might sustain under retrocession contracts failed to show basis for piercing corporate veil under Kentucky law where parent corporation provided sufficient capitalization initially, though reinsurance company later suffered insolvency, and observed various corporate formalities, despite shared officers and directors and contract under which parent provided management services to reinsurance company, and where, though reinsurance company paid dividends to parent while insolvent, there was no indication that its president had knowledge of insolvency and no showing that dividends were excessive in light of insurance company's reported yearly earnings.
Document Preview: Actions were brought by liquidator of insolvent reinsurer seeking coverage from certain retrocessionaires and premiums from companies which had ceded insurance risks to reinsurer, and defendants in two of the actions impleaded reinsurer's parent corporation and certain officials of Kentucky Department of Insurance.  On various motions for determination of defenses, for summary judgment, to vacate or to reconsider, and to dismiss, the District Court, Martin, J., held that: (1) New York law applied to determining validity of retrocession agreements though reinsurer was Kentucky corporation and insolvency proceeding was in Kentucky; (2) defense of fraud and remedy of rescission for fraudulent inducement of retrocession contracts were not rendered unavailable as matter of New York law by mere fact of insolvency proceedings; (3) no basis was shown for piercing parent corporation's corporate veil; (4) partial summary judgment granted by state court...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Auto Club Ins. Ass'n v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil of employer corporation and finding that employee was "named person" so as to render applicable automobile insurance policy covering vehicle driven by employee was not warranted in action involving priority dispute among insurers; there was no allegation of any fraud, illegality, or injustice by any member of corporation and corporation was not party to action. M.C.L.A. § 500.3114(1).
Document Preview: Occupant" of Vehicle. Employee who was injured while pumping gasoline was not occupant of vehicle under No-Fault Act provision."

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Application of Kummerfeld
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporation's failure to follow corporate formalities was insufficient to raise fact issue requiring hearing on whether corporation was individual's alter ego, so as to require individual to arbitrate pursuant to agreement signed in representative capacity, where there were no allegations of fraud or any evidence that individual used corporation for anything other than the business for which the corporation was formed. McKinney's CPLR 7503(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ENTITIES - Alter Ego. Failure to follow corporate formalities, alone, did not raise fact issue on alter ego claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hanrahan v. Audubon Builders, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of construction corporation was proper to avoid injustice and to hold owners personally liable for damages caused by delay in completing contract where owners had treated corporation as a proprietorship and there was ample evidence of commingling of personal and corporate funds; evidence of loss to corporation by commingling of funds or other improper or fraudulent corporate actions was not required to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liquidated Damages. Clause in construction contract clause constituted unenforceable penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mid-Century Ins. Co. v. Gardner
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, for purposes of allowing automobile insurer to treat corporate vehicles as vehicles of corporate principal which were not listed on policy, merely because principal owned all of corporate stock, either singly or in combination with wife, and conducted business without change following its incorporation.
Document Preview: Automobile insurer sued for declaratory judgment regarding coverage provided by policy.  The Superior Court, Sacramento County, Richard C. Creeggan, J., entered judgment in favor of insurer, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Sparks, J., held that: (1) corporation's principal shareholder and chief executive officer was not owner of corporate vehicles, within meaning of exclusion from uninsured motorist coverage for owned vehicles not listed in policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to permit insurer to treat corporate vehicles as vehicles of principal; and (3) other insurance exclusion could not be interpreted to preclude coverage. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: 111 Properties, Inc. v. Lassiter
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Assertion of vendor that formation of purchaser corporation was fraud and subterfuge to keep partner of vendor from knowing that it was really the sole stockholder of purchaser who was purchasing the property was insufficient grounds for piercing the corporate veil of the purchaser.
Document Preview: Vendor brought action against purchaser corporation and corporation's sole stockholder for breach of contract and fraud.  The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, Thomas Johnson, J., entered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Gunther, J., held that: (1) even if formation of corporation was subterfuge to conceal identity of purchaser from vendor, that was not ground for piercing corporate veil, and (2) purchaser corporation did not breach agreement to assist vendor in collecting back taxes and back rent from tenant where tenant was insolvent and any effort to collect would have been futile. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: China Basin Properties, Ltd. v. Allendale Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Fact that leased premises occupied by subsidiary were insured under policy obtained by parent to cover number of business locations leased by subsidiaries, and that parent negotiated insurance claim settlement with insurer after fire at premises were insufficient to pierce corporate veil and find that subsidiary was alter ego of parent.
Document Preview: Lessor brought suit in state court against fire insurer which paid $6.5 million property loss damage claim to parent of subsidiary which occupied leased premises.  After removal on basis of diversity jurisdiction, plaintiff amended complaint to add parent and subsidiary, and voluntarily dismissed insurer.  On subsidiary's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Armstrong, J., held that: (1) last principal place of business of subsidiary, a defunct corporation, would be utilized in determining its citizenship, and since last such place was California, diversity jurisdiction did not exist; (2) activities of parent in winding-down business of subsidiary did not alter determination of subsidiary's last principal place of business for diversity purposes; and (3) subsidiary was not alter ego of parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Foster Wheeler Energy Corp. v. Metropolitan Knox Solid Waste Authority, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, corporate veil of solid waste authority created jointly by city and county could not be pierced to impose liability upon city and county in suit for breach of contract to construct, operate and manage solid waste incinerator; city and county were not equity owners in waste authority, and fact that they had placed directors on authority's board and agreed to help make authority succeed was not sufficient nexus on which to predicate their liability.
Document Preview: Contractor sued city and county for breach of contract between contractor and solid waste authority, which was nonprofit corporation created jointly by city and county, neither of whom were equity owners in authority.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert Leon Jordan, J., denied defendants' motion to dismiss.  Defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Contie, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced to hold city and county liable, and (2) Tennessee Interlocal Cooperation Act did not provide for liability of city and county. Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Boyle v. Jacor Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under New York law, mere fact that parent corporation owned all stock of subsidiary did not justify piercing corporate veil so as to enable former officer and director of subsidiary to recover directly from parent payments allegedly due on note and consulting agreement with subsidiary.
Document Preview: Former corporate officer and director filed suit against parent corporation, demanding payment and interest on note and consulting agreement with subsidiary.  On plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Spiegel, J., held that: (1) Ohio choice of law rules applied; (2) under New York law, parent corporation's ownership of all of subsidiary's stock did not justify piercing corporate veil, and fact that parent's checks had been used to make recent payments to plaintiff did not unequivocally establish that parent had assumed subsidiary's obligations; and (3) genuine issues of material fact, as to whether parent and subsidiary had operated in such a manner as to justify piercing corporate veil, precluded summary judgment. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Chateaugay Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate parent was not alter ego of subsidiary, and thus not liable for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract, absent showing that parent was in control of subsidiary's actions with regard to transaction at issue or that any control possessed by parent was exercised to commit fraud or violate other legal duties, or to act dishonestly or unjustly in contravention of breach of contract plaintiff's legal rights.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor objected to proofs of claim.  The Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was not liable for subsidiary's breach of contract, and (2) claims against third party were subject to indemnification by debtor. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 126 B.R. 165.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Chateaugay Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts are generally more reluctant to pierce corporate veil for voluntary or contract creditor, than for involuntary or tort creditor.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor objected to proofs of claim.  The Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was not liable for subsidiary's breach of contract, and (2) claims against third party were subject to indemnification by debtor. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 126 B.R. 165.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Chateaugay Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary was not agent of corporate parent, for purpose of holding parent liable for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract, absent evidence that subsidiary had actual authority to sign contract on parent's behalf or that plaintiff reasonably could have believed that subsidiary was acting as agent of parent when it entered into contract.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor objected to proofs of claim.  The Bankruptcy Court, Burton R. Lifland, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was not liable for subsidiary's breach of contract, and (2) claims against third party were subject to indemnification by debtor. Motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 126 B.R. 165.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: First Realvest, Inc. v. Avery Builders, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Shareholders, officers, and directors are not held liable for corporation's breach of contract, absent establishment of participation theory or successful assertion of equitable doctrine of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: After counterclaim asserting breach of contract by corporation was filed, separate action alleging breach of contract was filed against corporation and its shareholders.  The Court of Common Pleas, Chester County, Civil Division, No. 9006083, Joyner, J., dismissed complaint in the separate action on demurrer, and plaintiff appealed.  The Superior Court, No. 1035 Philadelphia 1991, Olszewski, J., held that: (1) complaint alleging breach of contract by corporation did not plead sufficient facts to establish individual liability of corporate shareholders under participation theory, although complaint alleged legal conclusion that contract was in fact with shareholders; (2) complaint alleging breach of contract by corporation did not state cause of action against corporate shareholders under equitable doctrine of piercing the corporate veil; and (3) remainder of complaint against corporation alleging breach of contract was properly dismissed...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Crabtree v. Tristar Automotive Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Without facts to suggest that equitable remedy of ignoring corporate form was required, justice precluded suit against individual officers of corporation for breach of corporation's contract.
Document Preview: Seller of business brought fraud, breach of contract, and RICO action against buyer.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) dispute was not covered by narrow arbitration clause in the parties' agreement; (2) complaint did not state cause of action for fraud based on breach of contract; (3) complaint did not state cause of action for RICO; (4) complaint did state cause of action for negligent inducement; and (5) complaint did state cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty. Motion to compel arbitration denied, and motion to dismiss granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Smith v. MBL Life Assur. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Insurer and its parent company would not be treated as distinctly separate entities for purposes of determining whether parent company should have issued life policy to insured even though insured's application was made to insurer and not to parent company; insurer was wholly owned subsidiary of parent, those two companies shared several directors, the majority of insurer's officers were also officers of parent, and all of underwriting for insurer was done by underwriting department of parent.
Document Preview: Beneficiary of alleged life policy sued insurer and its parent company to recover under that policy.  The Jefferson Circuit Court, No. CV843028, Stuart Leach, J., entered directed verdict in favor of defendants on bad faith claim, entered judgment on jury verdict for beneficiary on breach of contract claim, and entered jnov for defendants on fraud claim.  Beneficiary appealed and defendants cross-appealed.  The Supreme Court, Ingram, J., held that: (1) evidence supported jury's finding that defendants breached contractual duty to issue life policy to insured; (2) beneficiary failed to present any evidence that she relied upon defendants' statement that there was no insurance coverage on insured's life; and (3) beneficiary failed to prove she was entitled to directed verdict on her contract claim. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Consun Food Industries, Inc. v. Fowkes
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Lorain County.
Headnote: Trial court properly disregarded distinction between grocery store franchisees and their corporation, which was solely created by franchisees for business purposes related to grocery store in franchisor's action to prevent franchisees from terminating franchise agreement; franchisees were unable to distinguish between themselves and corporation, and store's purchase by corporation would have altered status quo of proceedings.
Document Preview: Franchises. Franchise agreement that did not contain durational term was terminable by either party upon reasonable notice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stedman Energy, Inc. v. Lenape Resources Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: First corporation's corporate veil could not be pierced in order to impose liability on second corporation in action for breach of gas well-tending agreement, where there was no proof that second corporation was a mere department, division or alter ego of first corporation, or that second corporation was undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from judgment of the Supreme Court, Chautauqua County, Ricotta, J., entered in action for breach of gas well-tending agreement.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) corporation's corporate veil could not be pierced in order to impose liability on another corporation, and (2) exculpatory clause in agreement was insufficiently clear and unambiguous to be enforceable. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stedman Energy, Inc. v. Lenape Resources Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Liability could not be imposed upon corporation in action for breach of gas well-tending agreement merely because it and another corporation that entered into agreement were coinsured under liability policy.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from judgment of the Supreme Court, Chautauqua County, Ricotta, J., entered in action for breach of gas well-tending agreement.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) corporation's corporate veil could not be pierced in order to impose liability on another corporation, and (2) exculpatory clause in agreement was insufficiently clear and unambiguous to be enforceable. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Import Sales, Inc. v. Continental Bearings Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: President of corporation selling goods (seller) who was also shareholder of corporation buying those goods (buyer), and other shareholder of buyer, were not original parties to lawsuit brought by buyer against seller, for purposes of seller's action against them, on grounds that buyer was their alter ego. S.H.A. ch. 110, ¶¶ 2-608(a), 2-614(a).
Document Preview: Corporation which was buyer of goods (buyer) sued selling corporation (seller) for breach of contract.  Seller brought combination counterclaim and third-party action seeking to add to lawsuit president of seller who was also shareholder of buyer, and the other shareholder of buyer.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Thomas P. Quinn, J., dismissed the counterclaim and third-party claim and appeal was taken.  The Appellate Court, LaPorta, J., held that: (1) third-party action could not be maintained, to extent that it called for relief other than indemnification or contribution from individuals, and (2) trial court erred by dismissing entire complaint with prejudice. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Megaris Furs, Inc. v. Gimbel Bros., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Concession operators could not maintain breach of license agreement action against parent corporation of department store which made agreement since parent corporation did not completely dominate and control with respect to transactions at issue nor use control to direct department store employees to defraud operators.
Document Preview: Concession operators brought action against department store and its corporate owner for alleged breach of license agreements and tort.  Department store's motion for summary judgment was partially granted and operators' motion to amend their complaints were granted by the Supreme Court, New York County, Edwards and Ciparick, JJ.  Concession operators appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) provision of license agreement which allowed termination upon department store's discontinuation of business was enforceable; (2) no cause of action for negligent performance of contract existed; (3) statute of frauds barred claims of fraudulent inducement; (4) parent corporations' corporate veils were not pierced; and (5) department store had no duty to disclose decision to discontinue operation of store. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bergesen d.y. A/S v. Lindholm
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under either federal common law or Connecticut's "instrumentality rule" or "identity rule," corporate veil could be pierced in maritime case to hold related corporations and corporate directors liable for charterer's anticipatory breach of "time charter" agreements, where there was overlapping ownership of most corporations, corporations had common offices and directors, corporations operated out of same location on largely informal basis, consolidated financial statements and accounting records were prepared for corporations, evidence pointed to complete control of all corporations by two directors, directors' control appeared to have been purposefully exercised so as to deprive ships' owner of any economic incentive to enforce its contract rights, corporate assets were commingled and defused, and cash freely and informally flowed from one corporation to another.
Document Preview: Owner of ships brought action against charterer, guarantor of charterer's obligations, related corporations, and corporations' directors for breaches of charter contracts, fraud, tortious interference with contractual relations, civil conspiracy, and violation of Connecticut Unfair Trade Practices Act.  Owner filed application for writ attaching defendants' property.  The District Court, Thomas P. Smith, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) owner established probable cause to sustain validity of its claims, and therefore would be granted prejudgment attachment of defendants' property; (2) Connecticut prejudgment remedy statutes were not unconstitutional, either facially or as applied; (3) credible evidence showed that defendants' breach was reasonably likely to result in approximately $20 million in contract damages to owner over balance of charter parties; and (4) corporate veils would be pierced under either federal common law...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) PTE., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Franchisee that recovered judgment from franchisor for breach of contract failed to show that franchisor's parent corporation was directly liable on contract under actual authority theory of New York agency law; parent was not named party to franchise agreement, agreement contained no representations by parent to either franchisee or franchisor as to franchisor's authority as its agent, and oversimplification of corporate relationships in press release was not determinative.
Document Preview: Franchisee that had recovered judgment against franchisor for breach of franchise agreement sought to satisfy judgment against franchisor's parent corporation.  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Leisure, J., held that: (1) material issues of fact existed as to whether piercing corporate veil was appropriate, and (2) franchisee failed to establish fraudulent misrepresentation at time of contracting or parent's liability on agency theory. Plaintiff's motion denied, defendants' motion granted in part and denied in part. See also 130 F.R.D. 28.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gottehrer v. Viet-Hoa Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold corporate officer individually liable was not warranted in action for breach of contract, absent showing that officer utilized his position to perpetuate a fraud upon the plaintiff or corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from judgment of the Supreme Court, Kings County, Hurowitz, J., entered in action for breach of contract.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) contract did not obligate corporate officer in his individual capacity, and (2) piercing corporate veil to hold corporate officer individually liable was not warranted. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Omaha Indem. Co. v. Royal American Managers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Corporations which were controlled by two shareholders and which were used by those shareholders to perpetrate injustice and fraud were alter egos of shareholders and could be held liable to plaintiffs for damages caused by shareholders under Missouri law in action alleging breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, fraudulent misrepresentation, prima facie tort, and civil conspiracy.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporations and shareholders alleging breach of contract, and breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, fraudulent misrepresentation, prima facie tort, civil conspiracy and equitable relief. Claims against one corporation were submitted to arbitration and corporation was found liable.  Plaintiffs moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Bartlett, J., held that: (1) corporate officers and shareholders were personally liable for tortious conduct of their corporation, and (2) corporations controlled by shareholders were also liable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: CNC Service Center, Inc. v. CNC Service Center, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, corporate veils would be pierced to hold president and director personally liable for corporations' breach of contract, where they had engaged in imaginative and misleading financial recordkeeping, disregarded corporate structure in numerous respects, used clearly improper reasons to declare purported contractual defaults, purported to rescind contract when they knew that such rescission could not be implemented, and "lined" their own pockets with large salaries that corporations could not support.
Document Preview: Alleged buyer of business assets brought action against seller's sole shareholder and successor in interest for breach of warranty of title, fraud in the inducement, common-law fraud, and breach of employment agreement. Successor filed counterclaim against alleged buyer, related corporation, alleged buyer's president, alleged buyer's director, and business brokerage firm formed by alleged buyer's president, alleging fraud, violation of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, breach of contract, and securities fraud.  The District Court, Shadur, J., held that: (1) alleged buyer had not suffered harm, and thus was not entitled to damages, for seller's breach of warranty of title; (2) seller's successor failed to establish misrepresentation in connection with purchase or sale of stock, and thus could not prevail on securities fraud claim; and (3) president and director were personally liable for corporation's breach of contract under...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: CNC Service Center, Inc. v. CNC Service Center, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, president and director were liable for corporations' breach of contract pursuant to "alter ego" doctrine, where they had controlled corporations, and had diverted corporate funds to themselves so that corporations were unable to meet their obligations.
Document Preview: Alleged buyer of business assets brought action against seller's sole shareholder and successor in interest for breach of warranty of title, fraud in the inducement, common-law fraud, and breach of employment agreement. Successor filed counterclaim against alleged buyer, related corporation, alleged buyer's president, alleged buyer's director, and business brokerage firm formed by alleged buyer's president, alleging fraud, violation of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, breach of contract, and securities fraud.  The District Court, Shadur, J., held that: (1) alleged buyer had not suffered harm, and thus was not entitled to damages, for seller's breach of warranty of title; (2) seller's successor failed to establish misrepresentation in connection with purchase or sale of stock, and thus could not prevail on securities fraud claim; and (3) president and director were personally liable for corporation's breach of contract under...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lener v. Club Med, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for negligence or breach of contract in connection with injuries sustained by passenger when he slipped and fell on excursion boat owned by parent corporation's partially-owned subsidiary, even though parent corporation provided some personnel and administrative technical services to subsidiary; passenger failed to show that parent exercised such complete domination and control over subsidiary that parent could be held liable for torts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Passenger who was injured on an excursion boat sued the resort owner and its parent corporation for negligence and breach of contract.  The Supreme Court, Westchester County, Marbach, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, and granted resort owner's motion to vacate the default judgment entered against it.  Passenger appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) parent corporation was not liable for the torts of resort owner, and (2) resort owner failed to establish existence of a meritorious defense. Affirmed in part, and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: H & H Distributors, Inc. v. BBC Intern., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. III.
Headnote: Parent corporation is not liable for breach of purchase contract by subsidiary unless subsidiary is determined to be alter ego of parent.
Document Preview: Shoe distributor sued shoe importer and its subsidiary for fraud and breach of contract.  The District Court, Denver County, H. Jeffrey Bayless, J., rendered judgment for shoe distributor, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Marquez, J., held that: (1) jury finding that importer's failure to disclose detrimental information about branded shoe program and its statements that program was still viable constituted false representation and concealment for purposes of fraud was supported by evidence, and (2) jury award of damages against importer for subsidiary's breach of purchase contract was inconsistent with jury's failure to find that subsidiary was alter ego of importer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: H & H Distributors, Inc. v. BBC Intern., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. III.
Headnote: Jury award of damages against athletic shoe importer but not against its subsidiary for subsidiary's breach of purchase contract with shoe distributor was inconsistent with jury's failure to find that importer was alter ego of subsidiary; importer could not be liable for subsidiary's breach unless it had been alter ego.
Document Preview: Shoe distributor sued shoe importer and its subsidiary for fraud and breach of contract.  The District Court, Denver County, H. Jeffrey Bayless, J., rendered judgment for shoe distributor, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Marquez, J., held that: (1) jury finding that importer's failure to disclose detrimental information about branded shoe program and its statements that program was still viable constituted false representation and concealment for purposes of fraud was supported by evidence, and (2) jury award of damages against importer for subsidiary's breach of purchase contract was inconsistent with jury's failure to find that subsidiary was alter ego of importer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Newport Steel Corp. v. Thompson
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold president personally liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract; there was no suggestion that president ever commingled any of corporation's funds or assets with his own, nature of corporation's ownership and control did not indicate that president used corporation as mere instrumentality for his own affairs, and there was no evidence that legal formalities necessary to maintain corporate status were ignored.
Document Preview: Steel pipe manufacturer brought action against president of supplier alleging breach of contract, conversion, and unjust enrichment when supplier deposited check customer had sent to supplier instead of to manufacturer.  President moved to dismiss or for summary judgment.  The District Court, Sherman G. Finesilver, Chief Judge, held that: (1) supplier's depositing of check did not constitute conversion under Colorado law, and (2) corporate veil of supplier could not be pierced to hold president liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wilkerson v. Wegner
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Panel One.
Headnote: Owners of mares who entered into breeding contract with corporation, allegedly due to corporation's halter futurity contest which was later cancelled could not pierce corporate veil to hold individuals personally liable for damages allegedly resulting from cancellation of contract based upon claim that no capital contribution was made to corporation and thus corporation was not adequately capitalized to meet liability flowing from futurity; corporation came into existence pursuant to statute then in effect when articles of incorporation were filed, and thereafter, stallion service contracts were executed in corporate name. ORS 60.051.
Document Preview: Owners of mares who entered into stallion service contract with corporation allegedly based upon corporation's advertisement of halter futurity contest which was later cancelled brought action against corporation and individuals for prize money.  The Superior Court, Benton County, Carolyn Brown, J., granted summary judgment in favor of corporation and individuals, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Green, J., held that: (1) corporation was validly formed and insulated individuals from liability; (2) claim was speculative; and (3) owners were not entitled to amend complaint to include claim for specific performance. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fort & Turner Enterprises, Inc. v. Scrocca
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Three related corporations, selling insurance under one trade name, could be held liable, under theory they were joint participants in a common enterprise, for the failure of one corporation to obtain insurance for client; corporations had the same owners and officers, held themselves to public as being components of single business operation, collectively entered into contract for their common benefit under the trade name, and collectively initiated underlying litigation.
Document Preview: Corporate defendants engaged in business of selling insurance appealed from judgment of the Superior Court, Fulton County, Cooper, J., entered in action based on their alleged failure to procure insurance policy for which premium had been paid.  The Court of Appeals, Banke, P.J., held that related corporations could be held jointly liable on theory that they were joint participants in common business enterprise. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hyzer v. Hickman
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Parties entering into contractual relations with corporations are entitled to assume that corporation is more than a shell.
Document Preview: Purchaser of home from corporate vendor, and contractor who built home for vendor, sued shareholder seeking to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder responsible for corporation's obligations.  The State Court, Fulton County, Bruner, J., entered summary judgment for shareholder, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether corporate veil could be pierced because corporation was undercapitalized and had made preferential distributions to shareholder while insolvent. Reversed. Carley, C.J., and Beasley, J., concurred in judgment only. Deen, P.J., dissented and filed opinion in which Sognier, J., joined.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cascade Energy and Metals Corp. v. Banks
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Reverse piercing of corporate veils of Utah corporation, limited partnership, and trust affiliated with gold mine project promoter was not warranted; it was unclear as to whether Utah had adopted doctrine of "reverse" piercing, particularly for consensual contract-like transaction, there was no dispute that promoter's related entities were validly organized and met de-jure formation requirements, and claimants failed to show how their injury was connected with entities' commingling or lack of formalities or how claimants relied on entities' separateness or the lack thereof.
Document Preview: In a diversity case involving a dispute over gold mine between the mine's principal promoters and a group of investors, the United States District Court for the District of Utah, A. Sherman Christensen, J., found that promoter and affiliated corporation which was managing agent for joint venture breached fiduciary duties owed to joint venture, decided to reverse pierce entity veils of related entities, and found working interests in gold mine were not securities.  Individual and affiliated entities appealed and investors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ebel, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported finding that owner and manager of gold mine breached fiduciary duty to investors who purchased working interests in gold mine; (2) decision to reverse pierce corporate veil among related entities was improper; (3) investors' interest in mine were securities under federal and state securities laws;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cascade Energy and Metals Corp. v. Banks
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Analysis of corporate veil issues is different in a consensual transaction such as a breach of contract case than in a nonconsensual transaction such as many tort cases.
Document Preview: In a diversity case involving a dispute over gold mine between the mine's principal promoters and a group of investors, the United States District Court for the District of Utah, A. Sherman Christensen, J., found that promoter and affiliated corporation which was managing agent for joint venture breached fiduciary duties owed to joint venture, decided to reverse pierce entity veils of related entities, and found working interests in gold mine were not securities.  Individual and affiliated entities appealed and investors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ebel, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported finding that owner and manager of gold mine breached fiduciary duty to investors who purchased working interests in gold mine; (2) decision to reverse pierce corporate veil among related entities was improper; (3) investors' interest in mine were securities under federal and state securities laws;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Baker's Aid, a Div. of M. Raubvogel Co., Inc. v. Hussmann Foodservice Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation is generally not liable for contracts of its subsidiary unless parent dominates subsidiary to such degree that subsidiary is "mere instrumentality" of parent with no will of its own.
Document Preview: Oven buyer brought action against supplier to enforce restrictive covenant. On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, McLaughlin, J., held that: (1) supplier was contractually obligated to turn over and not use oven specifications following termination of supply agreement; (2) covenant not to compete was enforceable to extent it was reasonable; and (3) covenant not to compete did not violate antitrust laws. Buyer's motion granted in part and denied in part; seller's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Streamlight, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Only if contract rises to level of justifying wrong, protecting fraud, or defending crime will parent be liable for subsidiary's obligations and will subsidiary's corporate veil be pierced.
Document Preview: Debtor commenced adversary proceedings seeking to recover account receivable. The Bankruptcy Court, David A. Scholl, J., held that: (1) press release announcing merger of debtor's customer with customer's parent was insufficient to establish merger in legal sense of term so as to hold surviving corporation liable for customer's obligations under New York law; (2) parent corporation of debtor's customer was not liable for customer's debts; and (3) violation of New York transfer law entitled debtor to all remedies available to it. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Commercial Union Ins. Co. v. La Villa Independent School Dist.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Action of contractor's president, majority shareholder and chief executive officer in writing letter to school district stating that he would personally fund payment for corrective work on school gymnasium did not provide basis for piercing corporate veil so as to render president, chief executive officer and shareholder personally liable for breach of contract by contractor, where not only were letters written for settlement purposes so as to avoid litigation, but contractor had always been operated as independent entity.
Document Preview: School district brought suit against contractor, contractor's surety, and president, chief executive officer and majority shareholder of contractor seeking damages for breach of contract for construction of gymnasium for school district.  The 332nd District Court, Hidalgo County, Mario Ramirez, J., entered judgment awarding school district $12,950 against contractor and surety, but denied any recovery against president, chief executive officer and major shareholder, and appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Utter, J., held that: (1) representations by contractor that it was going to repair paint problems in school gymnasium did not serve to toll statute of limitations regarding surety whose duty under bond was discharged upon completion of contract; (2) contractor failed to state burden of establishing that liquidated damages clause was in fact penalty; and (3) no basis existed for piercing corporate veil. Reversed and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Campisano v. Nardi
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Mere breach of a corporate contract cannot establish the basis for application of instrumentality rule, under which corporate officer or director may be held personally liable for corporate debts, absent claim that corporation was formed for improper purpose or that persons seeking imposition of personal liability were improperly induced to enter contract with corporation.
Document Preview: Homeowners brought action seeking to hold sole shareholder officer and director of dissolved corporate contractor liable for breach of contract entered into by corporation prior to dissolution.  The Stamford-Norwalk Superior Court, Cioffi, J., granted defendant's motion for judgment in accordance with report of Dennis G. Eveleigh, referee, recommending judgment for defendant and Lewis, J., rendered judgment in accordance with referee's report.  Plaintiffs appealed.  The Supreme Court, Peters, C.J., held that: (1) plaintiffs failed to prove that officer had committed fraud, and (2) sole shareholder, officer and director of corporation dissolved by forfeiture could not be held personally liable for breach of contract entered into by corporation prior to its dissolution. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: David v. Glemby Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Jury could reasonably pierce corporate veil of subsidiary which entered into market development agreement and hold parent corporation liable; while subsidiary observed many formalities of corporate form, it ignored others and two companies had essentially the same officers who often acted on behalf of both companies simultaneously.
Document Preview: Hair stylist sued subsidiary and parent corporation for breach of marketing development agreement between hair stylist and subsidiary.  On corporations' motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Walker, J., held that: (1) jury could find that corporate veil of subsidiary should be pierced precluding summary judgment, and (2) hair stylist could not recover claimed loss of future profits resulting from breach. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Not every breach of contract nor every tort is injustice warranting holding parent corporation liable under alter ego theory for acts of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lowell Staats Min. Co., Inc. v. Pioneer Uravan, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Possibility that mining contractor might have difficulty enforcing breach of contract judgment against mining property owner was not the type of injustice that warranted piercing the corporate veil to hold sole shareholder of property owner liable under Colorado law.
Document Preview: Independent mining contractor brought breach of contract action against corporate owner of mining property.  Property owner brought action against contractor to recover overpayments for ore deliveries under contract and contractor brought third-party claim against sole shareholder of property owner and against shareholder's subsidiary.  Actions were consolidated and removed to federal court.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, John L. Kane, Jr., J., granted directed verdict motions of sole shareholder and subsidiary on claims in third-party complaint, jury returned verdict against property owner on counterclaim and on breach of contract claim awarded damages.  The District Court, 645 F.Supp. 254, denied contractor's motion for prejudgment interest.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Brorby, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil of mining property owner could not be pierced to render sole...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fen Hin Chon Enterprises, Ltd. v. Porelon, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent fraud, misrepresentation, or tortious conduct, Tennessee corporate law did not permit piercing corporate veil of buyer of licensee's business so as to reduce licensee's damages in breach of contract action against licensor.
Document Preview: Licensee brought action against licensor for breach of contract.  The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, L. Clure Morton, J., 667 F.Supp. 1174, entered judgment for licensee, and licensor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, David A. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) lost profits could not have been calculated on basis of profit rate for both business in question and unrelated business also operated by licensee, and (2) projected marginal cost approach rather than fully allocated historic cost approach should have been employed in estimating lost profits. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Blakeslee
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: Insurer, who was concededly not liable to insured dentist under general liability policy after dentist sexually assaulted patient, was not liable to professional corporation wholly owned by dentist which was a separate insured under policy, as corporation was simply "alter ego" of dentist.
Document Preview: Insurer brought declaratory judgment action against its insured, a dentist, and patient that dentist had allegedly sexually assaulted during treatment, for determination that general liability and professional insurance policy did not cover incident.  The Superior Court, Clark County, Robert L. Harris, J., granted summary judgment to insurer, and insured and patient appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Alexander, C.J., held that: (1) general liability policy, which concededly did not apply to dentist, also did not apply to his professional corporation, a separate insured, as corporation was alter ego of dentist, and (2) professional liability policy did not apply, as sexual assault was not part of dental treatment. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hennings v. State Farm Fire and Cas. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
