Headnote: Corporation could not be considered stockholder's "alter ego," and thus trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to invoke reverse piercing of corporate veil theory to allow finding that stockholder owned corporation's boat, which would have made stockholder's homeowner's policy exclusion for watercraft owned by insured applicable to boat collision in which stockholder was driving corporate boat, where stockholder only owned 50% of corporation's stock at time of boat accident.
Document Preview: Party injured in boat collision, who had previously entered into settlement agreement with driver of other boat, brought action against boat driver's homeowner's insurer to recover on settlement.  The District Court, Hennepin County, Myron S. Greenberg, J., entered partial summary judgment in favor of injured party finding that homeowner's policy covered collision, entered judgment against insurer based on difference between jury's finding of reasonable settlement amount and primary policy's limit of coverage, denied injured party's motion for judgment notwithstanding verdict, and denied injured party's request for preverdict interest.  Insurer appealed, and injured party also sought review.  The Court of Appeals, Parker, J., held that: (1) homeowner's policy's watercraft and business pursuit exceptions were inapplicable; (2) trial court properly submitted issue of reasonableness of settlement to jury; (3) insurer had right to separate...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gray v. Edgewater Landing, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Breach of contract, without showing of fraud, does not justify disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Tenant corporation brought action against landlord, asserting conversion. Landlord filed counterclaim charging breach of lease agreement and joining shareholders individually as third-party defendants.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, R.L. Goza, J., directed verdict exonerating shareholders and jury found for landlord.  Landlord appealed discharge of shareholders.  The Supreme Court, Robertson, J., held that shareholders were not liable for corporation's breach of lease. Affirmed. Dan M. Lee, P.J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gray v. Edgewater Landing, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Corporation's negligent performance of contractual duties does not justify disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Tenant corporation brought action against landlord, asserting conversion. Landlord filed counterclaim charging breach of lease agreement and joining shareholders individually as third-party defendants.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, R.L. Goza, J., directed verdict exonerating shareholders and jury found for landlord.  Landlord appealed discharge of shareholders.  The Supreme Court, Robertson, J., held that shareholders were not liable for corporation's breach of lease. Affirmed. Dan M. Lee, P.J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gray v. Edgewater Landing, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: To cause court to disregard corporate entity and justify shareholder liability, complaining party must demonstrate some frustration of contractual expectations regarding party to whom he looked for performance, flagrant disregard of corporate formalities by defendant corporation and its principals, and demonstration of fraud or other equivalent misfeasance on part of corporate shareholder; to present jury issue, party must present some credible evidence on each point.
Document Preview: Tenant corporation brought action against landlord, asserting conversion. Landlord filed counterclaim charging breach of lease agreement and joining shareholders individually as third-party defendants.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, R.L. Goza, J., directed verdict exonerating shareholders and jury found for landlord.  Landlord appealed discharge of shareholders.  The Supreme Court, Robertson, J., held that shareholders were not liable for corporation's breach of lease. Affirmed. Dan M. Lee, P.J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: I. Kaszirer Diamonds, Ltd. v. Zohar Creations, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Failure of diamond seller's agreement with company to indicate that company was a corporation did not warrant disregarding of its corporate existence, in seller's subsequent suit against corporation's shareholder for breach of agreement, absent showing that seller was unaware of company's corporate existence or that, in dealing with shareholder, it did not know that it was also dealing with corporation.
Document Preview: Diamond seller brought action against corporation and its shareholder for breach of agreement to return diamonds. The Supreme Court, New York County, Santaella, J., entered summary judgment against both defendants, and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that absent proof of contrary intention, corporate shareholder who signed agreement in his own name without indicating that he did so as corporation's agent, would not be held personally liable for breach of agreement. Judgment as to shareholder vacated, and otherwise affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Carterhouse, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Evidence established that activities of second corporation which related to its representation of competitor of principal were attributable to corporate debtor, which had signed agency agreement with principal containing noncompetition agreement, and thus, conduct of second corporation was attributable to debtor under Connecticut corporate veil analysis and debtor violated noncompetition clause; president and sole shareholder of debtor was also president and sole shareholder of second corporation, corporate formalities were not observed between debtor and second corporation, and no books or records were offered to demonstrate that debtor and second corporation, which shared same office, were treated as separate corporations.
Document Preview: Principal in agency agreement with Chapter 11 debtor objected to confirmation of plan.  The Bankruptcy Court, Alan H.W. Shiff, J., held that: (1) noncompetition clause in agency agreement prohibited Chapter 11 debtor's president, as well as debtor, from competing with principal, and clause was violated under Delaware law by president's formation of second corporation, of which corporation was sole shareholder, to act as agent for principal's competitor, and (2) debtor's plan, which did not provide for cure of debtor's breach of noncompetition in agency agreement, prevented debtor from assuming agency agreement, and thus, plan, which was to be funded primarily by continuance of debtor's contractual relationship under agency agreement, could not be confirmed. Objection sustained.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cancun Adventure Tours, Inc. v. Underwater Designer Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Buyer of modified air compressor satisfied its burden of showing that corporate fiction should be disregarded, so that sole shareholder of seller, as well as seller, would be liable to seller in action arising from defects in air compressor, where buyer produced substantial evidence that seller regularly comingled corporate and personal assets and regularly diverted corporate funds and assets for his personal use; sole shareholder treated his corporate and personal affairs as if they were indistinguishable and, thus, could not complain when buyer, who was injured by seller's misrepresentations, sought to do same.
Document Preview: Buyer brought action against corporate seller and sole shareholder, alleging breach of contract, breach of warranty, and fraud in sale of modified air compressor.  The United States District Court, Eastern District of Virginia, Leonie M. Brinkema, United States Magistrate, awarded compensatory and punitive damages to buyer, but declined to award buyer damages for lost profits, and appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Wilkinson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) personal jurisdiction could be exercised over seller and shareholder; (2) buyer gave adequate notice of alleged contractual breach; (3) liability could be imposed on shareholder in his individual capacity; (4) punitive damages cannot be awarded; and (5) buyer was not entitled to lost profits damages. Affirmed in part; reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. Construction and General Laborers Union No. 1140, Laborers Intern. Union of North America, AFL-CIO
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Sole proprietorship which was formed to perform concrete-pouring contracts by sole shareholder in corporation which had ceased business two years earlier because of economic difficulties was not alter ego of corporation.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board sought enforcement of order finding union in violation of National Labor Relations Act by causing employer to discharge nonunion laborer.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) sole proprietorship was not alter ego of corporation which had agreed to hire all laborers through union hiring hall, and (2) union's interference with proprietorship by causing proprietorship to fire nonunion laborer violated National Labor Relations Act. Order enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Morowitz v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Newly formed corporation generally will not be liable on promoter contracts in the absence of statute or charter provision or corporate act of adoption or ratification or novation, nor can it be considered as a party to contract and be bound thereby in disregard of distinction of corporate entity from persons of the members.
Document Preview: Taxpayers brought tax refund suit.  The Claims Court, Reginald W. Gibson, J., held that taxpayers failed to rebut presumption of correctness that attached to Commissioner of Internal Revenue's determination that payment from corporation was a constructive dividend. Judgment for Commissioner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hennessey's Tavern, Inc. v. American Air Filter Co.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Claim against defendant, based on alter ego theory, is not itself claim for substantive relief, such as breach of contract or to set aside fraudulent conveyance, but rather, it is procedural, to disregard corporate entity as distinct defendant and to hold alter ego individuals liable on obligations of corporation where corporation form is being used by individuals to escape personal liability, sanction fraud, or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, which had originally commenced breach of contract and misrepresentation and fraud action, appealed from judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Robert H. O'Brien, J., granting motion to dismiss action against added defendants based on plaintiff's failure to serve added defendants with summons and complaint within three years of original complaint.  The Court of Appeal, Danielson, J., held that: (1) service on newly named defendants within one month of amended complaint, wherein it was alleged that newly named defendants were alter egos of defendants named in original complaint, was timely, and (2) cause of action for fraudulent conveyance added by amended complaint was entirely new cause of action based on operative facts different from those underlying original complaint alleging breach of contract and misrepresentation and fraud, and thus, three-year limitation period for service of summons and complaint did not begin to run until amended...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Nunn v. Chemical Waste Management, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, parent corporation which acquired subsidiary corporation operating waste disposal facility could not recover lost profit damages arising from operation of facility from former owners of corporation; although contractual warranties contained in acquisition agreement were made by former owners to parent corporation, acquired subsidiary was entity which lost profits after it was discovered that waste from facility had leaked into ground waters, and separate entity status of parent and its subsidiary could not be disregarded.
Document Preview: Former owners of corporation operating industrial waste disposal facility brought suit against buyers for breach of contractual duty of payment for corporation's stock.  Buyers counterclaimed for, inter alia, breach of warranty.  Following bench trial, the United States District Court for the District of Kansas, Patrick F. Kelly, J., entered judgment in favor of buyers on counterclaim for breach of warranty.  Both sides appealed, and matter was returned after remand.  The Court of Appeals, Seth, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) warranties in acquisition agreement included warranty that facility was in compliance with all laws and warranty against leakage; (2) acquiring buyer was entitled to recover remediation costs, but not lost profits, which were properly attributable to its acquired subsidiary corporation; and (3) buyer was not discharged from their contractual duties of payment under purchase agreement. Affirmed in part, reversed...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Transportes Aereos de Angola v. Ronair, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, corporate director's sole responsibility for disposition of fund arising out of sale of aircraft did not, without more, provide sufficient evidence of abuse of corporate form for purposes of piercing corporate veil and holding director personally liable for breach of sale contract.
Document Preview: State-owned corporation of the People's Republic of Angola filed suit for breach of a contract to buy an aircraft.  Corporation moved for partial summary judgment on its claim for breach of contract and conversion, as well as on defense and counterclaims raised by the seller.  The District Court, Longobardi, J., held that: (1) the sellers could not claim that the purchase agreement was modified by a subsequent agreement for the substitute aircraft where the sellers had been deemed to admit that no modification occurred, as a sanction for failure to answer interrogatories; (2) no novation could have occurred without an agreement that would extinguish the obligations under the original contract; (3) even if there had been a bona fide dispute about substitution, no accord and satisfaction could have occurred without the parties' reaching a new agreement, completion of which would satisfy obligations under the original contract;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Maritime Ventures Intern., Inc. v. Caribbean Trading & Fidelity, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In contrast to an agent for a disclosed principal, who has no primary liability on the principal's contract, person who has so dominated a corporation as to become a corporate alter ego can be held liable on the corporation's contracts.
Document Preview: Vessel owner brought suit against charterer corporation and other defendants for demurrage charges which allegedly accrued under charter party; owner also asserted claim for fraud.  On motions to dismiss, the District Court, William C. Conner, J., held that: (1) evidence showed existence of binding charter party; (2) owner's allegations provided basis for exercise of subject-matter jurisdiction over claims against charter corporation's president; (3) arbitration agreement acted as waiver of immunity for purposes of subject-matter jurisdiction against country of St. Kitts-Nevis; (4) questions of fact precluded summary judgment on claims against charterer's officials, and country of St. Kitts-Nevis; and (5) owner was entitled to amend complaint to add joint venture claim. Motions to dismiss and motions for sanction denied except that motion to dismiss cause of action for fraud granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Georgia American Ins. Co. v. Mills
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In suit by injured passenger to recover no-fault benefits, insurer, which had not issued policy on vehicle involved in accident, was improperly denied summary judgment notwithstanding that it and issuing insurer were subsidiaries of same parent company and that its claims examiner had undertaken investigation of passenger's claim.
Document Preview: Injured passenger brought suit against insurers to recover no-fault benefits and statutory bad faith penalty, attorneys fees and punitive damages for failure to pay claim in timely manner.  Passenger amended complaint to designate one insurer as sole defendant.  Following jury trial before the Superior Court, Clinch County, Knight, J., judgment was entered in passenger's favor.  Original appeal, 359 S.E.2d 697, was dismissed on ground that case was technically still pending against second insurer in trial court.  Second insurer moved for summary judgment.  The Superior Court denied summary judgment and issued order directing entry of final, appealable judgment against first insurer.  Both insurers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Banke, P.J., held that: (1) endorsement providing that coverage was not afforded while vehicle was being driven by named insured's wife was unenforceable; (2) insurer could not defend bad-faith...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Parent may be held liable for contractual obligations of its subsidiary under alter ego doctrine theory, where subsidiary is mere business conduit for parent or where there is such unity of interest and ownership that individuality or separateness of corporations has ceased; but it also requires showing that recognition of separate corporate existence of corporations would sanction fraud or other improper purposes.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Ownership by one corporation of all or majority of stock of another, or fact that corporations have common officers and directors, or both, is not sufficient by itself to render parent corporation liable on its subsidiary's contract; each additional bit of evidence, however, that tends to show too close or too direct relationship between corporations, disregard by one corporation of normal corporate process or formalities in regard to other, undercapitalization of subsidiaries, commingling of funds or holding out by one that other is department of its business or that it stands behind it favors finding of parental liability.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: American Protein Corp. v. AB Volvo
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, existence of interlocking directorates was insufficient to pierce corporate veil between original contracting party and its great-grandparent, with respect to claim of breach of express written contract, where separate corporate and financial records were maintained, independent board meetings were held and separate corporate offices were maintained, and there was no evidence to suggest that great-grandparent used subsidiary to commit fraud or wrong causing plaintiff to suffer unjust loss.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, an American corporation, brought suit arising out of contract with American subsidiary of Swedish parent corporation.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Howard B. Turrentine, J., awarded plaintiff $3 million in damages in varying amounts against defendants for breach of contract, tortious interference of contract and negligent misrepresentation, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cardamone, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) existence of interlocking directorates was insufficient to pierce corporate veil between original contracting party and its great-grandparent; (2) evidence was insufficient to establish that president of original contracting party made any guaranty of original contracting party's performance; (3) decision of corporate executives to wind down affairs of subsidiary did not constitute tortious interference with plaintiff's contract with subsidiary; and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Loeffler v. McShane
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate officer who is also shareholder may, in appropriate circumstances, be held individually liable for corporate contracts under equitable doctrine of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Mortgagees sued to foreclose on mortgage.  Mortgagors sought to recover from abstract company and abstract company's principal corporate officer for their alleged improper disbursal of funds in connection with mortgage refinancing.  The Court of Common Pleas, Bucks County, Civil, No. 83-04038, Kelton, J., held that mortgagors were liable to mortgagee for unpaid balance on mortgage note and other defendants were liable to mortgagors for alleged improper disbursal of funds.  Appeal was taken.  The Superior Court, No. 01581 Philadelphia 1987, Beck, J., held that principal officer of company which supervised mortgage refinancing, who authorized disbursal of funds to improper party, was personally liable to mortgagors for damage caused by active misfeasance and negligence. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lezzer Cash & Carry, Inc. v. Aetna Ins. Co.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Subcontractor was not alter ego of contractor, so as to warrant piercing corporate veil in order to alter terms of payment bond pursuant to which surety agreed to protect designated subcontractors and materialmen, even though contractor and subcontractor shared same office and telephone; there was no evidence of common ownership or interlocking boards of directors or of fraud, illegality, or wrongdoing, and, furthermore, contractor and subcontractor were innocent parties as to materialman seeking payment under bond. Miller Act, § 2(a), 40 U.S.C.A. § 270b(a).
Document Preview: Materialman brought action against surety to recover cost of materials supplied for housing construction project.  The Court of Common Pleas, Civil Division, Delaware County, No. 8410833, Semeraro, J., entered judgment for supplier in amount of $51,834.09 plus interest, and surety appealed.  The Superior Court, No. 867 Philadelphia, 1987, Wieand, J., held that: (1) materialman selling materials to subcontractor, which in turn had contracted with first-tier subcontractor to furnish and deliver materials to job site, was not claimant protected by payment bond; (2) first-tier subcontractor was not alter ego of contractor so as to mandate piercing corporate veil; and (3) materialman's telephone calls to contractor and surety did not satisfy written notice requirements of payment bond. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bonanni v. Straight Arrow Publishers, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate officer, who was not party to corporation's contract, could be held personally liable for contract's breach, if, disregarding corporate form, he exercised such dominion and control over corporation's operations that corporation became his alter ego, vehicle for purely personal rather than corporate ends.
Document Preview: Former employee, bringing breach of contract action against corporation officer, moved to amend complaint against corporate officer.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Baer, J., granted motion for leave to amend complaint, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that affidavit of former employee's counsel was insufficient to support motion for leave to amend. Order reversed and complaint dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: BLH Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Parent corporations of dissolved subsidiary did not so completely dominate subsidiary that court would be justified in piercing corporate veil and holding parents liable on contracts of subsidiary; even after corporation was dissolved, it continued to perform remaining responsibilities under contract with Government and repeatedly negotiated and executed agreements in its own name, though after liquidation, subsidiary had no assets and became financially dependent upon parent.
Document Preview: Government sought to enforce contracting officer's decision that parent corporations of dissolved subsidiary which had contract with Government were liable for damages which arose from problem with pump-turbine system.  On motions for summary judgment, the Claims Court, Smith, Chief Judge, held that: relitigation of issue of whether subsidiary had capacity to sue or be sued was precluded by doctrine of res judicata; (1) parent corporations were not contractors as contemplated by the Contracts Dispute Act; (2) parents were not corporate alter egos of subsidiary; and (3) there was no implied-in-law contract between parents and Government. Parent corporations' cross-motions for summary judgment granted; Government's motion for partial summary judgment on counterclaims denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Chicago Florsheim Shoe Store Co. v. Cluett, Peabody & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Shoe manufacturer, whose concession agreement with retailer was breached, was unable to enforce agreement against corporation which had acquired now insolvent retailer, on basis that corporation exercised degree of control over retailer as to render it mere instrumentality and therefore alter ego of corporation; corporation sold its interest in retailer more than one year before concession agreement was breached, and manufacturer proffered nothing more than conjecture, speculating that if sale of retailer constituted stripping of its assets in manner of fraudulent conveyance, liability should be visited upon corporation for retailer's default on agreement.
Document Preview: Shoe manufacturer brought action against corporation which acquired retailer, which breached thereafter longstanding concession agreement with manufacturer. The United States District Court for the Central District of Illinois, Richard Mills, J., granted corporation's motion for summary judgment, and manufacturer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Bauer, Chief Judge, held that: (1) manufacturer was able to engage in adequate discovery prior to trial court's ruling on motion; (2) party seeking to set aside corporate identity of one identity as alter ego of another must bear burden of establishing that corporation was so controlled and manipulated that it had become mere instrumentality of another, and furthermore, that misuse of corporate form would sanction fraud or promote injustice; and (3) manufacturer failed to establish that corporation exercised degree of control over retailer as to render it mere instrumentality and therefore alter ego of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U.S. v. Van Diviner
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate president was not personally liable for corporation's breach of contract with United States to provide janitorial services at air force base on theory that corporate form should be disregarded, even though president did not always scrupulously maintain distinction between himself and corporation, where there was no evidence that he commingled corporation's funds with his own, distributed to himself corporate assets, misled Government or anyone, or otherwise misused or abused corporate form in any way that would threaten injustice to Government.
Document Preview: United States brought action against corporation and its officers for breach of contract to provide janitorial services at air force base.  The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, Ewing T. Kerr, J., found defendants liable, and corporate president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Logan, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) president was not personally liable for damages arising from breach due to fact that he signed contract, where United States believed that it was dealing with properly functioning corporate entity; (2) corporate president was not personally liable for damages arising from breach under theory of piercing corporate veil, where there was no evidence that president commingled corporation's funds with his own or otherwise misused or abused corporate form in way that would threaten injustice to Government; and (3) president was not liable under trust fund doctrine. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Continental U.K. Ltd. v. Anagel Confidence Compania Naviera, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiaries of same parent are not necessarily bound to each others' contractual obligations.
Document Preview: Cargo owner filed petition to compel arbitration in New York City of its claim against vessel owner for sea water damage to cargo. The District Court, Tenney, J., held that: (1) bill of lading clearly incorporated subcharter arbitration clause, and (2) cargo owner was not charterer within meaning of arbitration clause and, thus, could not compel arbitration pursuant thereto. Petition denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re F & S Cent. Mfg. Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary was "alter ego" or "instrumentality" of parent company that owned it, so that parent company was liable on subsidiary's contracts, where subsidiary never conducted business under its own name, never had any assets or obligations of its own, and had no officers who were able to make and implement decisions on their own without direct orders from parent company.
Document Preview: Trustee brought adversary action against subsidiary and parent corporation for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract to purchase debtor's assets.  The Bankruptcy Court, C. Albert Parente, J., held that: (1) subsidiary was alter ego or instrumentality of parent company, so that parent was liable on subsidiary's contract; (2) initial purchase offer signed by subsidiary's agent, letter from debtor's attorney indicating that parties had agreed to purchase price, and in-court statements by attorney for subsidiary asking bankruptcy court to set date three days subsequent as closing date established existence of enforceable contract and satisfied New York statute of frauds; but (3) trustee was not entitled to recover attorney fees for entire period of negotiation and sale, but only those fees that related exclusively to defendants' breach of contract. So ordered. See also, Bkrtcy., 53 B.R. 842.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Klukavy v. United Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, principals of purchasing corporation had no cause of action as owners with respect to insurance proceeds payable as result of destruction by fire of bar/restaurant, despite their claim that corporation was their alter-ego.
Document Preview: In interpleader action involving entitlement to insurance proceeds, one claimant moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Anna Diggs Taylor, J., held that: (1) principals of corporate purchaser had no cause of action, either as owners or under management agreement, with respect to insurance proceeds, and (2) management agreement was illegal and void in its entirety. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Baker v. Kulczyk
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: Fact that contracting party was persuaded to enter into contract with corporation rather than with individual personally did not establish that inequitable result would follow if corporate status were not disregarded and liability imposed jointly and severally on corporation, individual who was president and majority stockholder of two corporations, and another corporation, where contracting party did not allege or testify he was induced by fraud or misrepresentation to contract with corporation rather than with individual. I.C. § 30-1-25.
Document Preview: Action was brought against two corporations and individual who was president and majority stockholder of the two corporations, seeking to collect amounts due under two contracts and seeking imposition of joint and several liability on theory that corporations were alter egos of individual.  Defendants counterclaimed.  The First Judicial District, Boundary County, Watt E. Prather, J., awarded plaintiff unpaid balance due and denied counterclaims, and held corporations and individual defendant jointly and severally liable for judgments, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Swanstrom, J., held that: (1) allegations that defendant corporations might not have sufficient worth to satisfy judgment and that individual would do everything possible to avoid payment did not justify disregard of corporate status in imposing liability to remove individual's ability to transfer assets from one corporation to another; (2) fact that plaintiff was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Baker v. Kulczyk
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: Although disregard of corporate status in holding two corporations and individual who was president and majority stockholder of both corporations jointly and severally liable for contracts, which were each entered into by only one corporation, could not be sustained, corporations were nonetheless liable for portions of judgments based on contracts which they had entered into.
Document Preview: Action was brought against two corporations and individual who was president and majority stockholder of the two corporations, seeking to collect amounts due under two contracts and seeking imposition of joint and several liability on theory that corporations were alter egos of individual.  Defendants counterclaimed.  The First Judicial District, Boundary County, Watt E. Prather, J., awarded plaintiff unpaid balance due and denied counterclaims, and held corporations and individual defendant jointly and severally liable for judgments, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Swanstrom, J., held that: (1) allegations that defendant corporations might not have sufficient worth to satisfy judgment and that individual would do everything possible to avoid payment did not justify disregard of corporate status in imposing liability to remove individual's ability to transfer assets from one corporation to another; (2) fact that plaintiff was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Puma Indus. Consulting, Inc. v. Daal Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Officers and shareholders of corporation were not individually liable for commissions owed under procurement contract arising from assistance provided in procuring government contract for corporation, in that they did not act outside their capacities as officers in connection with procurement contract and there was no basis for piercing corporate veil. Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949, § 304(a), 41 U.S.C.A. § 254(a).
Document Preview: On appeal from a judgment entered in the Southern District of New York, Shirley Wohl Kram, District Judge, awarding $82,418.13 damages to appellee on its claim against appellants for commissions due under a written agreement, the Court of Appeals, Timbers, Circuit Judge, held: (1) that procurement contract did not violate federal law and was not against public policy, and (2) that shareholders and officers of corporate contractor should not have been held jointly and severally liable. As modified, affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Laya v. Erin Homes, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: In breach of contract case, to pierce corporate veil in order to hold shareholders actively participating in operation of business personally liable, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and of individual shareholders no longer exist and inequitable result would occur if acts are treated as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: Buyers of mobile home sued mobile home business and owner operator of business for breach of contract.  The Circuit Court, Ohio County, Wilson, J., granted owner operator's motion for summary judgment, and buyers appealed.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, McHugh, J., held that whether owner operator had inadequately capitalized corporation and whether there was disregard of corporate formalities presented issues precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Clee v. Remillard Bldg., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, corporation president's conduct with respect to entering and performing contract to build plaintiffs' house was such that corporate entity would be disregarded and individual liability imposed on president under instrumentality rule, where president completely dominated all aspects of corporation to point where it had no separate existence other than corporate name, where president's control of corporation with respect to all aspects of contract to build plaintiffs' house were used by him to commit dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiffs' legal rights and where president's control of construction contract and breach of duties assumed thereunder proximately caused damages plaintiffs suffered.
Document Preview: Action brought seeking damages for breach of contract to construct home.  The District Court, Nevas, J., held that conduct of construction company's principle with respect to entering and performing contract to build plaintiffs' home was such that corporate entity would be disregarded and individual liability imposed on president of company. Default judgment in favor of plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil, or disregarding the corporate entity, is appropriate where individual or corporation has overextended his or its use or a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, to perpetuate fraud, or to evade contractual or tort liability.
Document Preview: In interpleader action, the United States, former wife of debtor, and others claimed surplus cash proceeds from foreclosure sale of property on which second mortgage had been transferred to trust to secure alimony. The District Court, Harold L. Murphy, J., held that record established that transfer to trust of mortgage, and other transactions, were fraudulent conveyances and that neither trustee nor the wife, as contingent beneficiary of the trust, were subsequent purchasers entitled to the protections of the Georgia innocent purchaser statute. Transaction set aside and claims of former wife denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Husky Oil N.P.R. Operations, Inc. v. Sea Airmotive, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Corporation, which was owned almost exclusively by president of air transportation company, which ostensibly sold fuel to customer that was required by contract to reimburse airline for "actual cost" of some fuel, which did not receive the 50 cents per gallon supposedly charged by company, which did not handle any fuel that was passed directly from wholesaler to company, and which was not subsidiary of company, was alter ego of company in fuel purchase transactions and, therefore, was not seller of fuel for purpose of contract provision requiring customer to reimburse company for "actual cost" which was, instead, cost that company paid to wholesaler.
Document Preview: Air transportation company brought action against customer for customer's failure to pay charges for fuel and augmented crew allegedly required by contracts, and customer counterclaimed for fuel overcharges.  The Superior Court, Third Judicial District, Anchorage, Mark C. Rowland, J., denied customer's motion for summary judgment, issued judgment against customer, and denied customer's motions for judgment notwithstanding verdict or new trial. Customer appealed.  The Supreme Court, Compton, J., held that: (1) corporation, which was owned almost exclusively by president of airline and which did not handle any fuel that was passed directly from wholesaler to airline, was alter ego of airline in fuel purchase transactions and, therefore, was not seller of fuel for purpose of contract provision requiring customer to reimburse airline for actual cost which was, instead, cost that airline paid to wholesaler, and (2) air transportation company which...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Om-El Export Co., Inc. v. Newcor, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Corporate entity could be disregarded to permit award of damages for lost future commissions, without deduction for salary expenses of exporting company's sole shareholder, in exporting company's action to recover from heavy industrial machinery manufacturer for manufacturer's breach of contract to export manufacturer's products, where contract clearly contemplated personal services of sole shareholder and where sole shareholder was company's only real asset.
Document Preview: Exporting company brought breach of contract action against heavy industrial machinery manufacturer, who terminated contract early.  The Bay Circuit Court, Eugene C. Penzien, J., found that manufacturer breached its contractual duties and awarded damages to exporting company.  Manufacturer appealed damage award for future commissions and computation of interest on award.  The Court of Appeals, Kelly, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in finding that it was unreasonable to require exporting company to mitigate damages by developing new foreign markets for other companies; (2) trial court did not err when it failed to deduct from future commissions damages award salary that exporting company's sole shareholder would have been paid during years remaining on contract after termination; (3) prejudgment interest statute allowed interest on future commissions award from date of filing of the complaint; and (4) future commissions...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Specialized Tours, Inc. v. Hagen
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Even if warranty in sale agreement contemplated implied warranties that corporation had complied with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations of city, county, state and federal governments trial court could pierce corporate veil and impose liability for breach of warranty on seller of corporation only upon a finding that seller and corporation were one and the same and absent such findings "piercing the corporate veil" was unwarranted.
Document Preview: Purchaser of corporation brought action against seller of corporation claiming breach of contract/warranty, fraud and violation of State Securities Act and seller counterclaimed for unpaid contract balance.  The District Court, Rice County, found seller breached various contract warranties, committed actual fraud and violated State Securities Act and that purchaser converted seller's security interest and breached various contract agreements and both parties appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kelley, J., held that: (1) seller of corporation was under no legal obligation to follow generally accepted accounting principles in preparing corporation's financial statement; (2) seller of corporation breached contract by failing to disclose prepayments due within three months of sale of corporation; and (3) State Securities Act was applicable to sale of corporate business when purchaser acquired 100% of stock. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Orthopedic & Reconstructive Surgery, S.C. v. Kezelis
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Even if hospital subsidiary was agent for physicians' corporation, that was insufficient to establish identity of interest between physicians' corporation and hospital so as to permit corporations to recover from patient on basis of her contract with hospital.
Document Preview: Physicians brought contract action against patient.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Fred W. Reither, J., granted physicians motion for summary judgment and patient appealed.  The Appellate Court, Quinlan, P.J., held that: (1) record did not establish contractual relation between physicians and patient. Reversed, vacated and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kincaid v. Landing Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Corporation which was sales and marketing agent for development was not distinguishable from developer or contractor for purposes of homeowners' action against developer, sales and marketing agent and contractor alleging negligence and breach of warranty, where all three corporations had same shareholders, same vice president and same additional officer, all three corporate offices were located at same place, homeowner testified that she called marketing agent concerning problems with house and someone then came to house to correct problem and letters sent to homeowners indicated marketing agent was project developer and would handle all construction questions and that marketing agent was development, construction, sales, and property management company.
Document Preview: Homeowners brought action against developer, sales and marketing agent and contractor, alleging negligence and breach of warranty.  The Common Pleas Court, Horry County, Ralph King Anderson, Jr., J., entered judgment upon jury verdict awarding homeowners $19,800 actual damages and $13,500 punitive damages, and developer, sales and marketing agent and contractor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Shaw, J., held that: (1) erroneous instruction that violation of alleged building code was negligence per se was not reversible error; (2) allowing jury to view house prior to testimony by structural engineer was not abuse of trial court's discretion; and (3) allowing homeowners to amend claim during trial to increase damages request was not abuse of discretion. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kashi v. Gratsos
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Court would pierce corporate veil and hold individual corporate principals liable for damages resulting from contract breached by corporation where principals were fully involved and used corporation to perpetrate fraudulent scheme and paid no regard to usual formalities attending corporate form.
Document Preview: Purchaser brought breach of contract and fraud action against seller and seller's principals.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Abraham D. Sofaer, J., entered judgment in favor of purchaser and appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Winter, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) individual defendants participated in conspiracy and were jointly and severally liable for all damages suffered by plaintiffs; (2) purchaser was not required to attempt to cover in order to recover damages based on market price fluctuation; (3) corporate veil should be pierced to hold individuals liable for contract losses; (4) court did not abuse its discretion in declining to enforce settlement agreement; and (5) it was not a denial of due process to deny request for delay of trial until after statute of limitations had run against one of the defendants. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Irving R. Kaufman,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stansell v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: There was no basis for piercing corporate veil so as to extend coverage under commercial automobile policy issued to corporation to include liability of corporate president in his individual capacity, even though president was majority shareholder of corporation, where president was not sole owner, president denied any breach of corporate form, and president denied any personal use of business vehicles.
Document Preview: Personal injury action was brought against president of corporation, arising out of accident wherein passenger, while attempting to close sliding door, fell out of corporation's van, which president had loaned to his brother.  Insurer moved for declaratory judgment that commercial automobile policy issued to corporation did not provide coverage for individual liability of president.  The Floyd Superior Court, Royal, J., entered summary judgment for insurer, and passenger and president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held that: (1) commercial automobile policy did not provide coverage for individual liability of president, and (2) there was no basis for piercing corporate veil. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tesoro Petroleum Corp. v. Holborn Oil Co., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Foreign subsidiary's treatment by parent corporation as department rather than as independent subsidiary, and fact that parent employee handled negotiations for alleged contract for gasoline of which subsidiary was to take delivery, provided sufficient basis for concluding that corporate veil between parent and subsidiary should be pierced for purposes of litigation on alleged contract.
Document Preview: Oil company brought action on alleged contract with foreign subsidiary of another corporation to sell approximately 25,000 metric tons of gasoline.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Pecora, J., entered order which, among other things, granted foreign subsidiary's cross motion to dismiss action for lack of personal jurisdiction and denied oil company's summary judgment motion to dismiss affirmative defenses of lack of personal jurisdiction and forum non conveniens.  On appeal, the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) there was sufficient basis for piercing corporate veil between parent and subsidiary corporations for purposes of litigation; (2) trial court had personal jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary by virtue of parent's presence in state; and (3) doctrine of forum non conveniens did not require dismissal of action as to foreign subsidiary. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cooperstein v. Patrician Estates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil and imposition of liability on contractor was warranted where contractor and construction company functioned as one entity and company failed to maintain any indicia of separate corporate identity.
Document Preview: Purchasers of house brought action for specific performance of contract for construction of house and sale of property upon which it was located, and for damages for breach of contract.  The Supreme Court, Suffolk County, Scileppi, J., Retired, found for plaintiffs.  Defendants appealed, and plaintiffs cross appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) sufficient evidence supported finding of breach of contract; (2) piercing of corporate veil and imposition of liability on individual defendant was warranted; and (3) award of damages in addition to specific performance was proper. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Otto v. Weber
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: In absence of finding of fraud, vendor corporation's president, which signed sales agreement whereby, inter alia, vendor agreed not to compete within 100-mile radius, could not be bound personally to the covenant not to compete on a "corporate pierce" theory.
Document Preview: President of purchaser corporation brought suit alleging that contract between vendor and purchaser corporations personally bound president of former, as signer, to contract's covenant not to compete provision.  The District Court, Wright County, Kim Johnson, J., entered judgment in favor of purchaser, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Lansing, J., held that: (1) where contract did not so provide, provision could not personally bind president on either piercing the corporate veil theory or contract interpretation theory; (2) trial court made insufficient findings to support reformation of contract; and (3) even if such findings had been made, the evidence did not support them. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Weeks v. Kerr
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Fourth District.
Headnote: Generally, directors and officers of corporation are not individually liable for debts and contracts of corporation except where director or officer has personally guaranteed corporation's obligation so as to assume liability as guarantor and where director or officer has demonstrated disregard of corporate form, treating corporation essentially as conduit for personal business affairs.
Document Preview: Action was brought for commissions due under employment contract.  The Marion County Superior Court, Kenneth H. Johnson, J., granted judgment against corporate officer individually for unpaid commissions plus costs, and officer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Young, P.J., held that officer was not personally liable for corporate liability. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Alexander & Alexander of New York Inc. v. Fritzen
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In terms of legal responsibility, parent, subsidiary or affiliated corporations are treated separately and independently and one will not be held liable for contractual obligations of the other, unless it is shown that there was an exercise of complete dominion and control.
Document Preview: Corporation, which was either parent corporation or affiliate of employer, brought action against former employee and other defendants for conspiracy, unfair competition and tortious and malicious interference with its business relationships.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Clifford A. Scott, J., denied former employee's motion for summary judgment and granted corporation's cross motion to consolidate with action brought by employer, and former employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) corporation did not have standing to bring action against former employee for conspiracy to divert contracts or for tortious interference with employer's employment relationship; (2) corporation failed to state causes of action for prima facie tort and injurious falsehood; but (3) interest of justice would be best served by joint trial of action brought by corporation and action brought by employer. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jablonsky v. Klemm
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Attitude toward judicial piercing of corporate veil is more flexible in tort, as opposed to ordinary contract actions.
Document Preview: Purchasers of condominium units brought action against developer corporation and its president to recover damages for defective retaining wall.  The District Court, Stark County, Southwest Judicial District, William F. Hodny, J., entered damage award in favor of purchasers but denied recovery to those who had purchased their units with knowledge of the defect, and the parties cross-appealed.  The Supreme Court, Erickstad, C.J., held that: (1) trial court's decision to pierce developer's corporate veil and hold president personally liable was not clearly erroneous, and (2) record supported assessment and apportionment of damages. Affirmed. Meschke, J., filed specially concurring opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Friedman & Son, Inc. v. Safeway Stores, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. II.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation was alter ego of parent corporation and subsidiary corporation could not have interfered with contract between parent corporation for sale of cardboard to purchaser and conspiracy claim by purchaser could not be maintained, where all of stock of subsidiary corporation was owned by parent corporation, all of subsidiary's officers were parent corporation employees, two-thirds of subsidiary's board of directors were employees of parent corporation, and subsidiary had no business apart from that which it received from parent corporation.
Document Preview: Purchaser of cardboard brought action for breach of contract, intentional interference with contract, and civil conspiracy against vendor and subsidiary.  The District Court, City and County of Denver, Gilbert A. Alexander, J., denied motion of purchaser to amend complaint and entered summary judgment in favor of vendor.  Purchaser appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Berman, J., held that: (1) vendor breached contract containing requirement of 60 days written notice to purchaser before termination, but only to extent that vendor shipped cardboard prior to termination date of which vendor gave notice to purchaser; (2) subsidiary of vendor could not have interfered with contract between vendor and purchaser and conspiracy claim could not be maintained; and (3) purchaser was not entitled to amend its complaint to include bad-faith breach of contract claim. Affirmed in part, modified in part, and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Petersen v. Petersen
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Claim against wife on agreement between her and husband's construction company for additions to family home of which she was sole owner could not be extinguished by husband as an individual in a domestic relations context when, by his own admission, construction company in which he was a minority stockholder was not his alter ego.
Document Preview: In divorce action, the Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Larry R. Keller, J., entered judgment enforcing two notes executed by husband in favor of wife, but refused to enforce a construction agreement or to grant husband interest on sums expended by him in managing real estate contracts, and husband appealed.  The Supreme Court, Hall, C.J., held that: (1) finding that agreement by wife with husband's construction company for additions to family home of which she was sole owner was not intended by parties to be an accord and satisfaction of husband's personal obligations on two notes executed in favor of wife was supported by substantial evidence in record; (2) claim against wife on agreement between her and husband's construction company for additions to family home could not be extinguished by husband as an individual in a domestic relations context when, by his own admission, construction company in which he was a minority stockholder was not his alter...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bross Utilities Service Corp. v. Aboubshait
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary which negotiated international joint venture agreement but then chose to create foreign subsidiary to enter into actual written agreement could not assert claims of foreign subsidiary as basis for action for breach of joint venture agreement; court would not pierce corporate veil between parent and foreign subsidiary, regardless of whether subsidiary was created solely for tax purposes, whether that subsidiary had dissolved, or whether parent had guaranteed performance of contracts entered into by joint venture.
Document Preview: Parent corporation and domestic subsidiary brought action for breach of joint venture agreement to which parent's foreign subsidiary was a party, and for breach of alleged overarching oral partnership involving parent, domestic subsidiary and other parties to foreign subsidiary's joint venture. The District Court, Sprizzo, J., held that: (1) court would not pierce corporate veil between parent and foreign subsidiary to allow parent and domestic subsidiary to assert foreign subsidiary's rights, and (2) parent and domestic subsidiary could not enforce alleged overarching oral partnership which was identical to joint venture. Summary judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bross Utilities Service Corp. v. Aboubshait
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation's performance of work on behalf of subsidiary under joint venture to which only subsidiary was a party did not create contractual relationship between parent and other parties to joint venture.
Document Preview: Parent corporation and domestic subsidiary brought action for breach of joint venture agreement to which parent's foreign subsidiary was a party, and for breach of alleged overarching oral partnership involving parent, domestic subsidiary and other parties to foreign subsidiary's joint venture. The District Court, Sprizzo, J., held that: (1) court would not pierce corporate veil between parent and foreign subsidiary to allow parent and domestic subsidiary to assert foreign subsidiary's rights, and (2) parent and domestic subsidiary could not enforce alleged overarching oral partnership which was identical to joint venture. Summary judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bross Utilities Service Corp. v. Aboubshait
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation and domestic subsidiary could not enforce alleged "overarching oral partnership" agreement with foreign parties, which was identical to joint venture agreement between parent's foreign subsidiary and the same foreign parties; to permit action on oral partnership theory would in effect nullify rule preventing parent corporation from ignoring separate corporate existence of its subsidiary for its own benefit.
Document Preview: Parent corporation and domestic subsidiary brought action for breach of joint venture agreement to which parent's foreign subsidiary was a party, and for breach of alleged overarching oral partnership involving parent, domestic subsidiary and other parties to foreign subsidiary's joint venture. The District Court, Sprizzo, J., held that: (1) court would not pierce corporate veil between parent and foreign subsidiary to allow parent and domestic subsidiary to assert foreign subsidiary's rights, and (2) parent and domestic subsidiary could not enforce alleged overarching oral partnership which was identical to joint venture. Summary judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: RRX Industries, Inc. v. Lab-Con, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego doctrine applied to render individual defendant personally liable for corporation's breach of sales contract, where defendant was president and only officer, director, and stockholder of corporation, corporation had no board of directors or employees, no stockholder meetings were ever held, and corporation was undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Buyer of computer software system brought breach of contract action against seller based on defects in system.  The United States District Court for the Central District of California, Edward Rafeedie, J., entered judgment in favor of buyer, awarding amount paid under contract and consequential damages, and seller appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Eugene A. Wright, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil could be pierced to hold corporate president personally liable; (2) successor corporation to seller was liable; (3) evidence supported finding that seller breached contract for sale of computer software; (4) computer software system was good, rather than service, for purposes of determining remedies; and (5) buyer was entitled to consequential damages for seller's total and fundamental breach. Affirmed. Norris, Circuit Judge, concurred in part, dissented in part, and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Eagle v. Benefield-Chappell, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Deliberate conduct by the two shareholders in closely held shell corporation in increasing actual construction costs on which corporation's design fee was to be based and then adding an additional amount to the increased cost for the design fee, contrary to terms of contract, was sufficient showing of improper conduct to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Customers brought action against design firm and its two shareholders seeking refund of furniture deposits, and alleging conversion.  The Circuit Court for Palm Beach County, William C. Owen, Jr., J., rendered judgment against corporation for refund but found that customers failed to prove that corporate veil should be pierced or that defendants committed conversion, and customers appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Rivkind, Leonard, Associate Judge, held that: (1) furniture deposits which customers delivered to design firm were sufficiently capable of identification where they were delivered to be used for a specific purpose, even though there was no restriction against commingling in the firm's account, and thus conversion took place when the money was disbursed without authorization, and (2) deliberate increase of actual construction costs on which design fee to closely held shell corporation was to be based, and then adding additional amount to the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jurgens v. Abraham
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, shareholder of corporation would be liable for any breach of contract by corporation if corporation had been created to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: Diversity action was brought by payer of finders fee against several individuals associated with individual to whom fee was paid after monies were not properly deposited in escrow account or loan commitments, for which the fee was paid, secured.  The defendants moved for dismissal.  The United States District Court, District of Massachusetts, Garrity, J., held that: (1) under Massachusetts law dismissal of action against individual who received the funds and related corporation did not have collateral estoppel effect; (2) lack of peculiar power of coercion of defendants precluded claim for civil conspiracy; (3) defendants whose conduct had been relied upon as attorneys, although payer of fees was not a client, could be found to be liable for negligence; and (4) escrow agent could not be held liable as escrow agent for failure of parties to escrow agreement to properly deliver the money to him. Motions to dismiss granted in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: E.B. Roberts Const. Co. v. Concrete Contractors, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: Third-party beneficiary to construction contract between general contractor and subcontractor was not alter ego of subcontractor, absent evidence that there was any formal corporate connection between third party and subcontractor.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from judgment of the District Court, Adams County, James Delaney, J., finding breach of contract and awarding mechanic's lien on certain property.  The Court of Appeals, 664 P.2d 722, affirmed the finding of breach of contract and the mechanic's lien award, and certiorari was granted.  The Supreme Court, Lohr, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's summary finding that mechanic's lien claimed in lien statement was not excessive at the time of filing; (2) lien rights of mechanic's lien claimants were not forfeited, although amount of mechanic's lien claimed in lien statement was in excess of that actually awarded by trial court; and (3) third party was beneficiary of amended construction contract between general contractor and subcontractor and thus, was entitled to bring action for damages for lost profits sustained as result of contractor's breach of such contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: McCulloch Gas Transmission Co. v. Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
