Headnote: Corporate veil of subsidiaries could not be pierced to hold parent liable for breach of contract of subsidiaries, even though parent was alter ego of subsidiaries, where there was no finding that failure to pierce corporate veil would defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: Purchaser entered into 20-year gas purchase contract.  Seller assigned contract.  Purchaser brought breach of contract action against parent of seller and its assignee.  The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, Clarence A. Brimmer, Jr., J., entered judgment for purchaser, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, David L. Russell, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that corporate veil could not be pierced to hold parent liable for breach of contract, even though parent was alter ego, where there was no finding that failure to pierce corporate veil would defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jenkins v. Judith Sans Internationale, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where party has overextended his privilege in use of corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought suit for damages sustained as result of receiving certain cellulite treatments.  The Fulton Superior Court, Fryer, J., granted summary judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that: (1) absent evidence of abuse of corporate form, no issue as to piercing corporate veil was presented, and (2) defendant was not jointly and severally liable with corporation which owned and operated salon. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Branscum v. Castleberry
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: In contract cases, there must be a showing of fraud or bad faith in order to provide exception to general rule that forbids ignoring corporate existence.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and its shareholders to collect promissory note executed by corporation.  The 193rd District Court, Dallas County, Whittington, J., entered judgment against defendants jointly and severally, and shareholders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Akin, J., held that evidence did not support piercing corporate veil so as to hold shareholders individually liable for promissory note executed by corporation. Reversed. Howell, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pasta House Co. v. Miller
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Where corporation is used for improper purpose and to perpetrate injustice by assisting another corporation to avoid its contractual obligations, equity will step in, pierce the corporate veil, and grant appropriate relief.
Document Preview: Suit was instituted for an injunction prohibiting individual and corporate defendants from using plaintiff's trademarks, for a judgment on a defaulted note, for possession of items and accounts receivable pledged as security, and for judgment on an individual guarantee.  The Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, Michael F. Godfrey, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and against defendants on their counterclaim, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Snyder, J., held that: (1) evidence that first corporation which began operating from headquarters of corporate defendant after execution of royalty and licensing agreement with plaintiff was used for an improper purpose to assist corporate defendant to avoid its obligations to plaintiff under agreement justified piercing the corporate veil to award corporation's accounts receivable to plaintiff, and (2) although second corporation operated from defendant's headquarters after completion of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pasta House Co. v. Miller
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Evidence that corporation which began operating from headquarters of corporate defendant after execution of royalty and licensing agreement with plaintiff was used for an improper purpose and to perpetrate injustice by assisting corporate defendant to avoid its obligations to plaintiff under agreement justified piercing the corporate veil to award corporation's accounts receivable to plaintiff on ground that it was simply defendant's alter ego when it had no assets and used defendant's facilities, equipment, inventory, and employees.
Document Preview: Suit was instituted for an injunction prohibiting individual and corporate defendants from using plaintiff's trademarks, for a judgment on a defaulted note, for possession of items and accounts receivable pledged as security, and for judgment on an individual guarantee. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pasta House Co. v. Miller
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Although corporation operated from defendant's headquarters after completion of royalty and licensing agreement whereby defendant took over production and sales of frozen food products from plaintiff, where corporation dealt only in bulk food products which were foreign to products which were subject of agreement, and was not used for an improper purpose or for purpose of perpetrating fraud or injustice, there was no basis for piercing the corporate veil to award the corporation's accounts receivable to plaintiff on the basis that it was defendant's alter ego.
Document Preview: Suit was instituted for an injunction prohibiting individual and corporate defendants from using plaintiff's trademarks, for a judgment on a defaulted note, for possession of items and accounts receivable pledged as security, and for judgment on an individual guarantee.  The Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, Michael F. Godfrey, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and against defendants on their counterclaim, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Snyder, J., held that: (1) evidence that first corporation which began operating from headquarters of corporate defendant after execution of royalty and licensing agreement with plaintiff was used for an improper purpose to assist corporate defendant to avoid its obligations to plaintiff under agreement justified piercing the corporate veil to award corporation's accounts receivable to plaintiff, and (2) although second corporation operated from defendant's headquarters after completion of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Davis v. Professional Business Services, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho.
Headnote: Conduct of president of account billing service in refusing to relinquish ledger cards to client was in nature of contract breach, not tort, and, hence, piercing of corporate veil to impose liability upon president individually for client's cost of reconstructing account records was not warranted.
Document Preview: Client brought action against account billing service to recover damages arising out of latter's refusal to relinquish ledger cards to client upon termination of the parties' contractual relationship.  From judgment of the Fifth Judicial District Court, Twin Falls County, Theron Ward, J., various parties appealed.  The Supreme Court, Bistline, J., held that: (1) billing service's refusal to release ledger cards under the circumstances was a breach of an implied term of the parties' contract; (2) conduct of president of billing service was in nature of contract breach, not tort, and hence, piercing of corporate veil to impose individual liability upon president for client's cost of reconstructing account records was not warranted; (3) attorney fee award was not warranted; (4) account billing service was not a collection agency and it was improper to dismiss counterclaim for failure to have statutorily required collection agency...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Harris v. Best of America Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Facts that contractor's 1981 federal tax return showed capital of $200, while gross receipts for the year totalled over $1,200,000, and that the tax return showed a loss, yet corporation paid its president over $100,000 in salary for year did not warrant piercing corporate veil to hold president liable on contractor's contract with plaintiff.
Document Preview: Contractor and its president appealed from the Twenty-Second Judicial District Court, Parish of Washington, James R. Strain, Jr., J., which determined that owner was entitled to recover certain damages for faulty work under construction contract.  The Court of Appeal, Carter, J., held that: (1) stipulated damages provided in contract did not limit award of damages to owner for faulty workmanship; (2) trial court properly relied upon testimony of plaintiff's experts in determining award of damages; and (3) totality of facts did not support a finding that corporation had ceased to exist as an entity, separate and distinct from its sole shareholder, so as to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder liable on contract with plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Minnesota Bond Ltd. v. St. Paul Mercury Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon, In Banc.
Headnote: In order for a court to pierce the corporate veil and hold that wrongful acts of a 50 percent shareholder will bar recovery by corporate insured under fire insurance policy it must first be shown that the arsonist dominated the corporate affairs and that the other parties authorized or ratified that dominance; thus, finding that the arsonist was a dominant actor and piercing the corporate veil are not alternative theories for denying recovery to corporate insured.
Document Preview: Insurer appealed from a judgment of the Circuit Court, Deschutes County, Walter I. Edmonds, Jr., J., in favor of insured under a fire insurance contract, claiming that arson and misrepresentation by insured's 50 percent shareholder, officer and director barred any recovery for losses after the fire.  The Court of Appeals, Rossman, J., held that: (1) a corporation will not be precluded from recovery under a fire insurance policy simply because arsonist owns 50 percent of the corporation's stock; without evidence that other stockholders acquiesced in the arsonist's conduct, the corporation is innocent of wrongdoing and may recover for its loss, and (2) the corporation neither explicitly authorized 50 percent shareholder's action setting fire to corporate premises nor implicitly ratified them by allowing her to dominate corporate affairs, and thus, corporation could recover under fire insurance policy for losses it suffered from the fire. Affirmed. Warren, J.,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Minnesota Bond Ltd. v. St. Paul Mercury Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon, In Banc.
Headnote: Where 50 percent shareholder who set fire to corporate insured's premises was not dominant actor in corporate affairs, and where there was no evidence of authorization or ratification for her acts, corporate veil of the corporation would not be pierced in order to deny recovery to insured corporation under its fire insurance policy.
Document Preview: Insurer appealed from a judgment of the Circuit Court, Deschutes County, Walter I. Edmonds, Jr., J., in favor of insured under a fire insurance contract, claiming that arson and misrepresentation by insured's 50 percent shareholder, officer and director barred any recovery for losses after the fire. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Manchester Hides, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Iowa.
Headnote: Corporation and wholly owned subsidiary were two separate and distinct entities and thus an offset agreement signed by one in favor of debtor was not effective against the other corporation in the absence of evidence that subsidiary was undercapitalized, and corporation and subsidiary kept separate books and separate finances; there was no evidence indicating that subsidiary did not follow corporate formalities, and subsidiary was formed to take advantage of favorable domestic international sales corporations regulations, not to promote fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: Trustee filed turnover complaint.  The Bankruptcy Court, William W. Thinnes, J., held that: (1) subsidiary corporation did not misrepresent character of its business relation with debtor in a no offset agreement; (2) even if there was misrepresentation with respect to character of business transaction between a subsidiary and debtor where no offset agreement was signed, misrepresentation was not material; and (3) creditor was entitled to set off amounts owed debtor. Ordered accordingly. Sell also Bkrtcy., 32 B.R. 629.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tennessee Valley Authority v. Exxon Nuclear Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation and a subsidiary are in law separate and distinct entities, and under ordinary circumstances a contract in terms and in name with one corporation cannot be treated as that of both, and a parent corporation will not be liable for the obligations of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Supplier of uranium fuel and its parent company appealed from order entered by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Robert L. Taylor, Chief Judge, 570 F.Supp. 462, granting summary judgment in favor of Tennessee Valley Authority, reversing decision of the TVA Board of Contract Appeals, which held TVA liable on contract for one half of parent company's increased costs in producing uranium fuel.  The Court of Appeals, Gilmore, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that parent company was not entitled to compensation for increased production costs in accordance with special conditions contained in contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Huebner v. Sales Promotion, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 2.
Headnote: In action for damages and rescission of partnership agreement which was a franchise, trial court did not err in piercing corporate veil and asserting personal jurisdiction over individual defendants who made personal contacts in state sufficient for exercise of jurisdiction over them; the court did not assert personal jurisdiction over them merely because they worked for a corporation subject to Washington jurisdiction. U.S.C.A. Const.Amends. 5, 14.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and others for rescission of partnership agreement and damages.  It was alleged that the agreement violated Washington's Franchise Investment Protection Act.  The Superior Court, Thurston County, Orris L. Hamilton, J., entered summary judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Worswick, J., held that: (1) the partnership agreement was a franchise where corporation granted individual a license to use its trademark; (2) corporation had notice that it was subject to suit in Washington; and (3) trial court did not err in asserting jurisdiction over the individual defendants, as they were responsible for advertisements in Washington which led to signing of partnership agreement, and as they offered and negotiated other agreements with Washington residents. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hogan v. Mayor & Aldermen of Savannah
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Person who was corporate officer and shareholder brought action against the corporation's uninsured motorist insurer to recover damages for injuries sustained in accident which occurred while he was riding in police car to retrieve apparently impounded company vehicle.  The Superior Court, Chatham County, Oliver, J., granted summary judgment in favor of the insurer, and the corporate officer and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, C.J., held that: (1) the policy did not provide coverage for the plaintiff, who was not a named insured under the policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to view plaintiff as the named insured; and (3) statutory definition of insured as including the personal representative of any of the above did not provide coverage for the corporate officer and shareholder. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sicilia Di R. Biebow & Co. v. Cox
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where neither shareholder of corporation which imported citrus juice nor corporation formed by shareholder to market citrus juice in similarly shaped bottle were a party to the importation-distribution contract, for them to be liable under any breach of noncompete provisions of that contract, it was incumbent on the foreign seller to establish those compelling circumstances as would justify piercing the corporate veil to prevent fraud or other inequity and such showing was lacking where corporate formalities were followed and the importing corporation sold the product to the shareholders' corporation at a profit.
Document Preview: Trade dress infringement case was brought based on defendants' copying of plaintiff's design for citrus juice bottles.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Robert M. Hill, J., dismissed, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Reavley, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court incorrectly applied doctrine of functionality and, hence, its finding that plaintiff's bottle design was not distinctive could not be upheld, and (2) finding that defendant had no intent to infringe plaintiff's trade dress was clearly erroneous.  In addition, the court set forth the law as to the meaning and application of doctrine of functionality. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Edwards Co., Inc. v. Monogram Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, to pierce the corporate veil in a contract action it must be shown that the subsidiary was used by the parent for fraud or injustice and it is not alone sufficient to show that subsidiary is a mere agent or conduit of the parent; declining to follow Jetty, Inc. v. Hall McGuff Architects, 595 S.W.2d 918 and National Marine Service, Inc. v. C.J. Thibodeaux & Co., 501 F.2d 940.
Document Preview: Creditor of partnership in which wholly owned subsidiary was general partner sued the parent corporation to recover amount due and unpaid for supplies furnished the partnership.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Walter Ely, J., sitting by designation, rendered judgment against creditor, and it appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 700 F.2d 994, reversed and remanded.  On petition for rehearing, the Court of Appeals, 713 F.2d 139, held that subsidiary was a mere sham entity.  Rehearing en banc was granted, 715 F.2d 157.  The Court of Appeals, en banc, Randall, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Texas law, a showing of fraud or injustice is required to pierce the corporate veil in a contract action and that no such showing was made, and (2) in any event, subsidiary could not be properly characterized as nothing more than a piece of paper lying in a file cabinet. Judgment of District Court affirmed. Alvin B....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carroll v. Smith-Henry, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: That parent and subsidiary corporations share common officers or directors does not by itself impose liability on parent for contracts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Former employee brought breach of employment contract action.  The Common Pleas Court, Greenville County, Frank Eppes, J., entered judgment in his favor, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Goolsby, J., held that allegations contained in complaint and answer placed before trial court issue of whether employee was employed during relevant period by parent corporation or its subsidiary; therefore, trial court erred in refusing parent corporation's requested instruction which related to issue of a parent corporation's liability for a subsidiary's contracts, and that error was reversible, as jury might well have concluded in its absence that a parent corporation is always liable on its subsidiary's contracts. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: E.C.A. Environmental Management Services, Inc. v. Toenyes
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Even if fertilizer spreading contract technically bound subsidiary, rather than parent corporation, where parent owned 100% of capital stock of subsidiary, virtually all corporate formalities were abandoned by subsidiary prior to execution of contract, all directors of subsidiary were also directors of parent, it was in course of meeting of board of directors of parent that fertilizer spreading agreement was initially proposed, and subsidiary's operations were financed by parents, subsidiary was alter ego of parent.
Document Preview: Fertilizer spreading business gave demand promissory note in amount of $7,000 plus interest at 11 1/212 percent in exchange for loan on that amount.  Additionally, it purchased $1,062 worth of diesel fuel on credit.  Holder of note brought action to recover amount due on promissory note and its subsidiary filed suit to recover amount owed for diesel fuel.  Fertilizer business counterclaimed for breach of commercial contract.  The District Court, Eighth Judicial District, in and for Parish of Cascade, Joel G. Roth, J., entered judgment in favor of fertilizer spreading business, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Haswell, C.J., held that: (1) diesel sale was bona fide credit sale outside scope of usury and retail installment contract statute; (2) assessment of usury penalty up to date of trial on note was proper; (3) fertilizer spreading business was prevailing party on promissory note issue for purposes of determining...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: E.C.A. Environmental Management Services, Inc. v. Toenyes
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Where after expiration of fertilizer contract entered into by subsidiary, parent transferred assets of subsidiary to its own books in parcel cancellation of debt, subsidiary effectively ceased business, and consequently, had no assets from which to satisfy judgment for breach of contract, parent could not escape contractual liability by asserting it was not personally liable for obligations.
Document Preview: Fertilizer spreading business gave demand promissory note in amount of $7,000 plus interest at 11 1/212 percent in exchange for loan on that amount.  Additionally, it purchased $1,062 worth of diesel fuel on credit.  Holder of note brought action to recover amount due on promissory note and its subsidiary filed suit to recover amount owed for diesel fuel.  Fertilizer business counterclaimed for breach of commercial contract.  The District Court, Eighth Judicial District, in and for Parish of Cascade, Joel G. Roth, J., entered judgment in favor of fertilizer spreading business, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Haswell, C.J., held that: (1) diesel sale was bona fide credit sale outside scope of usury and retail installment contract statute; (2) assessment of usury penalty up to date of trial on note was proper; (3) fertilizer spreading business was prevailing party on promissory note issue for purposes of determining...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: NCR Credit Corp. v. Underground Camera, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Where subsidiary was presented to defendant as subsidiary that would finance sales contract and the subsidiary's actions were consistent with that role, while parent was the corporation whose representatives negotiated sales contract, whose system was purchased and installed and whose personnel serviced system, the parent corporation was proper party for plaintiff to sue upon complaint centering dissatisfaction with system purchased and not with financing program, and case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard.
Document Preview: In a suit for money allegedly due and unpaid on a computer sales contract, and on various motions, the District Court, Caffrey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) point charging that defendants conspired to defraud plaintiff to its great harm and detriment was insufficient to inform opposing party of nature of the conspiracy charged; (2) case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard; (3) court having declined to treat parent manufacturer and financing subsidiary corporation as same entity, it was found that subsidiary did not waive parent's right to arbitrate by filing suit in federal court, and where outcome of arbitration might dispose of some or all claims outstanding, proceedings in the court between plaintiff buyer and financing subsidiary would also be stayed pending outcome of arbitration; and (4) description of pending case in news weekly was unlikely to interfere with any litigant's right to fair...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Tennessee Pools and Recreation, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of contracting company which entered into contract with debtor containing noncompetition agreement and, debtor having done nothing to breach contract containing the noncompetition agreement, corporation and its principals were liable for violation of the agreement.
Document Preview: Debtor brought action against corporation and its principals for breach of noncompetition agreement.  The Bankruptcy Court, George C. Paine, II, J., held that: (1) corporation was alter ego of contracting company which entered into contract containing noncompetition agreement and, debtor having done nothing to breach contract containing the noncompetition agreement, corporation and its principals were liable for violation of the agreement; (2) in light of defendants' flagrant violation of the noncompetition agreement, counterclaim for procuring breach of contract for construction of swimming pool would be dismissed; and (3) debtor was entitled to nominal damages of $10 against corporation, as well as punitive damage award of $2,500 each against corporation and its principals. Judgment for plaintiff; counterclaim and third-party complaint dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Giblin v. Murphy
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where corporate veil was being pierced, contractual agreements between corporation and another would actually be considered as contract between the other person and the individual shareholders and officers of the corporation.
Document Preview: Seller of business, who was pledgee of stock of the purchasing business, brought fraud and breach of contract action against purchasing business and its officers and directors.  The Supreme Court, Schoharie County, Kahn, J., entered judgment in favor of seller and purchaser and its officers appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) there was no showing of fraud on the basis of defendant's failure to fulfill certain promises; (2) corporate veil was properly pierced; (3) corporate officers had breached duty owed to seller as shareholder and pledgee through wantonly negligent conduct of the business; and (4) award of punitive damages was proper. Affirmed as modified and remitted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Amarillo Oil Co. v. Mapco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil in tort or contract context, no single factor is determinative: not complete stock ownership, not filing of joint tax returns, not interlocking directors and officers, and not loans between parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs filed suit seeking declaration that they were entitled to extract certain liquid hydrocarbons from natural gas delivered to them pursuant to contract, and defendant corporation moved to dismiss, alleging that its subsidiary was current owner of rights to liquid hydrocarbons in dispute, and therefore, was party whose joinder was needed for just adjudication. The District Court, Mary Lou Robinson, J., held that: (1) subsidiary's separate corporate existence could not be disregarded for purposes of jurisdiction, and (2) subsidiary was indispensable party to action. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rao v. Rao
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Individual who was corporation's sole shareholder, officer and director would be considered by Illinois court not to be separate entity capable of inducing corporation to breach its contracts.
Document Preview: Corporation brought action seeking specific enforcement of restrictive covenant of employment agreement or liquidated damages.  Dismissed employee counterclaimed.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, Hubert L. Will, J., entered judgment from which appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Eschbach, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) employer who dismisses employee without good cause and in bad faith is not entitled to enforcement of restrictive covenant; (2) individual plaintiff who was corporation's sole shareholder, officer and director would be considered by Illinois court not to be separate entity capable of inducing corporation to breach its contracts; and (3) certain tort claims by the dismissed employee could not be judicially decided by reason of provision in the employment agreement for arbitration. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Valentine v. Ormsbee Exploration Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: In oil well driller's action against owner of oil lease to recover for furnishing of drilling rig and for loss of string of tools incurred in drilling well, disregarding of corporate entity was not error, in view of indication that driller was not even aware of the corporation's existence when driller entered into contract with owner.
Document Preview: Oil well driller brought action to recover against owner of oil lease for furnishing of drilling rig and for loss of string of tools incurred in drilling of a well.  Owner brought third-party action against a seller based on theory that defect in bail caused loss of the string of tools.  The District Court, Converse County, William A. Taylor, J., entered judgment for driller against owner, and in favor of owner on the third-party complaint against seller, and owner and seller appealed.  The Supreme Court, Guthrie, Retired Justice, held that: (1) admission of evidence that owner bore the loss because of the custom or usage in the oil industry was not error, and the finding that the custom would impose the loss on owner would not be disturbed on appeal; (2) disregarding of a corporate entity was not error, in view of indication that driller was not even aware of the corporation's existence when driller entered into contract with owner; (3)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Miles v. American Tel. & Tel. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: As traditionally applied in parent-subsidiary context, alter ego doctrine permits imposition of liability upon parent company for torts and contractual obligations of its subsidiary where parent exercises actual control over subsidiary and operates it as a mere instrumentality or tool; under these circumstances, subsidiary is merely a conduit through which parent conducts its business.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from summary judgment dismissal by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Robert W. Porter, J., of tortious invasion of privacy suit against a corporation.  The Court of Appeals, Politz, Circuit Judge, held that defendant was not liable as alter ego of its wholly-owned subsidiaries. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Miles v. American Tel. & Tel. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be evaluated in determining whether a subsidiary corporation is nothing more than a mere adjunct of its parent such as to permit imposition of liability upon parent for torts and contractual obligations of subsidiary include whether: distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are incorporated and maintained; daily operations of the two corporations are separate; formal barriers between management of the two entities are erected, with each functioning in its own best interests; those with whom corporations come in contact are apprised of their separate identity; common stock ownership; method and degree of financing of subsidiary by parent; common directors or officers; separate books and accounts; common business departments; extent to which contracts between parent and subsidiary favor one over the other; and connection of parent's employee, officer or director to subsidiary's tort or contract giving rise to suit.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from summary judgment dismissal by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Robert W. Porter, J., of tortious invasion of privacy suit against a corporation.  The Court of Appeals, Politz, Circuit Judge, held that defendant was not liable as alter ego of its wholly-owned subsidiaries. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: McFerren v. Universal Coatings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Manufacturer was liable for defective installation of product by manufacturer's "sister" company, even though written contract containing guaranty was between only purchaser and installer, in view of facts that same individual was president and owned stock in both companies, each of which provided services in skating rink business, that sister company was exclusive installer of manufacturer's product, that both companies were located in same building and their affairs were intimately interwoven, all of which led purchaser to reasonably believe that manufacturer was at least a party, if not principal party, with whom he contracted.
Document Preview: Action was brought against manufacturer and installer of allegedly defective skating rink surface.  The Tenth Judicial District Court, Parish of Natchitoches, W. Peyton Cunningham, Jr., J., rendered judgment in favor of purchaser.  Manufacturer of product appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Yelverton, J., held that: (1) damage award, representing total paid by purchaser under contract, was proper, and (2) manufacturer was liable for defective installation of product by manufacturer's sister company, even though written contract containing guaranty was between only purchaser and installer, where all circumstances led purchaser to reasonably believe that manufacturer was at least a party, if not the principal party, with whom he had contracted. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kuennen v. Citizens Sec. Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Decision of Roepke v. Western National Mutual Insurance Co. did not permit piercing corporate veil for purpose of treating majority shareholder of corporation, who was killed in an automobile accident, as named insured on automobile policy which covered four vehicles owned by corporation, where majority shareholder was not sole shareholder and only two of the four corporate vehicles were used as family vehicles.
Document Preview: Insurer appealed from a summary judgment granted by the District Court, Stearns County, Paul Hoffman, J., in favor of plaintiff in her suit to recover benefits under automobile policies.  The Supreme Court, Scott, J., held that the decision of Roepke v. Western National Mutual Insurance Co. did not permit piercing of the corporate veil for the purpose of treating majority shareholder of corporation, who was killed in an automobile accident, as the named insured on the automobile policy which covered the four corporate vehicles, where majority shareholder was not the sole shareholder and only two of the four corporate vehicles were used as family vehicles. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Knowlton Co. v. Knowlton
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Owner of all voting stock of closely held family corporation, who acquired the same pursuant to a separation agreement from husband, could not use the corporation as an instrument to avoid and defeat the manifest purpose and intent of her own contract to release husband from any liability for any claim existing at the time of the execution of the separation agreement; however, the separation and escrow agreements did not extend to claims between signatories to the separation and escrow agreements which arose thereafter.
Document Preview: Closely held family corporation appealed from a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, Franklin County, which sustained motion of defendant shareholders for summary judgment and entered judgment in their favor and dismissed corporation's complaint, while retaining for future determination the counterclaims and cross claims filed by defendants.  The Court of Appeals, Whiteside, P.J., held that owner of all voting stock of closely held family corporation, who acquired the same pursuant to a separation agreement from husband, could not use the corporation as an instrument to avoid and defeat the manifest purpose and intent of her own contract to release husband from any liability for any claim existing at the time of the execution of the separation agreement; however, the separation and escrow agreements did not extend to claims between the signatories to the separation and escrow agreements which arose thereafter. Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kelley v. Austell Bldg. Supply, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded where defendant has overextended his privilege in use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Building materials seller brought action on account against individual owner of corporate buyer.  Owner counterclaimed for damages for interference with business, malicious prosecution, and malicious abuse of process, seeking damages for the intentional wrongs and for punitive damages as well.  The Superior Court, Douglas County, Arthur W. Fudger, J., entered judgment on a jury verdict in favor of seller, but struck jury award of punitive damages in favor of owner on counterclaim.  Owner appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in holding that punitive damages could not be awarded by jury unless actual damages were also awarded; (2) where owner failed to object to form of verdicts prior to jury's deliberation or after verdicts were returned by jury, owner waived any complaints that trial court should have sent jury back for further deliberations; (3) evidence as to whether contract was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: LeBlanc v. Opt, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Where developer had control of corporation, he failed to hold regular shareholder and directors meetings, he failed to follow statutory formalities and transaction of corporate affairs, and he freely commingled funds from one corporation to the other, trial court, which awarded plaintiff developer $132,950 based on quantum meruit, properly disregarded corporate veil and held defendant developer personally liable.
Document Preview: From judgment entered by the 9th Judicial District Court, Parish of Rapides, Jules L. Davidson, Jr., J., awarding real estate developer $132,950 based on quantum meruit, defendant developer and his wholly owned corporation appealed. The Court of Appeal, Yelverton, J., held that: (1) trial court properly entered award in favor of plaintiff developer based on quantum meruit; (2) trial court properly disregarded corporate veil and held defendant developer personally liable; and (3) trial court erred in assessing to plaintiff one half of the costs of the trial proceedings. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hight Enterprises, Inc. v. Smith and Johnson (Shipping) Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder corporation could not be held liable, as an agent, for amount owing on dredging contract since principal would be either contracting corporation or its client, whose liability was not in question.
Document Preview: Dredging company brought action against contracting corporation and shareholder corporation to collect balance on a dredging contract.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Steven R. Plotkin, J., rendered judgment against both defendant corporations, and shareholder corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Barry, J., held that shareholder corporation could not be held liable either as a parent or undisclosed agent of contracting corporation or its client, or as shareholder of contracting corporation. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Matthes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S. D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In order to hold debtor liable under section of Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act governing breach of express or implied warranty for damages flowing from construction work performed under contract when debtor was not individually a party to contract but acted only as agent of wholly owned corporation, corporate veil would have to be pierced. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 17.50(a)(2).
Document Preview: Debtors filed objection to claim of homeowner for damages flowing from defective remodeling performed by corporation solely owned and operated by debtor. The Bankruptcy Court, Edward H. Patton, Jr., J., held that corporate veil could not be pierced to hold debtor personally liable for breach of warranty in construction work performed on homeowner's residence. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Matthes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S. D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil of corporation solely owned and operated by debtors could not be pierced to hold debtor personally liable for breach of warranty in construction work performed on residence pursuant to contract to which debtor was not individually a party but acted only as agent of corporation. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 17.50(a)(2).
Document Preview: Debtors filed objection to claim of homeowner for damages flowing from defective remodeling performed by corporation solely owned and operated by debtor. The Bankruptcy Court, Edward H. Patton, Jr., J., held that corporate veil could not be pierced to hold debtor personally liable for breach of warranty in construction work performed on homeowner's residence. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Allstate Ins. Co. v. Citizens Ins. Co. of America
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil of closely-held corporation so as to render applicable automobile insurance policy covering vehicles provided by corporation to sole stockholder and his family for business and personal use was not warranted. M.C.L.A. § 500.3114(3).
Document Preview: First automobile insurer brought action as equitable subrogee of insured to compel second automobile insurer to make future payments and to seek repayment of benefits already paid.  The Wayne Circuit Court, John H. Hausner, J., entered judgment, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Allen, P.J., held that: (1) statute governing extension of automobile personal protection insurance provided to employees while driving vehicle owned or registered by employer to employee's family did not require that policy issued to closely-held corporation to cover cars provided for sole stockholder and his family cover medical and economic losses sustained by sole stockholder's son while passenger in noncovered automobile; (2) piercing of corporate veil of closely-held corporation so as to render automobile insurance policy covering vehicles provided by corporation to sole stockholder and his family for business and personal use was not warranted; and (3) it...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hickman v. Rawls
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Where corporation was not a sham used for some illegal scheme, but was organized for legitimate purpose which failed due to circumstances beyond the control of the shareholders and where no evidence existed of any circumstance to suggest that the corporate entity was used against the public policy, plaintiffs could not pierce the corporate veil in order to hold sole shareholders liable for the corporation's breach of contract.
Document Preview: Action was brought seeking to pierce corporate veil in order to hold sole shareholders of corporation liable for the corporation's breach of contract.  The 191st District Court, Dallas County, Charles Ben Howell, J., rendered judgment against shareholders, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Akin, J., held that where corporation was not a sham used for some illegal scheme, but was organized for legitimate purpose which failed due to circumstances beyond the control of the shareholders and where no evidence existed of any circumstance to suggest that the corporate entity was used against public policy, plaintiffs were not entitled to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold sole shareholders liable for corporation's breach of contract. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: International City Bank and Trust Co. v. Morgan Walton Properties, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In absence of legal grounds for disregarding separate existence of two corporations, contract of one is not contract of other.
Document Preview: Makers appealed from judgments entered by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida, Winston E. Arnow, Chief Judge, in mortgage foreclosure proceedings. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) notes payable on demand or two years after date were payable on demand and, in absence of demand, two years after execution; (2) formal demand was not necessary prior to commencing suit; (3) evidence was sufficient to support determination that there was no issue of material fact regarding existence of seven-year joint venture or financing contract; and (4) denial of makers' motion for new trial, which was premised upon allegedly prejudicial statements made by bank's counsel in closing argument, was not abuse of discretion. Affirmed. See also 612 F.2d 227;404 So.2d 1059.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mitsui & Co., Inc. v. Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: In action by prime contractor to recover pass-through claims on behalf of subcontractor arising in connection with construction of fossil fuel plant, fact that third party to whom prime contractor had assigned contract was parent corporation of prime contractor did not preclude recovery by prime contractor, since there were no grounds on which to pierce corporate veil. 31 L.P.R.A. § 4429.
Document Preview: A prime contractor filed an action to recover damages arising out of the construction of a fossil fuel plant. A motion and cross motion for summary judgment were filed. The District Court, Perez-Giminez, J., held that: (1) the prime contractor was real party in interest, even though any monetary recovery would accrue to the benefit of the subcontractor; (2) there was sufficient privity of contract to allow the prime contractor to maintain the action, since the prime contractor and the owner were the parties to the prime contract; (3) the prime contractor did not lose its status simply because the prime contract was assigned to a related third party; and (4) even if the assignment was improper under the provisions of the prime contract, that did not preclude the prime contractor from maintaining the action. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mississippi River Grain Elevator, Inc. v. Bartlett & Co., Grain
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Unit A
Headnote: There was no error in determination that each member of group of defendants in counterclaim were liable in solido to grain trader on buy/sell contracts, under Louisiana law, as alter ego of the others, based on finding that members of group, while discreet corporations, were so centrally managed and interrelated that they functioned, at all pertinent times, as mere instrumentalities of each other.
Document Preview: Exporters brought suit against grain trader alleging breach of contract. Trader counterclaimed for shortweighing losses, expenses incidental to contract breaches, lost profits and loan grain discrepancy, and added other defendant in counterclaim. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, at New Orleans, Adrian G. Duplantier, J., awarded one exporter judgment against trader for $21,637.17, and granted judgment in favor of trader on its counterclaim for shortweighing losses and expenses incidental to contract breaches, but denied its claims for lost profits and loan grain discrepancy, and appeal and cross appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals, Politz, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) de novo determination of factual findings of magistrate was not required; (2) there was no error in determination that each member of group of defendants in counterclaim were liable in solido to grain trader on buy/sell contracts, under Louisiana law, as alter ego of the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re Mid-West Metal Products, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities of debtor and its parent were disregarded, where debtor was a party to the contract although not named in the body of the contract, plaintiff employee was hired to work for debtor by officers of debtor, claimant did in fact work for debtor, and was paid by debtor at rate set out in agreement, and thus obligations of parent under agreement should be treated as obligations of the debtor.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, former employee of debtor, filed proof of claim which included claims for salary, vacation pay, and other benefits, and debtor objected. The Bankruptcy Court, Benjamin E. Franklin, J., held that: (1) separate corporate entities of debtor and its parent were disregarded, where debtor was party to employment contract even though it was not named in body of the contract, plaintiff was hired to work for debtor by officers of debtor, plaintiff did in fact work for debtor, and was paid by debtor at the rate set out in the agreement, and thus obligations of parent under employment agreement should be treated as obligations of the debtor, and (2) where debtor's company policy was that an employee became entitled to one week's vacation only after working at debtor for one year, and plaintiff worked for debtor for less than one year, he was not entitled to $1,500 vacation pay based upon vacation entitlement which allegedly became due and payable on January 1, 1980....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Amfac Foods, Inc. v. International Systems & Controls Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Though parent companies are not liable on contracts made by their subsidiaries by virtue of owning them, piercing of the corporate veil is allowed and the parent company may be held liable if it perpetrated fraud on or caused severe injustice to another party through control of a subsidiary or if parent directs business activities of subsidiary to such a degree that it becomes agent of the parent.
Document Preview: Food processing firm brought action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages for alleged breach of subsidiary's contract to supply and install equipment in connection with construction of potato processing plant. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Patrick Dooley, J., entered judgment for firm, and corporations appealed. The Court of Appeals, Thornton, J., held that: (1) in such action in which firm contended that it had standing to bring the action because construction contractor acted as firm's agent in making contract with subsidiary, issue whether there had been agency relationship between general contractor and firm was for jury; (2) evidence warranted finding that parent corporation could be held liable under alter ego theory or under theory that subsidiary was parent's agent; (3) certain instruction was not a comment on probative value of evidence, but, rather, was an instruction that an offer could be accepted by performance; (4) mere allegation, by way of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hutchinson v. Brotman-Sherman Theatres, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: There was sufficient evidence to hold one corporation responsible for obligations of another on contract for closed circuit exhibition of heavyweight championship fight, where latter corporation had no assets aside from stationery and former corporation performed all exhibition activities without any indicium of legal obligation to do so and record demonstrated requisite unity of interest in ownership upon which to consider individuality of latter having ceased, and dissipating fiction of separate existence under circumstances which would sanction fraud and promote injustice.
Document Preview: Assignee of exclusive telecast rights for heavyweight championship fight brought suit for damages for breach of agreement by defendant exhibitors. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Charles E. Freeman, J. P., granted judgment to plaintiff, awarding compensatory and punitive damages, and defendants appealed. The Appellate Court, Hartman, P. J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in refusing to dismiss action on basis of release of holder of exclusive telecast rights for fight; (2) issue of whether trial court abused its discretion in denying leave to file counterclaim could not be reviewed where no counterclaim was ever presented to court; (3) absence of service of process did not affect in personam jurisdiction by court over one corporate defendant; (4) evidence was sufficient to hold such corporate defendant responsible for obligations of another; (5) trial court had right to reject defendants' version of the agreement; (6) trial court could disbelieve defendants' theory that...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kellytown Co. v. Williams
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where all dealings of president of coal excavation corporations were in corporate capacity, where president of excavation corporations never gave management company president any reason to believe he was dealing as individual and not as corporation president, where all various agreements were prepared by lawyers for management company, and where there was no evidence that president of coal excavation corporations personally received or used any money received by corporation, there was no basis to set aside corporate entity and hold president of coal excavation corporations personally liable for breach of contract.
Document Preview: Management company filed complaint in equity to pierce corporate veil of two coal excavation companies and to hold president of such companies personally liable for damages for breach of contract. The Court of Common Pleas, Clearfield County, No. 74-19, Cherry, J., entered judgment in favor of management company, pierced corporate veil of coal excavation companies and held president of such corporations personally liable for damages, and president of corporations appealed. The Superior Court, No. 1071 April Term, 1978, Brosky, J., held that evidence adduced at trial was legally insufficient to allow court to pierce corporate veils of coal excavation corporations and hold president of such corporations personally liable on contracts. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kellytown Co. v. Williams
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where person in all his dealings with management company acted in his disclosed capacity as president of coal excavation corporations, where contracts were expressly binding on management company and two excavation corporations only, and where fraud or other illegality was neither alleged or proved, trial court improperly pierced corporate veil of excavating company and held president of such companies personally liable on contracts.
Document Preview: Management company filed complaint in equity to pierce corporate veil of two coal excavation companies and to hold president of such companies personally liable for damages for breach of contract. The Court of Common Pleas, Clearfield County, No. 74-19, Cherry, J., entered judgment in favor of management company, pierced corporate veil of coal excavation companies and held president of such corporations personally liable for damages, and president of corporations appealed. The Superior Court, No. 1071 April Term, 1978, Brosky, J., held that evidence adduced at trial was legally insufficient to allow court to pierce corporate veils of coal excavation corporations and hold president of such corporations personally liable on contracts. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Roepke v. Western Nat. Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Where driver of van, who died as result of van-truck collision, was president and sole shareholder of corporation which was named insured under no-fault insurance coverages on corporation's six vehicles, including van he was driving, driver treated insured vehicles as his own and used them for family purposes, and neither he nor his household owned any other vehicles, and where no shareholder or creditor would be adversely affected by ruling, corporate veil would be pierced to hold that driver was an "insured" under corporate automobile liability policies and thus stacking of no-fault insurance coverages under policies would be allowed. M.S.A. §§ 65B.41-65B.71, 65B.47, subd. 4(a).
Document Preview: Automobile liability insurer appealed from order entered by the District Court, Rice County, Urban J. Steimann, J., granting partial summary judgment in favor of driver's surviving spouse and minor children to allow stacking of no-fault insurance coverages on six vehicles owned and insured by corporation wholly-owned by driver in action arising out of fatal van-truck collision. The Supreme Court, Scott, J., held that where driver of van was president and sole shareholder of named insured corporation, vehicles insured were used as family vehicles, neither driver nor his household owned any other vehicles, and no shareholder or creditor would be adversely affected, corporate veil would be pierced to hold that driver was the insured under corporate policies and thus to allow stacking of no-fault insurance coverages under policies. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gallagher v. Reconco Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Sole stockholder, as well as corporation, could be held liable for alleged breach of contract occurring when corporation discontinued construction job without completing it and after corporation had obtained all of the funds by submission of false affidavits in light of evidence that corporation was undercapitalized considering nature and magnitude of the corporate undertaking, corporation and sole stockholder did not observe corporate formalities, sole stockholder did not regard corporate entity seriously, and in light of evidence of some element of unfairness, something akin to fraud or deception in sole stockholder's method of obtaining money from bank by falsely swearing under oath on contractor's affidavits. S.H.A. ch. 32, §§ 157.50, 157.60a, 157.60b.
Document Preview: Homeowner brought action against corporation and its sole stockholder to recover damages for alleged breach of contract when corporation discontinued working on construction job without completing it and after corporation had obtained all of funds by submission of false affidavits. The Circuit Court, Cook County, George J. Schaller, P. J., determined that under facts of case individual stockholder as well as corporation, which was insolvent, should be liable, and stockholder appealed. The Appellate Court, Romiti, J., held that sole stockholder, as well as corporation, could be held liable for breach of contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Rokowsky v. Gordon
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Where prospective vendors of realty justifiably considered individual defendants to be principals in sales transaction and considered the corporate purchaser as a device of convenience to hold title temporarily as straw or conduit, the individual defendants were not protected from whatever liability there might be under contracts by reason of use of the corporation as a nominee.
Document Preview: One of prospective purchasers of commercial realty sued to recover on promissory note issued in the course of the deterioration of the transaction. In a second case and a third case, owners of beneficial interest in 26 of 28 parcels to be sold and executrices of estate of owner of the other two parcels claimed damages for breach of contract against corporation, the nominal purchaser, and its disclosed principals, and by amendment, they also sought damages for fraud in inducement of the agreement. In the second and third cases, the defendants counterclaimed for fraudulent misrepresentation. The District Court, Skinner, J., held that: (1) where prospective vendors justifiably considered individual defendants to be principals in sales transaction and considered the corporate purchaser as a device of convenience to hold title temporarily as straw or conduit, the individual defendants were not protected from whatever liability there might be under contracts by reason of use of the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ross Industries, Inc. v. M/V Gretke Oldendorff
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Where limited West German partnership formed purportedly separate corporation as sham to hold title to vessel and to enter into charter party agreements, and purported bareboat charter agreement between the partnership and the corporation provided that the corporation was to obtain prior approval of the partnership for all important legal transactions and for all matters exceeding normal business transactions involving the vessel, presumption of corporate separateness did not apply to the partnership and the corporation, and thus both were equally responsible for contracts entered into by either entity.
Document Preview: Shipper brought action against limited West German partnership, which owned vessel, and purportedly separate corporation, which was created to hold title to vessels and to enter into charter party agreements. The District Court, Robert M. Parker, District Judge, held that: (1) where limited West German partnership formed purportedly separate corporation as sham to hold title to vessel and to enter into charter party agreements, presumption of corporate separateness did not apply to the partnership and the corporation, and thus both were equally responsible for contracts entered into by either entity; (2) where vessel owner authorized time charterer to issue bills of lading, subsequent shipment contract became that of the ship, and the owner was bound by terms of bill of lading issued by master, and thus defendants were jointly and severally liable for damages incurred by shipper as result of breach of bill of lading contract in connection with deviation in delivery; (3) carrier...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: A. W. Fiur Co., Inc. v. Ataka & Co., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Even though contract appointing American firm as sales agent or representative for sale of fabrics manufactured by Japanese company was not executed by Japanese company but by its American subsidiary, parent corporation might be held liable for breach of such contract on proof that practically all dealings under contract were with parent, not subsidiary, and that parent controlled the subsidiary's actions.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by a firm acting as a sales agent or representative for the sale of fabrics manufactured by a Japanese corporation, alleging that the Japanese corporation had breached a sales agency contract. The Supreme Court, New York County, Louis Grossman, J., entered summary judgment against plaintiff, and it appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, Fein, J., held, inter alia, that triable issues of fact remained with respect to whether the Japanese corporation could be held liable for a contract technically executed by its American subsidiary. Modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Morgan Bros., Inc. v. Haskell Corp., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Where, through the conduct of various "Hanson's" interests in Arizona, purchaser of flanges was led to believe that it was dealing with a single business enterprise by seller's sole correspondent who repeatedly referred to "this company," "our position," "our failure," and the like, court did not err, in third-party claim for damages for defective product, in giving judgment to purchaser against "Hanson's, Inc.", even though the quotation, acceptance, delivery and invoicing was in the name of "Hanson's Pipe."
Document Preview: General contractor brought action for specific performance of contract to assemble and deliver gas metering skids; defendant asserted a third-party complaint against its supplier claiming damages for defective components. The Superior Court, Skagit County, Harry Follman, J., entered judgment against third-party defendant, and third-party defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Williams, J., held that: (1) court did not err in giving judgment to purchaser against Hanson's, Inc., even though the quotation, acceptance, delivery and invoicing was in the name of Hanson's Pipe; (2) trial court did not abuse its discretion in permitting introduction of evidence on a theory of disregard of corporate entity which had not been pleaded, or in denying a continuance; and (3) the insertion of clause on reverse side of invoice which materially limited buyer's remedies and which was received by buyer following delivery of goods, did not meet test of good faith...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Schnucks Twenty-Five, Inc. v. Bettendorf
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Corporate officer, who was responsible for organization of corporation and owned 95% to 98% of its stock, could not use corporation for purpose of evading his obligations under covenant which was within agreement to sell stock of grocery business and under which he agreed not to compete under his surname in regard to retail food business in certain area.
Document Preview: Plaintiff sought injunctive relief on basis of contention that defendants' use of certain surname in connection with grocery business was an appropriation of a property right belonging to plaintiff, and plaintiff also sought damages for conversion of its property rights, damages for tortious interference with its contract rights, declaratory judgment that use of certain names in advertising or identification was equivalent to the use of such surname and to have defendants enjoined from further use of phonetic facsimiles of the surname in connection with grocery business. The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, George W. Cloyd, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Dowd, P. J., held that: (1) it was sufficiently established that signed copy of original agreement to sell stock of grocery business was unavailable; (2) covenant, under which seller promised that he would not engage in grocery business under his surname, effected...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Thames & Co. v. Eicher
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Where purchasers of house knew only of corporation's agent and not of corporate builder-vendor during all negotiations until closing, and evidence showed that corporation was no more than alter ego of agent in that she held all stock in company, she furnished construction funds for corporation which appeared to be without substantial capital, corporation held no regular meetings, there were no minutes pertaining to its operation, and agent treated corporation almost as though it did not exist, trial court did not err in looking past and beyond corporate structure and allowing agent to be held individually, along with corporation, liable for defective house.
Document Preview: Purchasers of new house brought action for breach of implied warranty against corporate builder-vendor and its sole shareholder and agent. The Circuit Court, Warren County, Ben Guider, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers in amount of $50,000, and vendor and its sole shareholder appealed.
