The Supreme Court, Broom, J., held that: (1) where purchasers knew only of agent and not of corporate builder-vendor during all negotiations until closing, and evidence showed that corporation was no more than alter ego of agent, trial court did not err in looking past and beyond corporate structure and allowing agent to be held individually, along with corporation, liable for defective house; (2) where there was no evidence whatever as to quantum of moving and living expense damages suffered by purchasers of defective house, instruction allowing jury to consider such expenses in calculating damages was error; (3) where review of evidence of witnesses who testified as to what it would...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re County Green Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Amendment of contract with contractor for development of apartment project taking into account work in place was not sufficient reason to set aside corporate entity of contractor by inferring basic injustice from unconscionably low contract price, notwithstanding existence of some common members of contractor and owner of property.
Document Preview: On appeal by mechanics lienors from judgment of bankruptcy court holding invalid liens on certain property owned by bankrupt debtor, the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, James C. Turk, Chief Judge, 438 F.Supp. 701, reversed and remanded, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) decision to pierce corporate veil of general contractor depended largely on resolution of questions of fact, and thus decision of bankruptcy court not to pierce corporate veil should not have been reversed unless clearly erroneous; (2) overlapping ownership of bankrupt debtor and general contractor was not sufficient reason in and of itself to pierce corporate veil of contractor; (3) amendment of contract with contractor which took over when first contractor defaulted to take into account work in place did not provide reason to set aside corporate entity of contractor by inferring basic injustice from unconscionably low contract price; and (4) decision...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: In re County Green Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Fact that some of payments were not made from owner of property to contractor on apartment development project, but by others on owner's behalf, was not sufficient to justify drastic remedy of piercing corporate veil of contractor.
Document Preview: On appeal by mechanics lienors from judgment of bankruptcy court holding invalid liens on certain property owned by bankrupt debtor, the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, James C. Turk, Chief Judge, 438 F.Supp. 701, reversed and remanded, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) decision to pierce corporate veil of general contractor depended largely on resolution of questions of fact, and thus decision of bankruptcy court not to pierce corporate veil should not have been reversed unless clearly erroneous; (2) overlapping ownership of bankrupt debtor and general contractor was not sufficient reason in and of itself to pierce corporate veil of contractor; (3) amendment of contract with contractor which took over when first contractor defaulted to take into account work in place did not provide reason to set aside corporate entity of contractor by inferring basic injustice from unconscionably low contract price; and (4) decision...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lawton v. Gorman Furniture Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Fact that 50-year-old corporation dealing in furniture was a wholly owned subsidiary of another furniture business and that sole stockholder of the latter was president of the former was insufficient to pierce the corporate veil for purpose of holding subsidiary liable for parent's breach of agreement that it would not sell any bedroom furniture unless it first referred orders therefor to its lessor, which sold only bedroom furniture and accessories; it was not wrong for subsidiary to fill orders for bedroom furniture as the wrong was a failure of the parent to first notify the lessor.
Document Preview: One furniture business, which leased adjacent building to another furniture business, brought action to recover for breach of provision restricting lessee's sales of bedroom furniture unless orders therefor were first referred to lessor, which sold only bedroom furniture and accessories. The Oakland Circuit Court, William John Beer, J., rendered judgment for plaintiffs, and defendants appeal of right. The Court of Appeals, Allen, J., held that: (1) where 50-year-old corporation was wholly owned by lessee and sole stockholder of latter was president of the subsidiary, such relationship was not of itself sufficient to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold subsidiary liable for filling orders for bedroom furniture, which orders had not been referred to lessor; (2) proper measure of recovery was not profits gained by the lessee but profits lost by lessor; (3) where proof that lessor had been damaged was clear but proof of the amount or degree of damage was inadequate and case was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Baird & Warner, Inc. v. Addison Indus. Park, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that stockholder owns 100 percent of the stock is not sufficient to entitle court to pierce corporate veil and hold stockholder liable on a contract made by corporation.
Document Preview: Real estate broker, which had entered into brokerage contract with corporation, brought action to recover against corporation, its president and second corporation, which purchased first corporation's stock, on basis of claims for tortious interference with contractual relations, breach of brokerage contract, quantum meruit and fraud. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Daniel P. Coman, J., ruled that all counts within broker's complaint were barred by prior judgment and that all counts against second corporation and certain other counts were barred by statute of limitations, and broker appealed. The Appellate Court, First District, Romiti, J., held that: (1) affirmed judgment rendered against broker on certain counts within prior complaint was res judicata barring broker from relitigating issues involved in such counts; (2) fact that broker had voluntary dismissal entered on count within prior complaint did not prevent summary judgment from barring broker from having issues raised...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Carey v. National Oil Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Although Bahamian corporation was a subsidiary of a New York corporation, it was a separate entity, and court would not "pierce the corporate veil" in favor of those who created that veil for purposes of rendering Libyan Arab Republic and corporation wholly owned by Libyan government amenable to suit in United States court on claims arising out of contracts between Bahamian corporation and Libyan corporation. 28 U.S.C.A. §§ 1602–1611.
Document Preview: New York corporation and its assignee brought suit against Libyan Arab Republic and corporation wholly owned by Libyan government seeking to recover damages for alleged breaches of contracts for sale of crude oil and for overcharges on charter parties. After action was removed from the New York Supreme Court, the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., 453 F.Supp. 1097, dismissed case on jurisdictional grounds, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals held that neither Libyan Arab Republic nor corporation wholly owned by Libyan government was amenable to suit in the United States court on any claim arising out of contracts between Bahamian subsidiary of New York corporation and Libyan corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Culinary Workers and Bartenders Union No. 596 Health and Welfare Trust v. Gateway Cafe, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: On record showing that persons in control of corporation repudiated agreements and began dissolution which left corporation without single asset, and that new corporation with substantially identical ownership, operating identical business with identical employees in identical location received all assets, individuals were liable as such for performance of terms of challenged agreement, it being appropriate to disregard corporate entity of first-mentioned corporation in order to enforce obligation.
Document Preview: An action for unpaid contributions to a trust fund was consolidated with a declaratory judgment action, and the Superior Court, King County, Janice Niemi, J., declared that an agreement was binding and enforceable against individual defendants. Defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Hamilton, J., held that: (1) in view of the fact that Congress in enacting the Employee Retirement Income Security Act attempted to address problems of divided loyalties but also provided that nothing in such provision should be construed to prohibit a fiduciary from serving as such in addition to being an officer, employee or representative of a party in interest, some degree of collateral interest is permissible under such Act; (2) mere financial pressure which worked to bring about agreement is insufficient to establish economic duress or business compulsion; (3) where stock purchase agreement under which individuals bought a corporation provided defendants right, in event of default, to enter and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dawson v. G. Malina, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: In view of testimony and documentary evidence establishing that corporate name was merely name used for seller's art gallery and that, although there was incorporation, there were no corporate minutes kept nor meetings of board of directors held since date of incorporation, and that only one corporate franchise tax report had been filed, and in view of absence of evidence to indicate that individual defendant observed corporate formalities in operating art gallery, corporate veil was pierced and individual defendant was individually liable for amount found to be due to buyer for breach of warranty in sale of items from gallery.
Document Preview: In a suit for rescission of purchase of objects of Chinese art, or, alternatively, for damages for breach of warranty, the District Court, Bonsal, J., held that: (1) the standard to be applied in determining whether objects of art were in accord with descriptions furnished by defendant sellers, for purposes of New York General Business Law sections concerning express warranties as contrasted with expressions of opinion, was whether representations furnished the buyer by the seller with respect to each object could be said to have had a reasonable basis in fact at the time that the representations were made, and (2) as to certain items, under the evidence, there was a reasonable basis in fact for representations made by the seller concerning the periods of time when the items were made, but the plaintiff established a lack of reasonable basis in fact on the part of the seller in attributing certain other items to certain periods of time. Judgment for plaintiff as to certain items,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Grayson v. Nordic Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Mere breach of contract by corporation did not, without more, justify disregarding corporate entity.
Document Preview: Action was instituted for breach of contract for repair of home. The Superior Court, King County, Frank J. Eberharter, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and individual defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Dore, J., held that: (1) piercing corporate veil and holding individual defendants liable was error in action for breach of sales contract where evidence established that individual defendants conscientiously kept corporation's affairs separate from their own personal affairs and where actions of individual defendants did not constitute an unfair or deceptive trade practice so as to justify disregarding the corporate existence, and (2) in absence of evidence establishing a consumer protection violation, imposition of attorney fees on authority of Consumer Protection Act was improper. Reversed and remanded with instructions. Andersen, Acting C. J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Grayson v. Nordic Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil and holding individual defendants liable was error in action for breach of sales contract where evidence established that individual defendants conscientiously kept corporation's affairs separate from their own personal affairs and where actions of individual defendants did not constitute an unfair or deceptive trade practice so as to justify disregarding the corporate existence. RCWA 19.86.020.
Document Preview: Action was instituted for breach of contract for repair of home. The Superior Court, King County, Frank J. Eberharter, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and individual defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Dore, J., held that: (1) piercing corporate veil and holding individual defendants liable was error in action for breach of sales contract where evidence established that individual defendants conscientiously kept corporation's affairs separate from their own personal affairs and where actions of individual defendants did not constitute an unfair or deceptive trade practice so as to justify disregarding the corporate existence, and (2) in absence of evidence establishing a consumer protection violation, imposition of attorney fees on authority of Consumer Protection Act was improper. Reversed and remanded with instructions. Andersen, Acting C. J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Service Iron Foundry, Inc. v. M. A. Bell Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: In action against manufacturer and selling agent to recover damages for breach of warranty arising from purchase of a pollution control unit for use at plaintiff's foundry, evidence as to whether selling agent expressly warranted device and as to whether corporate manufacturer was alter ego of selling agent was sufficient for jury.
Document Preview: Plaintiff buyer brought action against manufacturer and its selling agent to recover damages for breach of warranty arising from purchase of a pollution control unit for use at its foundry. The Sedgwick District Court, B. Mack Bryant, J., directed verdict in favor of defendant selling agent and entered judgment against defendant manufacturer, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Abbott, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in excluding evidence tending to show an independent warranty by selling agent; (2) evidence as to alleged independent warranty by selling agent and as to whether selling agent was alter ego of manufacturer was sufficient for jury, and (3) trial court correctly instructed jury concerning damages which included damages for special circumstances as well as incidental and consequential damages. Judgment affirmed as to plaintiff and reversed as to defendant selling agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Amsted Industries, Inc. v. Pollak Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Single incident in which sole shareholder instructed his secretary to use close corporation's check to pay for a machine purchased from third party by related close corporation he also owned and controlled and shareholder's failure to know which corporation issued the check for machine did not establish any indiscriminate use of corporate funds so as to render shareholder personally liable for price of machine.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate buyer of machinery, its sole shareholder and related corporation seeking recovery of price of machinery delivered pursuant to contracts. From an order of the Circuit Court, Cook County, Daniel P. Coman, J., granting plaintiff's motion for summary judgment against all three defendants, individual defendant appealed. The Appellate Court, Simon, J., held that: (1) that sole shareholder controlled and dominated two corporations and was their sole source of equity financing did not render him personally liable for cost of machinery; (2) that two corporations may have been operated as one corporation did not establish shareholder's liability for debt and (3) factual issue existed as to whether corporate buyer and other related corporation were mere alter egos of shareholder precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Brunswick Corp. v. Waxman
Court: United States District Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Where there was no misappropriation of corporate assets of profits by two incorporators of no-asset corporation, which acted as signatory on sales contracts for purchase of bowling alley equipment, the incorporators could not be held personally liable on the purchase contracts under New York's instrumentality rule.
Document Preview: Seller of bowling alley equipment brought diversity action against officer and shareholder of corporate purchaser to recover balance due on the equipment. The District Court, Bartels, J., held that: (1) although neither purchaser nor separate bowling alley corporations had any assets or operated the equipment, the corporate veil would not be pierced where at time of sale seller knew that land and buildings on which lanes were to be erected were owned by the incorporators and that purchaser was a no-asset corporation and was on constructive notice that bowling alley operations were being conducted by incorporators individually and incorporators' actions did not cause seller any loss or defeat its expectations with regard to generation of profit from the equipment, and (2) incorporators realized an unjust enrichment by claiming on their personal tax returns the corporation's depreciation and other deductions and losses attributable to operation of the equipment furnished...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Japan Petroleum Co. (Nigeria) Ltd. v. Ashland Oil, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In diversity action wherein Nigerian corporation sued Kentucky corporation and two of its wholly owned subsidiaries, both Delaware corporations, for breach of contract, question of whether subsidiary of two Delaware corporations, which entered into contract with Nigerian corporation, and which was not named as a defendant, was an agency of defendant so that defendants could be held liable could be decided under general principles of corporate and agency law, which did not vary significantly from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.
Document Preview: Nigerian corporation sued Kentucky corporation and two of its wholly owned subsidiaries, both Delaware corporations, for breach of contract. The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to join subsidiary of two Delaware corporations, a Nigerian corporation, as an indispensable party. The District Court, Caleb M. Wright, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) there was no agency relationship between subsidiary and named defendants, and (2) where contract had been entered into with subsidiary and Nigerian corporation, where there was no agency relationship between named defendant and subsidiary corporation, and where, therefore, no judgment could be entered against defendants, subsidiary Nigerian corporation was indispensable party and case would be dismissed for failure to join it. Submit order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Thermothrift Industries, Inc. v. Mono-Therm Insulation Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: In suit brought by buyer against corporate seller, and others, for breach of contract to sell an insulation-manufacturing plant, for fraud, and for conspiracy to interfere with the contract, the motions on behalf of two corporate defendants, other than the seller, to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction would be overruled, since the key individuals involved raised common denominators among the three corporations, and since the similarities between their stockholders, officers and directors led to the conclusion that there existed the unity of ownership and interest necessary to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by buyer against seller, and others, for breach of contract to sell an insulation-manufacturing plant, for fraud, and for conspiracy to interfere with the contract. On defense motions to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction, the District Court, Ballantine, J., held that: (1) the exercise of long-arm jurisdiction over the corporate seller was not unreasonable, nor did maintenance of the suit offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice, since the seller committed numerous acts in Kentucky, all of which were freely and intentionally done, since the cause of action arose out of those acts, and since defendants' involvement with Kentucky, measured by the minimum contacts concept, clearly compelled the court to extend jurisdiction over the seller; (2) the two individual defendants, who were directors of all three corporate defendants, had sufficiently relevant contacts with Kentucky to invoke the three-prong test regarding the constitutional...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Smith-Hearron v. Frazier, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Doctrine of piercing of the corporate veil was correctly imposed in action by partnership on contract for architectural services performed against individual who was president and sole stockholder of corporation which never issued shares of stock which had board of directors which performed no functions and held no meetings, which had no net worth, and which had no property other than 13 acres of land which corporation conveyed to second corporation created for purpose of construction of housing project on 13 acres, in light of transactions in which corporation president was issued 400 of second corporation's 2,000 shares in return for services performed, second corporation then paid note owed by first corporation on 13 acres, and first corporation was then dissolved. LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B; LSA-C.C. arts. 435, 437.
Document Preview: Partnership brought action against individual who was president and sole stockholder of corporation for value of architectural services performed under written contract with corporation. The Eighth Judicial District Court, Parish of Winn, Hiram J. Wright, J., rendered personal judgment of $30,000 against president of corporation, and president appealed. The Court of Appeal, Marvin, J., held that doctrine of piercing of the corporate veil was correctly imposed with respect to corporation which never issued shares of stock, which had board of directors which performed no functions and held no meetings, which had no net worth, and which had no property other than 13 acres of land which corporation conveyed to second corporation created for purpose of construction of housing project on 13 acres, in light of transactions in which appellant was issued 400 of second corporation's 2,000 shares in return for services performed, second corporation then paid note owed by first corporation...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union v. Penntech Papers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maine, Northern Division.
Headnote: Some degree of moral culpability on part of parent corporation must be shown to establish liability for a contract of a subsidiary, which rule holds true even when subsidiary is found to be alter ego or instrumentality of the parent.
Document Preview: Action was brought pursuant to the Labor Management Relations Act by unions to compel corporation, which through its subsidiary had acquired all of paper company's outstanding capital stock, and which was not a signatory to collective bargaining agreement, to arbitrate certain provisions of agreement entered into by unions and paper company. The District Court, Bownes, J., sitting by designation, held that although there was sufficient integration between paper company and acquiring parent corporation to challenge relationship between the two corporations, challenge seeking to pierce the corporate veil and require arbitration had to fail where there was no fraud or misrepresentation by either paper company or acquiring corporation as to scope and application of collective bargaining agreement. Motions to compel arbitration denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Coastal States Trading, Inc. v. Zenith Nav. S. A.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: When parent corporation so dominates and controls affairs of subsidiary that subsidiary cannot be said to have independent existence or will of its own, then courts may pierce corporate veil of subsidiary and bind parent to contractual obligations incurred by subsidiary effectively at parent's behest, or, conversely, subsidiary may, under some circumstances, be held bound to obligations undertaken by its parent; such disregard of separate corporate trappings of subsidiary may be appropriate if it is found that subsidiary was expressly functioning as agent for parent or if subsidiary was merely "instrumentality" of parent.
Document Preview: Delaware consignee brought diversity action against Panamanian vessel owner to recover value of cargo of oil lost when vessel disappeared at sea. The District Court, Motley, J., held that: (1) although the vessel owner was not a signatory to a charter party containing an arbitration clause executed between the subcharterer of the vessel and the consignee, the charter party was incorporated by reference into the bill of lading and the arbitration clause could be enforced against the consignee by the vessel owner, but (2) under the New York attachment statute, the vessel owner was a citizen of the United States, even though it maintained its principal place of business in New York, and its assets in the state could be attached. Action stayed pending completion of arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jones v. Cranman's Sporting Goods
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Corporate fiction will be disregarded where corporation has overextended its privileges in use of corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud or evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Buyer of rifle brought action against seller and corporation, whose subsidiary fully guaranteed rifle, to recover for injuries sustained when rifle exploded. The Superior Court, Chatham County, Frank S. Cheatham, Jr., J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Quillian, P. J., held that: (1) evidence raised factual issue as to whether rifle buyer gave notice of breach of warranty to seller and issue as to seller's negligence in its inspection of rifle, precluding summary judgment for seller and (2) evidence that corporation which fully guaranteed rifle was wholly owned subsidiary of corporate defendant raised issue as to corporate defendant's liability. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Turnkey Proposals, Inc. v. Rose
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Where it was clear that companies involved in various turnkey projects had no clear-cut lines of demarcation between them and were used by individual defendant as his alter ego, equity mandated that corporate veil be pierced in action to recover for breach of contract.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract. The Supreme Court, Nassau County, entered judgment in favor of plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that (1) where companies involved in various turnkey projects had no clearcut lines of demarcation between them and were used by individual defendant as his alter ego, equity mandated that corporate veil be pierced; (2) evidence supported finding that agreement provided for fee in sum of 5% of selling prices of projects as well as findings that there was no oral partnership agreement and that plaintiff did not breach its contract; (3) even if recovery were to be based upon quantum meruit, where there was substantial performance on part of plaintiff, proper measure of damages would be the contract price, and (4) inasmuch as it was possible to ascertain with precision the date on which cause of action accrued, interest should be computed from that date. Judgment modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hanson Southwest Corp. v. Dal-Mac Const. Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: There must be some ground in addition to mere unity of financial interest, ownership and control for a court to treat corporate entities as one and make each responsible for the torts and contracts of the other; such additional ground turns on whether there is good faith and honesty in the use of a subsidiary corporate entity for legitimate ends, and, generally, it is determined by whether the subsidiary corporate entity is so controlled and manipulated by the parent for the parent's own interests that it prejudices innocent third parties or is in contravention of the public welfare.
Document Preview: Contractor, which contracted with corporation to construct shopping center and which stopped working on center because contractor had not been paid, brought action to recover against corporate owner for breach of contract and to recover against owner's parent corporation on alter-ego theory. The 134th District Court, Dallas County, Charles E. Long, Jr., J., rendered judgment for contractor, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Akin, J., held that: (1) parent corporation was not alter ego of corporate owner so as to permit recovery against parent for owner's breach of contract; (2) contract did not require that contractor's draw requests be approved by an inspecting architect unless financing was obtained through lender and it required an architect's approval; (3) exhibit, which contained record of bills received by contractor for construction project, was not admissible as a business record; (4) damages award was unsupported by the evidence; (5)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hanson Southwest Corp. v. Dal-Mac Const. Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Even if parent corporation guaranteed purchase money loan for shopping center site, parent controlled flow of funds to subsidiary, parent owned all of subsidiary's stock and representations were made that center was owned by parent or number of related companies, parent was not "alter-ego" of subsidiary so as to permit contractor, which contracted with subsidiary to construct shopping center, to recover against parent for subsidiary's breach of contract where subsidiary status was not employed to defraud parent's existing creditors, to evade existing obligation, to circumvent statute, to achieve or perpetuate monopoly or to protect crimes.
Document Preview: Contractor, which contracted with corporation to construct shopping center and which stopped working on center because contractor had not been paid, brought action to recover against corporate owner for breach of contract and to recover against owner's parent corporation on alter-ego theory. The 134th District Court, Dallas County, Charles E. Long, Jr., J., rendered judgment for contractor, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Akin, J., held that: (1) parent corporation was not alter ego of corporate owner so as to permit recovery against parent for owner's breach of contract; (2) contract did not require that contractor's draw requests be approved by an inspecting architect unless financing was obtained through lender and it required an architect's approval; (3) exhibit, which contained record of bills received by contractor for construction project, was not admissible as a business record; (4) damages award was unsupported by the evidence; (5)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Miller & Miller Auctioneers, Inc. v. Mersch
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Even if agent was acting at auction only as agent of corporation, rather than as agent of individual, individual could be held liable to auctioneer for breach of sales contract, where individual was using corporation as facade for himself to wrongfully purchase oil drilling rig by spurious check which, at time of signing and delivering to agent and at time check was presented to auctioneer, was known by individual to be spurious check in that bank account did not have funds therein with which such check could have been honored and where evidence established that corporation was mere alter ego of individual so that corporate entity could be disregarded.
Document Preview: Auctioneer brought action against individual and corporation which bought oil drilling rig at public auction sale. The District Court, Daugherty, Chief Judge, held that: (1) auctioneer's resale of oil drilling rig after auctioneer failed in its efforts to cause buyers to honor and pay check complied with statutory requirements; (2) auctioneer exercised required due care and reasonable diligence to ascertain agency of buyers' agent and scope of his authority; (3) even if agent was acting as agent only of corporation, circumstances were appropriate for piercing corporate veil so as to hold individual buyer liable, and (4) auctioneer was entitled to recover attorney fees. Judgment in favor of auctioneer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lyons v. Stevenson
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Where evidence in action for recovery of commission allegedly due on sale of mortgage company showed that corporate president was dominant and controlling shareholder of company and evidence showing, inter alia, that agreement to pay commission was accepted in belief that president was signing agreement as an individual and that he regarded himself personally obligated to meet terms of agreement raised inference that failure to disregard corporate entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice, trial court did not err in piercing corporate veil and holding corporate president liable for commission.
Document Preview: Real estate broker brought action to recover commission allegedly due on sale of mortgage company. The Alameda County Superior Court, Robert L. Bostick, J., rendered judgment for broker, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeal, Bray, J., held that real estate broker who was retained to sell mortgage company not its stock and who did not participate in negotiations leading to transfer of stock was entitled to recover commission even though he was not licensed as a corporate securities broker; that evidence supported trial court's finding that plaintiff did not act in capacity of a securities broker; and that trial court properly pierced corporate veil to hold president of mortgage company liable for commission. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Edwin K. Williams & Co., Inc. v. Edwin K. Williams & Co.-East
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: In action brought by trade name licensor against licensee and corporate owner of licensee to recover, inter alia, for breach of contract and copyright and trade name infringement, trial court erred in failing to treat licensee and corporate owner of licensee as one entity, in view of fact that between licensee and corporate owner there was intermingling of transactions and employees, a disregard of formal separateness of two corporations, common stock ownership and common directors and officers, transfer of most of assets and business to later formed corporation, representations to public of single identity, and moral culpability and threat of injustice.
Document Preview: Licensor brought action against licensee and corporate owner of licensee seeking, inter alia, damages and injunctive relief for breach of agreement between parties, interference with contractual business relations, and copyright and trademark infringement, and licensee counterclaimed, alleging antitrust violations and invalidity of licensor's copyrights. The action was instituted in state court and removed to federal district court. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, David W. Williams, 377 F.Supp. 418, entered judgment for licensors, and defendants appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Solomon, District Judge, held that agreement between parties created relationship of trade name licensee and licensor; that licensee could not assert lack of quality control to invalidate trade name license; that account books containing several pages of instructions were entitled to copyright protections; that licensee was guilty of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: 68th Street Apts., Inc. v. Lauricella
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division.
Headnote: Where parties undertook to arrange contract between their two corporate entities, they accepted benefits and assumed burdens of limitation on their respective personal liabilities and corporate form was not to be disregarded.
Document Preview: Two stockholders in close corporation brought cross actions arising out of the cessation of construction on an apartment building owned by the corporation. General contractor, controlled by one of the stockholders, brought action against the other stockholder. The Superior Court, Law Division, Gaulkin, J.S.C., held that the relationship of the principals was that of partners or coventurers; that where the principals formed the corporation for the purpose of constructing an apartment building, one principal's unreasonable refusal to continue the project rendered him liable to the other principal in damages; and that where the parties undertook to arrange a contract between their two corporate entities, they accepted the benefits and assumed the burdens of the limitation on their respective personal liabilities and the corporate form was not to be disregarded. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Unijax, Inc. v. Factory Ins. Ass'n
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Where subsidiary corporations which owned Louisiana property damaged by fire were not the "mere instrumentality" of parent corporation, parent could not recover on business interruption policy covering parent and subsidiaries on theory that parent was doing business through its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: Parent corporation brought action to recover on business interruption policy for fire loss to paper mill owned by subsidiaries. The Circuit Court, Duval County, Marion W. Gooding, J., entered final summary judgment for insurer and for agent engaged to procure business interruption policy for plaintiff and plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Boyer, C.J., held that the parent and its two subsidiaries being separate entities, and each separately insured under the same policy, each corporation was required to maintain its own action to recover for its own loss; that parent corporation was not doing business through its subsidiaries which were not the mere instrumentality of parent; that parent corporation was not the real party in interest; that insurer's agreement for prelitigation payment would not support parent's claim of estoppel in view of specific provision in the agreement against waiver or modification of any conditions or requirements of policy...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: T. G. I. Friday's, Inc. v. International Restaurant Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M. D. Louisiana.
Headnote: In the absence of evidence that two owners of two corporations ever disregarded the corporateness to use the corporations as mere agencies to conduct their own private business, alter ego theory would not be applied to find liability on the part of the owners for any breach of franchise agreement entered into by one of their corporations.
Document Preview: Corporation which operated restaurants under the name of T.G.I. Friday's' brought action against two individuals who owned corporation which had a franchise to operate one of those restaurants and a second corporation formed by those individuals which had opened a restaurant under the name of Ever Lovin Saturday's' to recover for alleged infringement of federal service mark and state service mark, for unfair competition, and for breach of contract. Second corporation and its two major stockholders filed action against the plaintiff seeking declaratory judgment that the corporation was not bound by the franchise agreement. The District Court, E. Gordon West, J., held that there was no likelihood of confusion between the mark T.G.I. Friday's' and the mark Ever Lovin Saturday's;' that the plaintiff had never acquired a proprietary interest in its Louisiana service mark Saturday's; that the defendants had not engaged...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pogue v. International Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Where defendant corporation, which appealed from judgment for plaintiff in action brought to recover for breach of franchise agreement, had ultimate authority and responsibility for activities of other defendant corporations, including corporation which executed franchise agreement, such other corporations, for purpose of such action, were not separate entities but were under defendant corporation's control.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover for breach of franchise agreement. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, Southern Division, Frank W. Wilson, Chief Judge, entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and plaintiff, and one defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Feikens, District Judge, held that corporation which executed franchise agreement and defendant corporation into which such corporation merged had sufficient contacts with Tennessee to warrant service of process under Tennessee long-arm statute on defendant corporation which appealed, that plaintiff failed to establish sufficient causal relationship between her economic injury and allegedly illegal tie-in arrangement to warrant award of treble damages, and that where plaintiff sold merchandise only on consignment at prices fixed as part of program of maintaining high quality of merchandise, plaintiff was not entitled to award of treble damages for alleged price-fixing. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Evergreen Plantation, Inc. v. Zunamon
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Certain members of two families, which owned 209,747 of 508,365 shares of corporation dissolved after a vote of 398,164 shares in favor of dissolution and only 38,976 shares against dissolution, were not "alter-ego" of corporation; thus, even if distinction between such members and partnership, which was formed by members and acquired corporation's interest in a timber-cutting contract through partnership's nominee, could be disregarded, members were "third party purchasers" of such interest for purpose of rule that action in lesion beyond moiety cannot succeed against third-party purchaser absent fraud or bad faith.
Document Preview: Seller and assignee of right to purchase brought suit to invalidate sale of timber for lesion beyond moiety. After remand, 291 So.2d 414, the Sixth Judicial District Court, Parish of Tensas, Cliff C. Adams, J., rendered judgment rejecting demands to set aside sale and awarded defendant expert witness fees, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeal, Second Circuit, Dennis, J., held that even if distinction between certain stockholders and partnership, which was formed by such stockholders and which acquired corporation's interest in timber-cutting contract through partnership's nominee, could be disregarded, stockholders were third party purchasers' of such interest for purpose of rule that action in lesion beyond moiety cannot succeed against third-party purchaser absent fraud or bad faith, that evidence did not warrant a finding of fraud or bad faith on part of such stockholders, that finding that value of timber sold did not twice exceed the price given was not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bart Arconti & Sons, Inc. v. Ames-Ennis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Corporate form of subcontractor, which had been held liable to general contractor in suit for breach of construction contracts, could not be disregarded and judgment entered against subcontractor's principals and two other corporations controlled by principals on basis that, inter alia, subcontractor had been permitted to become dormant while affairs of other corporations improved simultaneously, in absence of evidence of fraud or similar conduct.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by general contractor against subcontractor, subcontractor's principals, and two other corporations controlled by principals, for breach of three construction contracts and breach of modification of one of such contracts, and subcontractor counterclaimed for general contractor's alleged breach of contracts in failing to make certain payments. The Superior Court, Baltimore City, Albert L. Sklar, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff against all defendants, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Levine, J., held that evidence supported finding that subcontractor breached original construction contracts and that therefore general contractor was justified in withholding payments to subcontractor; but that, in absence of showing of fraud or similar conduct, corporate form could not be disregarded and judgment entered predicated on liability of subcontractor, which was corporation, to general contractor, against subcontractor's principals and two other...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Interocean Shipping Co. v. National Shipping & Trading Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In an appropriate situation, the corporate veil may be pierced and a party may be held bound to arbitrate as a signatory's alter ego.
Document Preview: On appeal from order entered in the Southern District of New York, Sylvester J. Ryan, J., granting vessel owner's petition pursuant to Federal Arbitration Act to compel arbitration of its claim for breach of a charter party following our remand, 462 F.2d 673, the Court of Appeals, Timbers, Circuit Judge, held (i) that district court's findings that there was a valid charter party which contained all essential terms were not clearly erroneous; (ii) that district court's findings that charter broker had authority to act for both the proposed charterer as well as the guarantor of the charter party were not clearly erroneous; and (iii) that, although the charterer was properly directed to proceed to arbitration, the district court erred in ordering the guarantor to arbitrate. Arbitration order affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Freeman v. Sturdivant Development Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where corporate assignee of option contracted with assignor to pay assignor additional $15,000 if during the term of the option or any extension thereof a firm financial commitment was obtained for construction of an apartment complex on the optioned property, and property was later leased to corporation having same president and secretary as the assignee, both corporations could be found liable for the additional $15,000 if firm financial commitment was obtained during an extension of the option and assignee and corporation to which the optioned property was thereafter leased were "one and the same."
Document Preview: Action was brought by assignor of option against assignee and another corporation to recover $15,000 allegedly due under assignment contract or, in the alternative, to recover in quantum meruit for services rendered, and defendants counterclaimed seeking damages for fraud. The Superior Court, Catawba County, Dennis J. Winner, J., denied defendants' motion for summary judgment, granted directed verdict for plaintiff on counterclaim, and granted directed verdict for plaintiff on contract claim against assignee but against plaintiff on quantum meruit claim against assignee and on both claims against the other defendant, and all parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, Arnold, J., held that with respect to assignor's contract with assignee whereby assignee was to pay assignor an additional $15,000 if during the term of the option or any extension thereof assignee obtained a firm financial commitment for the construction of an apartment complex on the optioned property, genuine issue...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Chengelis v. Cenco Instruments Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for breach of royalty payment contract entered into by plaintiff with subsidiary corporation where plaintiff entered into the contract which bound only the subsidiary notwithstanding knowledge of interrelation of the two corporations, and where there was no proof that corporate form of subsidiary was used by parent corporation to perpetrate a fraud or promote an injustice akin to fraud.
Document Preview: Action against a parent corporation for breach of a royalty contract entered into by plaintiff with a subsidiary corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, Weber, J., held that where parties deal at arm's length, represented by counsel, corporate veil cannot be removed merely to give a litigant an advantage at law; the court also held that parent corporation could not be held liable for breach of royalty payment contract entered into by plaintiff with subsidiary corporation where plaintiff entered into the contract which bound only the subsidiary notwithstanding knowledge of interrelation of the two corporations, and where there was no proof that corporate form of subsidiary was used by parent corporation to perpetrate a fraud or promote an injustice akin to fraud. Judgments for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Chengelis v. Cenco Instruments Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A party which knowingly limits its contractual relationship to one of two or more related corporate enterprises cannot successfully attack the validity of the entity with which it dealt without proof of misrepresentation or other unusual circumstances justifying the application of an estoppel.
Document Preview: Action against a parent corporation for breach of a royalty contract entered into by plaintiff with a subsidiary corporation. The United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, Weber, J., held that where parties deal at arm's length, represented by counsel, corporate veil cannot be removed merely to give a litigant an advantage at law; the court also held that parent corporation could not be held liable for breach of royalty payment contract entered into by plaintiff with subsidiary corporation where plaintiff entered into the contract which bound only the subsidiary notwithstanding knowledge of interrelation of the two corporations, and where there was no proof that corporate form of subsidiary was used by parent corporation to perpetrate a fraud or promote an injustice akin to fraud. Judgments for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Quickick, Inc. v. Quickick Intern.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Even though majority shareholder who owned 90% of corporation which was assigned rights to market concentrate and which was legally incorporated with $1,000 capitalization of which majority shareholder advanced $900 controlled corporation and was ultimate source of funds advanced to corporation and guaranteed all of its loans and most of its accounts payable, where the facts surrounding shareholder and corporation were known to corporate assignor of marketing rights, assignor was not deceived as to its assignee's status and financial affairs and majority shareholder could not be considered alter ego of corporation and held liable for payments due by corporation under marketing contract.
Document Preview: Corporate assignor of marketing rights brought action against corporate assignee and its majority shareholder to cancel marketing contract, and to recover amount allegedly due under contract for purchases and damages for breach of contract, damage to trademark, trade name and good will and for loss of future profits. The 19th Judicial District Court, Parish of East Baton Rouge, Elven E. Ponder, J., rendered judgment in favor of plaintiffs, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeal, Ellis, J., held that award against corporate defendant was proper, that stockholder defendant waived exception of lack of jurisdiction over his person, that law of Texas applied, and that shareholder was not personally liable under either contract providing for formation of defendant corporation or as alter ego of corporation for its failure to make payments required under marketing contract. Reversed in part, affirmed in part, and rendered. Certiorari denied, La., 305 So.2d 123. Application denied,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gladding Corp. v. Register
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Where parent formed subsidiary for sole purpose of consummating sale of business to it and negotiations culminating in acquisition were conducted solely by parent with seller of business, since contract for sale to subsidiary was unambiguous, parent was not liable by terms of contract which also included an agreement to employ seller of business.
Document Preview: Interpleader action brought by escrow agent with respect to parent and subsidiary corporation involved in acquisition of business and the seller of business on ground that there were conflicting claims to funds held by escrow agent. Counterclaims and third-party complaints were filed. The Circuit Court for Dade County, Rhea Pincus Grossman, J., held on trial on equitable issues, entered order denying with prejudice counterclaim seeking rescission of contract and set case down for jury trial on issue of damages. An interlocutory appeal was taken. The District Court of Appeal held that buyer by delay had waived right to rescind, that parent corporation was not liable to sellers of business to newly created subsidiary and that both sellers and buyer had right to prove amount of damages each party incurred. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kagel v. First Commonwealth Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Where principal officers and shareholders used thinly capitalized corporate entity to enter into obligations which they could not perform and corporate funds were used to pay a number of their individual personal expenses, including income taxes, property taxes and stock purchases, the corporate veil would be pierced and such individuals held personally liable for whatever damages plaintiff suffered because of the corporation's breach of stock purchase contract.
Document Preview: Trustees in bankruptcy for corporate helicopter line brought action against defendant corporation and its principal officers and stockholders to recover for alleged breach of contract to purchase from plaintiff all issued and outstanding capital stock of a third corporation. The District Court, Wollemberg, J., held that although plaintiff's acceptance letter contained numerous terms not embodied in defendant's initial offer the acceptance letter did not constitute a counter-offer where such items were merely embodiments of additional terms orally agreed to prior to expiration of the offer, that fact that offer was made subject to condition precedent of a satisfactory equipment appraisal did not render contract unenforceable as illusory, that where the individual defendants knowingly used their thinly capitalized corporate entity to enter into obligations which they could not perform the corporate veil would be pierced and that plaintiff was entitled to the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Vandervest v. Kauffman Pizza, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Where entire pizza parlor venture was solely personal enterprise of guarantors, who owned all stock and were directors and had control and management of operation of the business and who had personally guaranteed performance of the lease, so that for them to escape liability would work fraud upon plaintiff, equity should step in and pierce corporate veil, if necessary, to hold the guarantors-stockholders-directors personally liable upon their written promise to guarantee.
Document Preview: Action to enforce a rental-payment guaranty provision of a lease. An interlocutory judgment pursuant to the written guaranty was entered by the Circuit Court, Brown County, James A. Martineau, J., and the guarantor defendants, three doctors, appealed. The Supreme Court, Beilfuss, J., held that a finding that a certain individual was an agent of the guarantors was not against the great weight and clear preponderance of evidence, including evidence which was sufficient to establish that his acts and representations were either directed or known and ratified by the guarantors and evidence of the guarantors' own manifestations and participation. The court also held that where plaintiff would not enter into or sign a contract to construct a building until furnished a financial statement from the three doctors, nor sign a lease before the doctors signed it as guarantors, there was good and sufficient consideration for their agreement to guarantee rental payments, and they could not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Levenstein v. Sapiro
Court: Supreme Court of Florida.
Headnote: When an individual deals through the instrumentality of his solely owned corporation his protection from individual liability is not necessarily absolute, except where fraud is clearly involved; there may be cases where the nature of the relationship between the individual and his alter ego, his corporation and their activity is so completely personalized that the ingredient of actual fraud is unnecessary in order for the individual to be held liable for a contractual obligation made in name of his corporation; equitable principles are applicable in determining such liability.
Document Preview: Assignee of contract to acquire certain realty brought action against corporate vendor, its sole stockholder and others to recover for breach of sales contract clause relating to adequate water and sewer facilities. The Circuit Court, Dade County, John J. Kehoe, J., entered judgment against stockholder in his individual capacity, and the latter appealed. The District Court of Appeal, 266 So.2d 40, reversed and remanded. On writ of certiorari, the Supreme Court, Ervin, J., held that when an individual deals through the instrumentality of his solely owned corporation his protection from individual liability is not necessarily absolute, except where fraud is clearly involved; there may be cases where the nature of the relationship between the individual and his alter ego, his corporation and their activity is so completely personalized that the ingredient of actual fraud is unnecessary in order for the individual to be held liable for a contractual obligation made in name of his...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Custer Builders, Inc. v. Quaker Heritage, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Although corporate developer and corporate general contractor had the same two directors, officers and shareholders, in absence of showing that developer dominated contractor, that the two corporations had participated in joint venture, or that there was fraud, wrongdoing or commingling of corporate funds, the corporate identities would not be disregarded so as to permit subcontractor to recover from developer on theory that general contractor, which breached agreement with subcontractor, was developer's agent, alter ego or mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: Action by subcontractor against general contractor and developer to recover on alleged oral contract, whereby general contractor had guaranteed subcontractor's gross payroll and its costs so that it would suffer no loss on project and to recover from developer on theory that general contractor was developer's agent. The Supreme Court, Schenectady County, Trial Term, Guy A. Graves, J., entered judgment for plaintiff against general contractor and for developer and plaintiff appealed and general contractor filed cross appeal. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Reynolds, J., held that, although corporate developer and corporate general contractor had the same two directors, officers and shareholders, in absence of showing that developer dominated contractor, that two corporations had participated in a joint venture with respect to the construction or that there had been fraud, wrongdoing or commingling of corporate funds, the corporate identities would not be disregarded so as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Davies v. Little
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Where business corporation owned property which was headquarters for nonbusiness corporation, business corporation's board of directors and nonbusiness corporation's board of governors were identical, offices of president of both corporations were held by one person, the directors' and governors' meetings were held simultaneously and the minutes of both organizations were kept in one minute book, there was a community of interest between the two corporations and a merger of corporate identities so that vendor's notice to the nonbusiness corporation activating right of first refusal was valid notice to the business corporation.
Document Preview: Lessees brought action against lessor-vendor and the ultimate purchasers of certain property for specific performance of option to purchase and for damages because of an alleged conspiracy to deprive lessees of opportunity to exercise option, and purchaser brought eviction proceeding against lessees. The Superior Court, Washington County, Orme, J., entered judgment for defendants in lessees' action and ordered lessees to vacate real estate, and lessees appealed. The Supreme Court, Kelleher, J., held that where there was no showing that notice by lessees of their intent to buy was ever given during term of lease, and where, under terms of restrictive agreement between vendor and ultimate purchaser giving purchaser right of first refusal, purchaser was not obligated to exercise right to refuse until vendor gave written notice that sale was desired and about to be made, vendor's statement, during term of lease, to stockholders of corporate purchaser that lessee had an option to buy...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fagan v. La Gloria Oil & Gas Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In absence of any showing that in making guarantee contract corporate debtor corporation was anything other than a bona fide corporation acting in furtherance of its own separate and legitimate business, liability would not be imposed on shareholders on the alter ego theory.
Document Preview: Suit in the nature of creditor's bill by corporate creditor against officers and directors of corporate debtor. The District Court, Harris County, Warren P. Cunningham, J., entered a judgment in favor of the judgment creditor and the defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Tunks, C.J., held, inter alia, that evidence sustained trial court's implied finding that plaintiff judgment debtor did not receive its equitable share of assets of corporate debtor which were misapplied by defendant officers and directors who instituted scheme or why they would so manipulate corporate affairs that corporate debtor would continue business solely for purpose of permitting it to pay claims which defendants had against it and to pay claims of creditors to whom defendants were secondarily liable, and defendants were liable under the trust fund doctrine. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sheetz v. Spagnol
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate entity may not be disregarded merely to rewrite contract for sale of stock so as to provide for personal liability where none is provided by contract.
Document Preview: Assumpsit action wherein sellers of corporate stock sought recovery of specified sum from buyer. The Court of Common Pleas, Westmoreland County, Civil Division, No. 896 July Term, 1969, Richard E. McCormick, J., entered judgment for sellers and buyer appealed. The Superior Court, No. 305 April Term, 1972, Cercone, J., held that where agreement for sale of all corporate stock required buyer to exercise his ownership control so that corporation would pay sellers $20,000 within two-year period with respect to their preexisting claims againset corporation, and there was nothing to establish fraudulent attempt by buyer to conceal himself behind corporate veil, buyer was not personally liable for payment of such amount. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Before a subsidiary can be found to be a mere instrumentality of a parent corporation, for purpose of holding parent liable for subsidiary's contracts, the parent must, under New York law, have control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination of finances, policy and business practices in respect to the transaction attacked; such control must have been used to commit fraud or wrong and such control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Berger v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, a national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover from parent corporation, as alleged alter ego of subsidiary, for breach of contract entered into with subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, John V. Singleton, J., awarded damages to plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Goldberg, Circuit Judge, held that where evidence failed to establish that parent corporation, national broadcaster, completely dominated not only the finances, but policy and business practices of wholly owned subsidiary corporation, a film maker, subsidiary could not, under New York law, be found to have been a mere instrumentality of parent; thus, parent could not be found to have breached contract, which involved syndication of fashion spectacular and which had been entered into by and in name of subsidiary, by entering into a similar contract with another. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Paine v. Carter
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In suit on contract, where plaintiff claimed under former president of corporation who was also participating director and stockholder in corporation and former president, corporation and individual defendant were parties to contract and contract recognized and assumed separate existence of corporation and individual defendant, plaintiff was legally bound by the written contract as well as by undisputed testimony as to knowledge of corporate structure and separate existence of parties and was precluded in law or estopped to claim that individual defendant was alter ego of the corporation.
Document Preview: Suit on contract. The District Court, Harris County, Arthur Lesher, J., rendered take nothing judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Barron, J., held that where plaintiff claimed under former president of corporation who was also participating director and stockholder in corporation and former president, corporation and individual defendant were parties to contract and contract recognized and assumed separate existence of corporation and individual defendant, plaintiff was legally bound by the written contract as well as by undisputed testimony as to knowlege of corporate structure and separate existence of parties and was precluded in law or estopped to claim that individual defendant was alter ego of the corporation. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: York Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc. v. Chrysler Credit Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
