Headnote: Although both corporate manufacturer and its sales subsidiary were "automobile manufacturers" as defined in the Dealers Day in Court Act, where facts indicated that they were separate legal entities each operating in its own sphere, only the subsidiary, which had entered into franchise agreement with dealer, could be held accountable for performing or complying with it, and since manufacturer was not a party to the franchise, it should have been dismissed from the suit. 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 1221-1225.
Document Preview: Suit by automobile dealer and its stockholders against automobile manufacturer, manufacturer's sales subsidiary and financing corporation for fraud and deceit and violation of antitrust laws and the Automobile Dealers Day in Court Act. A creditor of dealer intervened. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Alabama at Mobile, Daniel Holcombe Thomas, Chief Judge, entered judgment for dealer and stockholders against manufacturer and its subsidiary and in favor of intervenor against stockholders and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that stockholders, although not signing parties to franchise agreement with manufacturer's sales subsidiary, were, by virtue of provision of agreements obligating them to keep franchise viable, entitled to assert claim under the Dealers Day in Court Act. Reversed and remanded in part; affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Cross Properties, Inc. v. Brook Realty Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Fact that individual corporations of corporate group may have been run as single enterprise and that management of corporations belonging to group knew that proposed sale of substantially all their assets was opposed by principal shareholders and contract was entered into on eve of directors' ouster from office did not require court to pierce corporate veil and hold that sale required consent of two-thirds of shareholders of parent corporation. Business Corporation Law § 909.
Document Preview: Appeals from interlocutory judgment of Supreme Court, Westchester County, Trial Term, Hugh S. Coyle, J., dismissing amended complaint with prejudice, adjudging contract to sell property to be valid, and granting leave to apply for hearing to determine whether specific performance should be decreed and what damages, if any, should be awarded, and order of same court at Special Term, John J. Dillon, J., denying motion to modify interlocutory judgment to dismiss cross claim of purchaser for specific performance or for summary judgment dismissing cross claim. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Munder, J., held that contract which was approved by boards of directors of New York corporations and which covered sale of substantially all assets of New York corporations which were wholly owned subsidiaries of Canadian corporation 90% Of whose stock was owned by English corporation was valid even though not approved by two-thirds of shareholders of English corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pilot Title Ins. Co. v. Northwestern Bank
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where corporation, to which was donated bookkeeping credit received by borrower for major portion of loan represented by demand note given to bank, was at all times under control of bank, and bank caused corporation to use such credit to purchase certain assets from bank, corporation was alter ego of bank, and thus bank had sustained no loss with respect to portion of loan allocated for assets and issuer of mortgagee title policy to bank on tract of land, which was subject to deed of trust given by borrower to bank as security for demand note, and to which borrower did not have title, was not liable under such policy for sum allocated for assets.
Document Preview: Action by issuer of mortgagee title policy for injunctive relief, or in alternative, relief pursuant to Declaratory Judgment Act. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, Pilston Godwin, J., ordered injunctive relief and certain defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Graham, J., held that where corporation, to which was donated bookkeeping credit received by borrower for major portion of loan represented by demand note given to bank was at all times under control of bank, and bank caused corporation to use such credit to purchase certain assets from bank corporation was alter ego of bank, and thus bank had sustained no loss with respect to portion of loan allocated for assets and issuer of mortgagee title policy to bank on tract of land, which was subject to deed of trust given by borrower to bank as security for demand note, and to which borrower did not have title, was not liable under such policy for sum allocated for assets. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Doyn Aircraft, Inc. v. Wylie
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Where, in negotiation of distributorship agreement which individual signed as trustee for corporation to be formed, the identities of the individual and the corporation merged and to segregate them would cause inequitable result, individual could properly be held personally liable for breach of the contract on theory that corporation was individual's alter ego.
Document Preview: In action for breach of contract, fraud and conversion, the United States District Court for the District of Kansas, Wesley E. Brown, Chief Judge, rendered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hill, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that though distributorship agreement between Texas resident and Kansas corporation was executed in Texas and was to be governed by the laws of that state, acts of Texas resident within Kansas constituted transaction of business' within Kansas long-arm statute, where Texas resident traveled to Kansas to investigate possibility of becoming distributor and where, when difficulties arose after the execution of the contract, Texas resident again traveled to Kansas, where the parties, inter alia, reaffirmed the Texas contract, and assumption of in personam jurisdiction by the District Court for the District of Kansas over the Texas resident, who was personally served in Texas, did not offend traditional notions...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Roman Catholic Archbishop v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Uncontroverted affidavit that corporation sole had no dealings with European monastery of same religious faith negated any possibility that corporation so controlled and dominated the monastery as to be liable for its actions under "alter ego" doctrine; thus, plaintiff was not entitled to recover from corporation sole amount deposited with monastery for purchase of dog which was not delivered and for additional amount expended for similar dog. West's Ann.Corp.Code, § 10000 et seq.
Document Preview: Mandamus proceeding to compel the Superior Court of Alameda County to enter summary judgment in favor of petitioner, a corporation sole, in suit against petitioner to recover amount deposited with European monastery of same religious faith for purchase of dog which was not delivered and to recover additional amount expended for similar dog. The Court of Appeal, David, J., held that uncontroverted affidavit that corporation sole had no dealings with European monastery negated any possibility that corporation so controlled and dominated the monastery as to be liable for its actions under alter ego doctrine; thus, plaintiff was not entitled to recover. Peremptory writ issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Roman Catholic Archbishop v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Fact that plaintiff, in action against corporation sole to recover amount deposited with European monastery of same religious faith for purchase of dog which was not delivered and for additional amount expended for similar dog, would not be able to collect if corporate veil of corporation sole was not pierced was not sufficient to apply alter ego theory.
Document Preview: Mandamus proceeding to compel the Superior Court of Alameda County to enter summary judgment in favor of petitioner, a corporation sole, in suit against petitioner to recover amount deposited with European monastery of same religious faith for purchase of dog which was not delivered and to recover additional amount expended for similar dog. The Court of Appeal, David, J., held that uncontroverted affidavit that corporation sole had no dealings with European monastery negated any possibility that corporation so controlled and dominated the monastery as to be liable for its actions under alter ego doctrine; thus, plaintiff was not entitled to recover. Peremptory writ issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gordon Chemical Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: Fact that three corporations had common management, were engaged in interdependent business, and were all insured for one amount under business interruption policy did not require that such corporations be treated as single corporation for purposes of recovery under the policy, after fire which resulted in loss of profits of one corporation but no loss in total profits of the three, where stockholders of such corporations were not identical, no stockholders owned same proportion of outstanding stock in any two of such corporations, corporations had different employees, and separate books of account were kept for each corporation by different individuals.
Document Preview: Action to recover business interruption loss under insurance policy. The Superior Court, Meagher, J., found for one of the insureds, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Spalding, J., held that where business of one corporation insured under business interruption policy was manufacture of polystyrene, policy provisions requiring reduction of loss by complete or partial resumption of operation of the property herein described, whether damaged or not * * *., by making use of other property at the location(s) described herein or elsewhere * * *,, and by making use of stock (raw, in process or finished) at the location(s) described herein or elsewhere, did not compel manufacturer to avoid loss by purchase of polystyrene from others for sale to its sole customer; such would not be resumption of its operations. Order for judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Crowell Corp. v. Merrie Paper Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence to warrant conclusion that seller completely dominated finances, policy and business of buyer and evidence clearly established that seller maintained its own separate assets, employees and means of production, and was not mere agent of buyer, mere fact there was close working relationship between seller and buyer did not warrant piercing veil of respective corporations.
Document Preview: Proceedings on motion for summary judgment. The Supreme Court, New York County, Harry B. Frank, J., denied the motion and movant appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that where there was no evidence to warrant conclusion that seller completely dominated finances, policy and business of buyer and evidence clearly established that seller maintained its own separate assets, employees and means of production, and was not mere agent of buyer, mere fact there was close working relationship between seller and buyer did not warrant piercing veil of respective corporations as basis for denial of partial summary judgment. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Margarine Verkaufsunion G.m.B.H. v. M.T.G.C. Brovig
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although consignee and shipper were subsidiary corporations, where evidence indicated an arms-length commercial transaction between the corporations, and bill of lading was a negotiable "on board" freight paid instrument, and was fully negotiated to the consignee, which made final payment for shipment 10 days before outturn of the cargo, the bill of lading became a document of title, bringing consignee under the protection of the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act. Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, 46 U.S.C.A. § 1300.
Document Preview: Action by consignee against vessel, her owner, and vessel's charterer to recover damages for short delivery and contamination of part of shipment of cottonseed oil. The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held that evidence established that defendants complied with statutory requirement of due diligence to make vessel seaworthy and the tanks fit for reception and carriage of the shipment, and that cause of contamination by sea water of a portion of the shipment was a crack in plate of one tank which developed during heavy weather encountered on high seas due to a latent defect not discoverable by due diligence. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Mid-Southern Toyota, Limited v. Bug's Imports, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Parent corporation is not bound to perform subsidiary's contracts and is not liable for breaches of those contracts by subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action for declaration of rights under contract. The Boyle Circuit Court, Delbert Eagle, J., rendered judgment, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Davis, C., held, among other things, that provision that contract between plaintiff, Kentucky distributor of Japanese made automobiles, and defendant, who was to act as plaintiff's warehousing agent in Kentucky, should run for one year and would be renewed if defendant's sales in Kentucky equaled plaintiff's sales in rest of plaintiff's territory did not provide for only one-year renewal or for renewal in perpetuity but for renewal indefinitely, and contract was terminable after a reasonable time. Affirmed in part and reversed in part. Neikirk, J., concurred in result only.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ariate Compania Naviera, S. A. v. Commonwealth Tankship Owners, Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where charter party was contrivance of president of corporation which had only real financial stake in transaction and president was endeavoring to put together transactions to make money while shielding himself with corporations with minimal capitalization, corporate veil of corporation would be pierced and president would be held personally liable for breach of charter party.
Document Preview: Shipowner filed libel alleging breach of time charter party and conspiracy to defraud owner of its charter hire. The District Court, Cannella, J., held that where charter party was contrivance of president of corporation which had only real financial stake in transaction and president was endeavoring to put together gransactions to make money while shielding himself with corporations with minimal capitalization, corporate veil of corporation would be pierced and president would be held personally liable for breach of charter party. Judgment for plaintiff shipowner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ferrarell v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1, Department B.
Headnote: Mere fact that defendant was officer and shareholder did not in and of itself present case for disregarding corporate entity and imposing liability upon defendant for corporation's breach of contract, absent showing that corporation was influenced and governed by defendant and that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality or separateness of defendant and the corporation had ceased to exist.
Document Preview: Action for breach of contract against corporation, its president and designated broker, a salesman employed by corporation, and surety of broker and corporation. The Superior Court of Maricopa County, Cause No. 161899, Porter Murry, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs against only the corporation and plaintiffs appealed from a judgment in favor of remaining defendants. The Court of Appeals, Haire, J., held that where contract was expressly made in name of corporation, Salesman who signed contract on behalf of corporation was not liable for corporation's breach of contract. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Leon Handbag Co. v. Local 213 of Leather, Luggage and Handbag Workers
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Duty to arbitrate will continue even where there is a drastic change in the corporate structure or ownership.
Document Preview: Action by handbag manufacturer against union seeking declaratory relief with respect to alleged right to cease handbag manufacturing. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Richard L. Wells, J., sustained general demurrer to complaint, and manufacturer appealed. The Court of Appeal, Roth, P.J., held that face of manufacturer's complaint, seeking declaration that it had right to cease handbag manufacturing, change its business to handbag jobbing and have handbags made for it by independent contractors as part of its jobbing business, did not establish that dispute so asserted was not covered by arbitration clause of collective bargaining agreement applicable to any grievance, difference, or dispute concerning working conditions or interpretations or application of collective bargaining agreement. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Manufacturer's Nat. Bank of Detroit v. Hartmeister
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Imposing liability for commissions upon individual who negotiated agreement with plaintiff and who was sole owner of corporations which owned property did not constitute impermissible piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: Diversity action to recover commissions on real estate sales. The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, William E. Doyle, J., found for plaintiff and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Circuit Judge, held that broker's licensing law did not preclude recovery of commission by employee who was placed in charge of operations of property under agreement for salary per month plus 5% Commission on all sales if owner was not required to use services of broker, and that imposing liability for commissions upon individual who negotiated agreement with plaintiff and who was sole owner of corporations which owned property did not constitute impermissible piercing of corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ebco, Inc. v. Bechtold
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 1.
Headnote: Where ownership of multiple corporations by same stockholders creates ambiguity as to where burden of performance of contract executed by one corporation guaranteeing performance by another corporation lies, the court will look behind the corporate veils as an aid in interpreting the contract.
Document Preview: Action by corporate seller of laundry business to recover balance of purchase price from corporate buyer's shareholders who guaranteed payment. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Virgil H. Langtry, J., held that guarantors were discharged of liability and seller appealed. The Supreme Court, O'Connell, J., held that corporate seller's promise on sale of laundry that it agrees to cause two hotels, all of whose stock was owned by stockholders of seller, to agree to have hotel laundering and dry cleaning performed by buyer was a single intergrated promise to see that hotels' laundry needs would be served by buyer and on breach of his promise buyer's guarantors were discharged. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: National Sur. Corp. v. U.S. for Use of Way Panama, S. A.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where individual who contracted for construction of public building caused his company to assign contract to a foreign corporation controlled by him, subcontracts referred to assignee as general contractor and stationery of both companies was used interchangeably to make purchase orders, the two concerns were one entity as to the contract supplier of assignee did not have contractual relationship with subcontractor and it was not necessary for it to give assignor the 90-day notice in order to recover from surety on assignor's Miller Act payment bond. Miller Act, §§ 1 et seq., 2(a, b), 40 U.S.C.A. §§ 270a et seq., 270b(a, b).
Document Preview: Action on Miller Act payment bond. The United States District Court for the District of the Canal Zone, Guthrie F. Crowe, J., 238 F.Supp. 887, entered judgment against surety which appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hutcheson, Circuit Judge, held that where individual who contracted for construction of public building caused his company to assign contract to a foreign corporation controlled by him, subcontracts referred to assignee as general contractor and stationery of both companies was used interchangeably to make purchase orders, the two concerns were one entity as to the contract, supplier of assignee did not have contractual relationship with subcontractor and it was not necessary for it to give assignor the 90-day notice in order to recover from surety on assignor's Miller Act payment bond. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wooddale, Inc. v. Fidelity & Deposit Co. of Md.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where corporation was formed for limited purpose of bidding on contracts which would be sublet to subcontractor and corporation maintained its office at same place of business as subcontractor and maintained no payroll, estimators or workmen, and corporation's fidelity bond application disclosed that corporation was formed for limited purpose, surety could not avoid liability on fidelity bond on theory that corporation was a "shell" or "dummy".
Document Preview: Corporate contractor brought action against bonding company on fidelity bond, and bonding company filed thirdparty complaint against subcontractor. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa, Roy L. Stephenson, J., 251 F.Supp. 775, rendered judgment for bonding company and dismissed third-party complaint and corporate contractor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Lay, Circuit Judge, held that subcontractor who as president of corporate contractor from which he allegedly misappropriated funds submitted all bids in name of corporation and who bid only on jobs approved by director and who was subject to control, direction and ultimate discharge of corporation and its directors was an employee of corporation within meaning of fidelity bond notwithstanding subcontractor's dual employment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: June v. Vibra Screw Feeders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Where president of defendant New Jersey corporation and another corporation personally conducted business of both corporations, using corporation names, before corporations were officially chartered, and letterheads and invoices of corporations were used interchangeably by president in his dealings with Michigan representative of defendant corporation, defendant corporation was estopped, in action by its Michigan representative for alleged breach of contract for payment of commissions due for sale of corporation's product in Michigan, from claiming any legal recognition of separate corporate entities previously ignored in dealing with Michigan representative.
Document Preview: Action by former Michigan representative of New Jersey corporation for alleged breach of contract for payment of commissions due for sale of corporation's product in Michigan. The Circuit Court, Oakland County, William John Beer, J., granted summary judgment in favor of plaintiff, and the corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, McGregor, J., held that corporation, which, in year preceding action, had dozens of sales in Michigan totalling over $30,000, and whose Michigan customers included large industries in Michigan, maintained continuous and systematic contacts within Michigan sufficient to warrant assumption by Michigan courts of jurisdiction over it. The Court further held that granting summary judgment, as consequence of refusal to appear after invocation of rule authorizing court to compel appearance of out-of-state party over which Michigan court has jurisdiction, was error, and, where parties specified in written order of appearance that nonappearance would result in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kaminsky v. Kahn
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Where buyer of stock had contractual duty to sell certain stock purchased from seller before selling other stock in same corporation, charging buyer in accounting proceeding with sale of such stock by a certain corporation was proper where that corporation was controlled by buyer and was his alter ego.
Document Preview: Accounting proceeding in which cross appeals were taken from judgment of the Supreme Court, Trial Term, New York County, Matthew M. Levy, J., in favor of seller. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that under contract for sale of a corporation's stock providing that if buyer desired to sell any of stock purchased he was required to submit written evidence of a bona fide purchase offer to seller who had right and option to purchase the shares upon the terms set forth in the offer, buyer who also owed other stock not subject to option, had duty upon selling stock in that corporation to first sell stock sold him by seller, even though buyer was not a fiduciary. The Court further held that where sale of unregistered stock, such as that transferred to buyer, was worth about 30 to 60% Less than registered stock traded on the exchange, holding buyer accountable for market price, less cost of registering stock, was error and judgment was modified to charge buyer only with actual...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Associates Development Corp. v. Air Control Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Where seller transacted business only with manager of corporate buyer and billed corporate buyer for all goods without any suggestion as to personal liability of individual defendant or liability of another defendant corporation, owned by individual defendant who also owned buyer, until long after bills were incurred, corporate buyer was alone liable.
Document Preview: Seller's action on sworn account for goods and merchandise sold by it to buyer corporation which was sued together with individual and another defendant corporation. The 53rd District Court, Travis County, Herman Jones, J., entered a judgment against buyer corporation only and seller corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Hughes, J., held that where seller in making sales transacted business only with manager of corporate buyer and billed corporate buyer for all goods without any suggestion as to personal liability of individual defendant or liability of another defendant corporation, owned by individual defendant who also owned buyer, until long after bills were incurred, corporate buyer alone was liable. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Tropic Builders, Limited v. Naval Ammunition Depot Lualualei Quarters, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Hawai'i.
Headnote: Inadequate capitalization of corporation entering into an express contract to pay for certain work would not suffice as ground for piercing corporate veil and holding liable an individual who was in control of corporation and received benefits of performance of the work, where individual was liable on contractor's bond for work so performed but suit was not brought on bond.
Document Preview: Subcontractor brought action against two other subcontractors to foreclose mechanic's lien on premises owned by the United States and leased to corporation. The First Circuit Court, City and County of Honolulu, Frank A. McKinley, J., found for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Lewis, J., held that rule requiring that plaintiff furnish person making service of process with such copies as are necessary meant that the necessary copies were one for each defendant even though they had a common agent, and where partial assignment was made in form of an order on debtor with which debtor had agreed to comply, creditor in suing on claim could include sum assigned but would hold this sum for benefit of assignee, and where court on appeal reviewed judgment as one in an assumpsit action, only attorneys' fees provided for in assumpsit actions were allowable. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Evans v. General Ins. Co. of America
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Facts that plaintiff in personal injury action against corporation and corporation's employee was president stockholder of corporation and owner of 70% of stock and that plaintiff's wife owned 10% would not make corporation plaintiff's alter ego and cause plaintiff to be in fact suing himself within contention of corporation's liability insurer that it had no duty to defend corporation in such event.
Document Preview: Action by truck liability insurer against corporate insured, insured's president-majority stockholder, and operator of insured's truck for declaratory judgment that insurer had no obligation to defend insured or operator in action brought against them by president-stockholder for injuries received when struck by truck. The District Court, Dallas County, Paul Peurifoy, J., entered declaratory judgment for insurer, and president-stockholder appealed. The Court of Civil Appellas, Dixon, C. J., held that president-majority stockholder was not an employee within liability policy provision that insurance for other than named insured does not apply to an employee with respect to an injury to another employee, and that evidence failed to sustain court's finding that injury arose from president-stockholder's employment as insured corporation's employee within exclusion provision of policy. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stebane Nash Co. v. Campbellsport Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporation to which stockholders had leased building was not entitled to assert insurable interest that stockholders had in building on basis that corporation and stockholders were one and the same and that there was a continuity of interest and insurers were not liable to corporation for loss on that basis.
Document Preview: Consolidated actions to recover upon three fire policies issued by three separate insurers. The Circuit Court, Calumet County, Arnold J. Cane, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Beilfuss, J., held that in absence of showing that corporate insured had any insurable interest in building, it was not entitled to recover from insurers for damage thereto, but that evidence supported finding that any misrepresentations of insured in proof of fire loss as to value of personal property were not willfully or falsely made with intention to deceive insurer. Affirmed in part and reversed in part, with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: McDonald & Co. v. Kemper
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Sole stockholder and corporation were one, and realtor could recover commission under exclusive written agency contract with realtor to sell corporation's property where stockholder accepted realtor's buyer and used realtor's efforts to close the deal but because it was to his advantage, sold all stock instead of such property.
Document Preview: Action by realtor against president of corporation to recover commission for procuring a buyer for property of corporation. The District Court, Tarrant County, Harold Craik, J., entered judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Renfro, J., held that sale of all stock by sole stockholder to buyer secured by realtor, rather than sale of corporate property as provided in exclusive written agency contract, did not defeat broker's right to commission on sale. Reversed and rendered in part; reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Atomic Fuel Extraction Corp. v. Slick's Estate
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. San Antonio.
Headnote: Where plaintiff, when it made its contracts with corporate defendants, knew about individual defendant, who was alter ego of corporate defendants, his position with respect to corporate defendants, and that he was not a promisor, plaintiff could not recover from individual defendant for breach of contracts.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract, breach of agent's fiduciary duty, alleged fraud, and tortious interference with a contract. The 131st District Court of Bexar County, Eugene C. Williams, J., granted motions of all defendants for instructed verdict, and the plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Pope, J., held that question whether plaintiff, which sought to recover damages for breach by corporate defendants of contract to furnish funds to plaintiff to prevent termination of uranium milling contract obtained by plaintiff from Atomic Energy Commission, complied with conditions precedent of contract with corporate defendants that one of the corporate defendants be satisfied that plaintiff had good possessory title to mining claims, that ore supply was sufficient, and that ore was amenable to processing by methods contemplated by defendants was for jury. Judgment for corporate defendants on cause of action for breach of contract reversed; cause of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wireline, Inc. v. Byron Jackson Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Although same persons were in charge of parent corporation's division and parent's wholly owned subsidiary, where no directors of parent had ever served as directors of subsidiary and employees of subsidiary were paid by subsidiary, which conducted its own corporate meetings and filed separate tax returns, parent and subsidiary were separate identities and subsidiary which did not appear in licensing agreement between plaintiff and division could not be held liable on agreement.
Document Preview: Action brought by corporation under antitrust laws, wherein defendant corporation moved for summary judgment claiming that it was not proper party defendant. The District Court, Jameson, J., held that, although same persons were in charge of parent corporation's division and parent's wholly owned subsidiary, where no directors of parent had ever served as directors of subsidiary and employees of subsidiary were paid by subsidiary, which conducted its own corporate meetings and filed separate tax returns, parent and subsidiary were separate identities and subsidiary which did not appear in licensing agreement between plaintiff and division could not be held liable on agreement. Motion for summary judgment granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hirsh v. Miller
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: If vendor, who sold pest control business and covenanted not to compete, held stock ownership of 80% in corporation engaged in identical pest control business using same technique to recapture business previously sold to purchaser, such activity was the same as though vendor, individually, were so engaged, for purpose of determining right to injunctive relief.
Document Preview: Suit by purchaser to enjoin vendor from engaging in pest control business in violation of employment contract covenant. The Civil District Court, Orleans Parish, No. 416516, Division B, Clarence Dowling, J., entered judgment maintaining vendor's exception of no right and no cause of action and dismissed suit and purchaser appealed. The Court of Appeal, Yarrut, J., held that if vendor, individually and as president of pest control corporation, entered into an agreement for sale of corporation and thereafter entered into three separate agreements including the bill of sale, employment contract with a covenant not to compete, and a lease, and if vendor held 80% Stock ownership in corporation engaged in identical pest control business using same technique to recapture business previously sold, court should grant injunctive relief to purchaser corporation in accordance with covenant not to compete. Judgment annulled, case remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: David Moore Development Co. v. Higgins Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Tile manufacturing corporation whose salesman guaranteed to replace defective tile could not avoid liability on guarantee by claiming that it manufactured tile under contract between itself and another corporation which possessed no separate identity from manufacturer and which had no separate offices from manufacturer whose officers, with exception of its directorate, were also officers of other corporations.
Document Preview: House contractor's suit against tile manufacturer for indemnification for expenditures made by contractor in replacing defective tile. The Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans, Division D, No. 406-119, Rene A. Viosca, J., entered judgment for the contractor and the manufacturer appealed. The Court of Appeal, Regan, J., held that house contractor who purchased corporation's floor tile from corporation's sales representative, who handled sales, made demonstrations, and effected adjustments for dissatisfied customers, was entitled to assume that sales representative possessed authority to make written guarantees on behalf of corporation to pay for replacement of defective tile. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc. v. Atlas
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York, Part III.
Headnote: A seller who without inquiry accepts a corporate purchaser with which he could, absent guarantee of a person or corporation of substance, have refused to contract, cannot claim to have been defrauded if corporate purchaser has no substance.
Document Preview: Action by judgment creditor to recover the amount of the judgment from defendants. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Nassau County, Part III, Bernard S. Meyer, J., held, inter alia, that where corporate purchaser of realty had been dormant prior to contract to purchase, it had no regularly elected officers or directors and it had no assets, liabilities or income, and vendor did not rely upon third party's credit, vendor which obtained judgment against corporate purchaser could collect such judgment from corporation's president. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fontainbleau Hotel Corp. v. Crossman
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where corporation was never in possession of dress shop and never actively engaged in any business venture and did not even have a bank account, interest of corporation and shareholder, who ran dress shop, were identical, and corporation was alter ego of individual so that corporate veil would have been pierced and dominant shareholder held responsible for breach of contract.
Document Preview: Action by tenant, owner of dress shop, for enforcement of agreement allegedly giving exclusive right to sell certain items of women's wearing apparel. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, Emett C. Choate, J., entered a judgment partially in favor of dress shop owner and all parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, Wisdom, Circuit Judge, held that consideration of lease agreement and agreement between dress shop owner and another tenant showed that dress shop owner had exclusive right to sell certain apparel, and that a jury issue was presented as to whether landlord had notice of violations of owner's exclusive rights between certain dates. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bearden v. Ebcap Supply Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 1.
Headnote: That purported guarantor was married woman owning all of stock of corporate debtor did not allow court, deciding whether guaranty was supported by consideration, to pierce corporate veil to consider benefit as one flowing directly to owner.
Document Preview: Suit against corporation for materials furnished, wherein manager of debtor and owner and stockholder of corporate debtor were joined. The Civil Court, Fulton County, Osgood O. Williams, J., entered judgment adverse to stockholder and she brought error from overruling motion for new trial. The Court of Appeals, Russell, J., held that separate instrument reciting that in consideration of creditor's agreement to withhold legal action toward collection of indebtedness and to extend additional credit to corporation, debtor's sole owner and stockholder guaranteed payment of note and payment of any future indebtedness of corporation to supplier was not sufficient to constitute consideration flowing to stockholder, insofar as collection of past due indebtedness was concerned and was not a legally enforceable contract of guaranty. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Continental Television Corp. v. Caster
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District, First Division.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil of corporate buyer under contract for purchase of capital stock was not justified by corporation's exercise of its right to terminate contract, where corporation had not been used as an instrumentality of fraud or to circumvent individual obligations, and seller knew that corporation was alter ego of those whom seller had required to guarantee a designated payment upon closing.
Document Preview: Action by corporate buyer and those for whom corporation was alter ego against sellers for return of earnest money paid under contract to purchase on ground that contract to purchase had been terminated. Sellers counterclaimed for balance due on contract and for damages. The Circuit Court, Winnebago County, William R. Dusher, J., entered judgment adverse to plaintiffs, and they appealed. The Appellate Court, Smith, J., held that three of five directors remaining after one of original six directors prescribed by corporate bylaws resigned constituted majority of directors then in office and were entitled to fill vacancy in directorship under by-law permitting filling by majority of directors then in office, and quorum was present when new director accepted his office, and, therefore, resolution of termination of the four directors was valid act of board of directors. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: G. E. J. Corp. v. Uranium Aire, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation taking option to purchase mining claims was alter-ego of parent corporation and parent corporation was liable for breach of option contract, notwithstanding that corporations had to be separate entities if parent was to achieve its purpose of gaining federal income tax advantages, where subsidiary was owned, controlled and operated by parent as conduit for parent's purchase of mining claims, and it would be unjust to allow parent to escape liability by operating puppet corporation organized with insufficient capital to meet its prospective liabilities in view of fact that parent had induced optionors to give option by assuring optionors that parent would back up subsidiary.
Document Preview: Suit to recover on an option for the sale of mining claims. The United States District Court for the District of Arizona, James A. Walsh, Chief Judge, gave judgment for the plaintiffs, and the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Koelsch, Circuit Judge, held that none of the assigned errors could be sustained. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Town of North Castle v. Windmill Farm Homes, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Westchester County, New York.
Headnote: Fact that individuals, who owned realty as to which there was non-conforming right to excavate, remove, and sell sand and gravel from sand pit, were majority stockholders of corporation and for all purposes in control of activities of corporation, was not sufficient under circumstances to justify piercing corporate veil and to render unenforceable agreement of corporation with town to abandon claim to non-conforming use on ground that agreement was without consideration.
Document Preview: Town brought an action for a declaratory judgment against corporation and others to determine the rights of the parties under an agreement between the town and the corporation whereby the corporation agreed to abandon any claim to a non-conforming use or right to excavate, remove, and sell sand and gravel from sand pit in residential zone, and to enjoin the corporation and others from operation of the sand and gravel pit. The Supreme Court, Frank S. McCullough, J., held that ordinance of town could under police power terminate non-conforming use or right of landowners to excavate, remove, and sell sand and gravel from sand pit in residential zone, but that compensation might be required if action of town became so onerous as to maount to taking. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Drdlik v. Ulrich
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Even though corporation may be used as instrumentality or agency in carrying out joint venture, court will disregard corporate form and enforce joint venture agreement.
Document Preview: Action to recover reasonable value of labor allegedly rendered on behalf of defendants and to recover same sum on theory of money had and received. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Steven S. Weisman, J., entered judgment of nonsuit, and the plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Burke, P. J., held that where parties entered into joint venture agreement for construction and sale of two houses, one joint adventurer could not maintain action against other joint adventurer for services rendered in such venture. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Minton v. Cavaney
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: The "alter ego" doctrine applies to tort claims against a corporation, as well as to contractual debts.
Document Preview: Action to hold a corporate director personally liable upon a judgment recovered against a corporation. Subsequent to commencement of the action, the director died and executrix of his estate was substituted as defendant. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Frederick F. Houser, J., entered judgment adverse to defendant and she appealed. The Supreme Court, Traynor, J., held that corporate director could not be held personally liable upon a judgment against the corporation for negligence, without an opportunity to relitigate issues of corporation's negligence and amount of damages, where director was not a party to action against the corporation and did not control the litigation leading to the judgment against the corporation. Judgment reversed. Schauer and McComb, JJ., dissented in part. Opinion, 12 Cal.Rptr. 86, vacated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Irey v. Len
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Finding that corporation was alter ego of individual and that individual was personally liable on corporation's contract was proper where individual had complete ownership, management and control of corporation, and admitted that he co-signed for the two entities as one.
Document Preview: Action on a written contract for services. From a judgment of the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Jesse J. Frampton, J., granting plaintiff the relief sought, the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Shinn, P. J., held that the plaintiff, who rendered the services required under a contract to act as an officer for a corporation in connection with a construction project for five per cent of the stock of the corporation to be formed for that purpose, was entitled to be paid five percent of the stock of both corporations involved in the project, where it was understood that the work would have to be contracted for and performed according to the Wherry Act, and the parties at the time of contracting did not know that to act under the Wherry Act they would have to have two corporations. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Moore & Moore Drilling Co. v. White
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Withholding of information with respect to corporation's financial condition by its owner in negotiations leading to contract between driller of oil well and corporation was not actionable fraud, in absence of confidential relationship between owner and driller, where driller failed to make reasonable inquiry and investigation.
Document Preview: Action by the driller of an oil well to recover the contract price from the individual who was the sole owner of the corporation with which the drilling contract was made. The District Court, Dallas County, Paul Peurifoy, J., withdrew the case from the jury and rendered a judgment for the individual, and the plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Williams, J., held that the plaintiff's evidence showed no more than a suspicion of fraud, that the individual was not the corporation's alter ego, and that the individual and the corporation were not mining partners where there was never any joint operation of the well and the contract between them required the cost of the development to be paid solely by the corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Five Star Transfer & Terminal Warehouse Corp. v. Flusche
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Where member of partnership which controlled corporation and which conducted the business of corporation and owned its assets had allegedly represented to purchaser of stock in corporation that corporation was in good financial condition, and had allegedly fraudulently induced purchaser to pay $18,810 for stock in such corporation which had no assets and was not a going concern, fact that plaintiff had purchased stock from the corporation did not insulate partner from liability and where evidence in action for rescission and damages established that partner had actively participated in and benefited by the fraud perpetrated on purchaser by a corporate fiction, corporate veil could be pierced to enter judgment against partner for rescission and damages.
Document Preview: Action for $18,810 by buyer of stock in corporation, the business of which was conducted by a partnership and the assets of which were owned and held by partnership, for rescission and damages resulting from allegedly fraudulent representations by partners that the business entity was a solvent going corporation. The District Court, Dallas County, A. R. Stout, J., gave judgment for buyer and corporation and one of the partners appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Fanning, J., held that jury's answer to special issue, that value of stock, at the time of delivery to buyer, was $18,810, was unnecessary to disposition of case in view of fact that evidence established that purchaser had been damaged by paying $18,810 for stock in a corporation that had no assets and was not a going concern, and trial court did not err in disregarding jury's answer to special issue and permitting purchaser to pursue remedy of rescission and damages. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fisser v. International Bank
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Consequence of applying "alter ego doctrine" is that corporation and those who have controlled it without regard to its separate entity are treated as but one entity, and, at least in area of contracts, acts of one are the acts of all.
Document Preview: German coal importers brought libel against the International Bank charging breach of a maritime contract and filed a petition to enforce arbitration pursuant to the Federal Arbitration Act in accordance with contract of affreightment, which was signed solely by importers and Liberian corporation, on ground that the Liberian corporation was the alter ego of the International Bank. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, in admiralty, Edmund L. Palmieri, J., rendered a decree dismissing the libel and the petition, and the importers appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hincks, Circuit Judge, held that the District Court erred in ruling that International Bank was not bound by the arbitration provisions merely because the International Bank had not signed the contract, and that amenability of International Bank to arbitration could be solved only by determining whether Liberian corporation entered into the contract as the alter ego of the International...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wyoming Const. Co. v. Western Cas. & Sur. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: It was enough to hold second corporation which had acquired stock in and had assumed control of first corporation liable for first corporation's breach of contract caused by second corporation, if disregard of corporate entity was required to prevent injustice, irrespective of whether second corporation was guilty of fraud.
Document Preview: Action by surety on sub-subcontractor's performance bond, for indemnity, to recover its costs in completing contract, against sub-subcontractor and company which had acquired its stock. The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, rendered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Breitenstein, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that evidence on issue of whether sub-subcontractor had been excused from performance because of alleged breach by subcontractor warranted finding by jury adverse to sub-subcontractor and that evidence warranted jury's finding that defendant which had acquired stock in sub-subcontractor had dominated it, in its own interest, and, with full knowledge of situation, had caused sub-subcontractor to default on contract to detriment of surety. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wyoming Const. Co. v. Western Cas. & Sur. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Surety's action against its principal and corporation which had assumed control thereof, for indemnity, to recover its cost in completing contract after default by principal was action on written contract and as liability was imposed on corporation assuming control of principal under instrumentality theory, Wyoming four-year limitation statute covering noncontract, fraud and tort actions did not apply with respect to claim against such corporation. W.C.S.1945, §§ 3-305, 3-509.
Document Preview: Action by surety on sub-subcontractor's performance bond, for indemnity, to recover its costs in completing contract, against sub-subcontractor and company which had acquired its stock. The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, rendered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Breitenstein, Circuit Judge, held, inter alia, that evidence on issue of whether sub-subcontractor had been excused from performance because of alleged breach by subcontractor warranted finding by jury adverse to sub-subcontractor and that evidence warranted jury's finding that defendant which had acquired stock in sub-subcontractor had dominated it, in its own interest, and, with full knowledge of situation, had caused sub-subcontractor to default on contract to detriment of surety. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Martinson v. Andrews
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, Department 2.
Headnote: Under a joint adventure agreement for development and sale of a patented invention, defendant's obligation faithfully to perform his contract with the plaintiffs did not permit him to hide behind a purported corporation which he controlled, as as means of defending the justified anticipation of plaintiffs to share in the benefits of the invention.
Document Preview: Suit to require an accounting by owners of contractual rights to shares of the proceeds derived from inventions conceived and patented by the defendant. Judgment for the plaintiffs in the Circuit Court, Multnomah County, E. K. Oppenheimer, J., and the defendant appeals. The Supreme Court, Sloan, J., held that the relationship created by an agreement between the parties was that of coadventurers, that the defendant's obligation faithfully to perform his contract did not permit him to hide behind a corporation which he controlled, and that the agreement was not limited to the continental United States. Decree affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Francis O. Day Co. v. Shapiro
Court: United States Court of Appeals District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: In action for breach of written contract to construct storm sewers, where principal owner of various defendant corporations allegedly represented that an engineering corporation was to be the general contractor in whose name he executed the construction contract and he allegedly utilized the corporate forms to evade liability when in fact the contract was his own contract and written for his own benefit, to prevent injustice, the concept of separate corporate entity could not stand as a bar to the relief of plaintiff.
Document Preview: Action to recover on an unpaid state court judgment recovered in an action for breach of written contract to construct storm sewers. From a judgment of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, F. Dickinson Letts, J., the plaintiff appeals. The United States Court of Appeals, Danaher, Circuit Judge, held that the complaint was sufficient to state a cause of action, and that the circumstances required disregard of the corporate entity to prevent injustice where the defendant allegedly utilized the corporate forms for the purpose of evading liability on the contract. Judgment reversed in part and affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Ackerman v. Citron
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey. Appellate Division.
Headnote: That president who was majority shareholder in corporation himself purchased building in which corporation was a tenant because corporation's creditors would not allow corporation to purchase it would not warrant piercing corporate veil so as to allow a broker, entitled under agreement to a commission if corporation or anyone acting on its behalf purchased the property, to recover such commission.
Document Preview: Broker's action against vendor for commission due on sale of building to tenant pursuant to provision in lease negotiated by broker, entitling broker to 5% Of selling price if premises were purchased by tenant or anyone acting on its behalf. From a judgment of dismissal, the plaintiff appealed. The Superior Court, Appellate Division, Conford, J.A.D., held that evidence on issue on whether corporate president who purchased building after corporate creditors refused to authorize purchase by corporation and suggested such personal purchase acted primarily out of consideration of service to corporation was for jury. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Geletucha v. 222 Delaware Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: In contract cases, there is no liability of one corporation because of the activities of another in the absence of fraud, deception or illegality of purpose.
Document Preview: Negligence action arising out of death of plaintiff's intestate as result of asphyxiation from fumes of chemical known as perchloroethylene used by corporate retail cleaning establishment, against management corporation which handled the repairs, maintenance, office supervision and clerical work of the retail corporation. The Erie Trial Term, Regis O'Brien, J., dismissed the complaint as to the management corporation on the merits, on motion by such corporation at the close of the plaintiff's case. The plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that the evidence raised question for jury as to whether management corporation was liable as the instrumentality and agency of the retail corporation or whether the corporations were separate identities. Reversed and new trial ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wescott & Winks Hatcheries v. F. M. Stamper Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: In action by buyer of turkey poults against supplier, a subsidiary corporation, for breach of alleged written contract to sell and deliver poults when manager of parent company had notified buyer by letter that "we will be unable to fill your order", separate identity of two corporations could not be disregarded merely because one was parent and sole stockholder of the other, in determining whether letter from parent company was sufficient compliance with statute of frauds to render subsidiary corporation liable on its oral contract. I.C.A. § 554.4, and (1).
Document Preview: Action for damages for breach of alleged written contract to sell and deliver turkey poults. The District Court, Johnson County, James P. Gaffney, J., directed verdict for supplier and buyer appealed. The Supreme Court, Smith, J., held that where buyer had solicited tenders on turkey poults for delivery on July 17, 1953 and agent of supplier, a subsidiary corporation, had telephoned buyer and had stated that they could take care of order and had prepared unsigned written order blank reciting date wanted week of July 17, and buyer had written letter correcting order blank by requiring delivery on July 17, 1953, and thereafter manager of supplier's parent company had written letter advising buyer that they would be unable to fill order, memorandum signed by parent company did not constitute compliance with statute of frauds sufficient to render subsidiary corporation liable on its oral contract. Affirmed. Oliver, J., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Holland v. Joy Candy Mfg. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: In action by advertising agency to recover for services rendered in preparation and placing of advertising for candy manufactured by one corporate defendant and sold through retail outlets maintained by second corporate defendant, evidence established that corporate defendant which maintained retail outlets was a mere instrumentality of corporation which manufactured candy and that affairs of two corporations were so managed and controlled by the same interlocking officers, directors and a single stockholder as to constitute one corporate entity in its dealings with creditors.
Document Preview: Action by advertising agency to recovery for services rendered in preparation and placing of advertising for candy manufactured by one corporate defendant and sold through retail outlets operated by other corporate defendant. The Municipal Court of Chicago, Joseph F. Geary, J., entered judgment against both corporate defendants and defendant manufacturing corporation appealed. The Appellate Court, Feinberg, J., held that evidence established that corporation which maintained retail outlets was a mere instrumentality of defendant corporation which manufactured the candy and that affairs of the corporations were so managed and controlled by the same interlocking officers directors and single stockholder as to constitute one corporate entity in its dealings with creditors. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bramwell v. Airport Blue Print Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: In action by purchaser of business against seller and others for alleged violation of agreement of seller not to engage in same business in certain county for ten years, evidence sustained finding that seller and others formed corporations for purpose of enabling seller to circumvent his covenant with purchaser and that seller dominated and controlled said corporations. West's Ann.Bus. & Prof.Code, § 16601.
Document Preview: Action by purchaser of business against seller and others for alleged violation of agreement of seller not to engage in same business in certain county for ten years. The Superior Court, San Diego County, C. M. Monroe, J., rendered judgment for purchaser, and seller appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Griffin, Acting P. J., held that evidence sustained finding that seller and others formed corporations for purpose of enabling seller to circumvent his covenant with purchaser and that seller dominated and controlled said corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Appleby v. Wallins
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Middlesex.
Headnote: Where plaintiff brought action against corporation and its president for commission allegedly due under agreements with president personally and with corporation, and there was no suggestion by any parties of any fraud, wrong or injustice in organization of corporation, it was improper for court to give instruction to effect that corporate entity should be disregarded if it was formed to shield individuals from personal liability.
Document Preview: Action for commissions allegedly due under contracts with corporate entity and with president of corporation personally. The Superior Court, Sullivan, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendant brought exceptions. The Supreme Judicial Court, Counihan, J., held that where there was no suggestion by any of parties of any fraud, wrong, or injustice in organization of corporation, it was improper for court to give instruction to effect that corporate entity should be disregarded if it was formed to shield individuals from personal liability. Exceptions sustained.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Yarmove v. Robinson
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In broker's action to recover commission for procuring a purchaser for defendants' property, dismissing complaint as against respondent who controlled the corporate respondent was error.
Document Preview: Action by broker to recover commissions for producing a purchaser for defendants' property. From an adverse judgment, Leonard J. Supple, J., the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that evidence of custom or habit introduced by the defendant to ppove that he had not entered into a brokerage contract with the broker was inadmissible. Judgment in accordance with the opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Potter v. Minskoff
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Complaint, which was filed against directors of corporation for conspiracy to induce breach of contract by the corporation, and which sought to hold directors personally liable on theory that corporation could be disregarded as a fiction because directors were sole owners of the corporation, failed to state sufficient facts to warrant disregarding corporate entity and holding directors personally liable.
Document Preview: Action against Onondaga County, directors of corporation for alleged conspiracy to induce corporation to breach contract with plaintiff. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Frank Del Vecchio, J., denied defendants' motion to dismiss complaint and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Bastow, J., held that complaint which failed to allege that directors induced corporation to break its contract with plaintiffs was insufficient to impose personal liability upon directors for breach of such contract. Order reversed. Williams, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Brown v. Gloeckner
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: One contracting with special purpose corporation to construct state subsidized housing project, which corporation had contracted with State Planning Board to construct and operate, had no right to bring action in equity against such corporation, individual owners of all its stock, and two other corporations, on ground that such other defendants were also liable to plaintiff for contracting corporation's breach of contract on theory that court should look behind corporate entities, in absence of allegations of fraud, concealment or misrepresentation by such defendants. 35 P.S. § 1661.
Document Preview: Action to recover damages for defendant special purpose corporation's alleged breach of contract for plaintiff's construction of state subsidized housing project which corporation had contracted with State Planning Board to construct and operate, declare corporation a trustee for plaintiff of all assets in its possession or control, and restrain it and other defendants from selling or encumbering their assets and dissolving corporation or merging it with any other corporation. From a decree of the Court of Common Pleas, Allegheny County, at No. 3136, January Term, 1955, in Equity, William J. McNaugher, President Judge, dismissing the bill, plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, No. 182, March Term, 1955, Per Curiam, held that plaintiff had no right to sue in equity on grounds that individual defendants and other corporate defendants than contracting corporation were also liable to him on theory that court should look behind corporate entities and that contracting corporation...
