Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pace Corp. v. Jackson
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Corporate fiction will not be disregarded so as to hold individual officers, directors or stockholders liable on obligations of contract, except where it appears that individuals are using corporate entity as sham to perpetrate fraud, to avoid personal liability, to avoid effect of a statute, or in a few other exceptional situations.
Document Preview: Action by a corporation and two shareholders for declaratory judgment construing contract with former shareholder. Defendant filed cross-action for breach of contract. The District Court, Bexar County, C. K. Quin, J., entered judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Archer, C. J., 275 S.W.2d 849 affirmed the judgment, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Calvert, J., held that provisions of contract that corporation would supply cigarettes to defendant for any business he might become interested in outside of county, was not so uncertain, indefinite or lacking of mutuality as to be unenforceable where defendants had agreed to sale of his stock in corporation in return for execution of such agreement, but that shareholders were not personally liable under such provisions of contract. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Clarke Auto Co. v. Fyffe
Court: Appellate Court of Indiana, In Banc.
Headnote: Where defendant corporation and associate corporation both dealt in automobiles, kept books and records at office of associated corporation, had similar names, and generally did business in such a manner that third parties had no way of knowing with whom they were dealing, for purposes of action by buyer who was told to make check for automobile payable to defendant corporation, the corporations were treated as merged, and defendant corporation could not escape liability by contending that associated corporation made the sale. Burns' Ann.St. § 25-203.
Document Preview: Action to recover price paid for automobile, on ground that seller, a corporation, did not have title thereto. The Circuit Court, Boone County, Charles F. Thompson, J., entered judgment for buyer, and defendant corporation appealed. The Appellate Court, Royse, J., held that where defendant corporation and associated corporation kept books and records at office of associated corporation, had confusingly similar names, and generally did business in such a manner that third parties had no way of knowing with whom they were dealing, and where buyer, was told to make check for automobile payable to defendant corporation, for purpose of action arising from sale the corporations were treated as merged, and defendant corporation could not escape liability by contending that associated corporation made the sale. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shafford v. Otto Sales Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Fact that president of import business sent letter to broker personally offering sale of coconut without showing that import business had been incorporated at that time, that president's family completely owned business and fraudulently concealed its breach of business contract whereby broker was to receive commission on all sales of coconut to a certain company was not sufficient to show use by president of business for personal purposes and would not support a personal judgment against him.
Document Preview: Broker's action against import and export company and its president for commissions alleged to be due him under terms of oral agreement on all sales of coconut made to a certain company. The Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco, rendered judgment for broker and imported export business and its president appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Peters, P. J., held that fact that import and export business breached contract with agent and fraudulently concealed such breach from him, that president controlled the business and with his family owned it entirely and that president personally sent letter to broker offering coconuts for sale and had sent broker contract without evidence that business had been incorporated at that time were not sufficient to show a use by the president of the corporate entity for his personal purposes. Judgment against president reversed and judgment against import and export business affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Koengeter v. Holzbaugh
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: A contract for benefit of corporation is not contract for benefit of separate estates of several stockholders, and is not transformed into contract of such character by mere fact that all stocks of corporation happen to be owned by one person, in absence of showing of fraudulent or improper use of corporate device to cloak actions of sole stockholder.
Document Preview: Action by Laura Koengeter against Fred Holzbaugh and Dorothy K. Callahen, formerly Dorothy K. Holzbaugh, jointly and severally, on promissory note executed by defendants while they were husband and wife. The Circuit Court for the County of Wayne, Robert M. Toms, J., entered judgment on note with endorsement thereon which recited that it was rendered upon written instrument delivered by defendants while they were husband and wife and which directed similar endorsement on writ of execution, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Dethmers, J., held that mere fact that avails of loan had been used to provide working capital for corporation of which wife was sole stockholder did not, in absence of showing of fraudulent or improper use of corporate device to cloak actions of such sole stockholder, authorized levy upon separate estate of wife for satisfaction of judgment on note. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mercantile Home Bank & Trust Co.
Court: Kansas City Court of Appeals, Missouri.
Headnote: Where insurer had policy covering two subsidiary corporations and paid claim to one upon execution of proof of loss and obtained release and assignment from it but other corporation actually suffered loss, and both corporations dealt with each other as separate corporate entities, insurer failed to prove that it had been subrogated to rights of insured which had suffered loss.
Document Preview: Action by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company against the Mercantile Home Bank & Truck Company to recover amount paid by plaintiff to its insured in settlement of liability for losses sustained on certain checks. The Circuit Court, Jackson County, Allen C. Southern, J., rendered judgment for the defendant and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Bour, C., held that the insurer failed to prove that it had paid amount of loss to its insured. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Galdi v. Caribbean Sugar Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Notwithstanding identity of stockholders and control, corporations are distinct entities and neither can be treated as alter ego or agent of other when openly contracting for itself and in its own corporate name.
Document Preview: Joseph C. Galdi and others, holders of bonds issued by Caribbean Sugar Company, sued that company and others, to compel defendant National Shawmut Bank to account for funds allegedly held by it as constructive trustee for plaintiffs, consisting of proceeds of the sale of preferred stock of Caribbean Sugar Company. The Superior Court, Kirk, J., sustained a demurrer and dismissed the bill, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Williams, J., held that the bill did not show that the purchase of defendant corporation's preferred stock at allegedly excessive prices constituted a payment of dividend in violation of the indenture with bondholders, or a transaction fraudulent as to creditors under the showing made as to defendant bank's control of the corporation and its subsidiary who purchased the stock. Interlocutory and final decrees affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: W. W. Britton, Inc. v. S. M. Hill Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Essex.
Headnote: Where seller had been charging goods to individual's account and subsequently two corporations were formed which succeeded to individual's business, one of which carried individual's name in title and seller continued charging items sold to the other corporation to account, which it had set up, for months without objection, seller could recover from corporation which contained individual's name on an action of contract on an account annexed, notwithstanding that some bills had been paid by other corporation.
Document Preview: Action of contract on an account annexed by W. W. Britton, Incorporated, against S. M. Hill Company for work performed and materials furnished in respect to automobile repairs. On plaintiff's motion for judgment on auditor's report, the Superior Court, Murray, J., ordered judgment for defendant, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Lummus, J., held that plaintiff was entitled to recover against the defendant, notwithstanding that its invoices for items furnished were occasionally made out in name of another company. Order reversed and judgment to be entered for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Neal v. Daniels
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: One selling corporation's majority stock while in another corporation's employ was not agent of individual owning all of corporate employer's stock and hence not liable to such owner for amount of commission received for sale, as such owner and corporate employer were separate and distinct legal entities. LSA-C.C. art. 3005.
Document Preview: T. S. Neal sued Leonard J. Daniels for the amount of a commission received by defendant for selling the majority stock of a corporation after negotiations begun while in plaintiff's employment. From a judgment of the First Judicial District Court, Caddo Parish, Robert J. O'Neal, J., dismissing the suit, plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Hawthorne, J., held that the evidence showed that defendant was not plaintiff's employee or agent, but was employed only by a corporation organized by plaintiff, defendant and another, when defendant began the negotiations. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Haining Lumber Co. v. Octavius Leon, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: Where record indicated that defendant corporation was the seller and shipper of lumber, owner and proprietor of corporation could not be held liable for breach of warranty of quantity.
Document Preview: Action by Octavius Leon, Inc., a corporation, against Haining Lumber Company, a corporation, Harold E. Crain, proprietor, and Harold E. Crain, for recovery of the market value of the shortage in lumber shipped by defendant. The Superior Court, Yavapai County, W. E. Patterson, J., entered judgment for the plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Phelps, J., held that the evidence established that shipper had violated an implied warranty so as to authorize buyer to recover market value of shortage in shipment. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Kennedy v. Kennedy
Court: Supreme Court, Westchester County, New York, Special Term, Part II.
Headnote: Agreement by sole stockholder in family corporation that each of his seven brothers and sisters should receive seven per cent of stock in corporation and that corporation should advance the sum of $50 weekly for the support of certain of his brothers and sisters who were minors, to be charged against their interests in the corporation, was not an obligation of the corporation.
Document Preview: Action by Edward G. Kennedy, individually and as administrator of the goods, chattels and credits of Joseph T. Kennedy, Sr., deceased, and others against Joseph T. Kennedy, Jr., and the Joseph T. Kennedy Funeral Chapel, Inc., for specific performance of an agreement between the named plaintiff and Joseph T. Kennedy, Jr. Judgment for the plaintiffs as against Joseph T. Kennedy, Jr., and complaint dismissed as to Joseph T. Kennedy Funeral Chapel, Inc. See, also, 195 Misc. 220, 91 N.Y.S.2d 293.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Superior Portland Cement v. Pacific Coast Cement Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, en Banc.
Headnote: Although negotiations had been conducted nominally by officers and directors of the parent corporation the decisions reached by such officers were binding on the subsidiary corporation.
Document Preview: Action by Superior Portland Cement, Inc., against Pacific Coast Cement Company, for specific performance of provision in lease giving the plaintiff the first right to purchase the property or in the alternative for damages on account of breach thereof. From a judgment for the defendant, the plaintiff appeals. Judgment reversed and cause remanded for further proceedings in conformity with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Fulton Ship Operators P & I Service, Inc., Matter of
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where corporation engaged in maritime insurance business contracted to manage affiliated corporations which acted as central agents for syndicates of insurance companies and under its power of management directed certain of its employees from time to time to do necessary work in connection with servicing of syndicate policies, contract of hire between affiliates and employees did not exist merely because a single individual was an officer and director in each of the corporations, since affiliates as separate entities had right to make such managerial contracts as officers and directors saw fit.
Document Preview: Appeal from Decision of Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board. Proceeding in the matter of the liability of the Fulton Shipoperators P & I Service, Inc., and of the Fulton P & I Underwriting Agency, Inc., for unemployment insurance contributions under article 18, § 500 et seq., of the Labor Law. From a final determinations of the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board which affirmed determinations of the referee Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner, that the corporations involved were employers subject to the provisions of the Unemployment Insurance Law, the corporations appeal. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sells Petroleum v. Victory Swabbing Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Where recovery of money alleged to be due was sought under oral contracts allegedly made with president of corporation as agent of the corporation, court was required to assume that in law, president and corporation were separate and distinct persons, and hence an agent of president individually was not by reason of that fact alone, an agent of corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Gregg County; Earl Roberts, Judge. Action by the Victory Swabbing Company, Inc., against Sells Petroleum, Inc., and another for money alleged to be due for drilling two wells and for the use of a swabbing machine. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appeal. Reversed and cause remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Baker Divide Min. Co. v. Maxfield
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: The corporation and shareholders are distinct parties in contracts made by one or the other.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Placer County; Dal M. Lemmon, Judge. Ejectment action by the Baker Divide Mining Company against James Maxfield to recover possession of mining land and for damages for wrongful withholding of possession, wherein the defendant filed a cross-complaint. From a judgment for the plaintiff awarding it possession of property and rental value damages for wrongful withholding, the defendant appeals. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Farm Sec. Administration, Dept. of Agriculture, v. Herren
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil is not done to reach and impose liability upon someone who has agreed to pay either by actual promise or one implied in fact, but rather upon someone behind the contracting corporation who ought to pay but has avoided making any agreement to do so, express or implied in fact.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Arkansas; John E. Miller, Judge. Suit by Gordie M. Herren against the Farm Security Administration, Department of Agriculture, United States of America, to recover under the Tucker Act for damages for waste in violation of covenant of a lease of land to a land leasing association supervised by Farm Security Administration. Judgment for the plaintiff, and the defendant appeals. Judgment reversed with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Industrial Installations Corp. v. Rosenblatt
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part III.
Headnote: Plaintiff, a corporation whose president, a licensed professional engineer, entered into agreement with defendant, could not recover for the value of work designed by plaintiff for an industrial building for defendant, where plaintiff had not procured and was not entitled to receive a license to practice architecture. Education Law, § 1476.
Document Preview: Action by the Industrial Installations Corporation against Joseph Rosenblatt and Benjamin Rosenblatt, individually and as copartners, the names Joseph and Benjamin being fictitious, intending to designate the persons doing business under the firm name and style of J. & B. Rosenblatt. On motion for summary judgment in favor of defendants. Motion granted. The complaint alleged that the parties entered into an agreement whereby defendant was to pay the sum of 6 per cent. of the value of work designed by plaintiff, a corporation, for an industrial building, that defendant paid part of the amount due, and that subsequently the project was resumed and that its value was $100,000, and that plaintiff was entitled to $6,000 less the amount previously paid. The defendants' defense was that the plaintiff had not procured and was not entitled to receive from the Regents of the State of New York a license to practice architecture. Plaintiff's president...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Herman v. Mobile Homes Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: In determining whether corporate entity should be disregarded and the parent company held liable on the contracts of its subsidiary because the latter served as a mere instrumentality or adjunct of the former, each case is sui generis and must be decided in accordance with its own underlying facts.
Document Preview: Separate actions by Ralph J. Herman and wife, by Dale Ownby and wife, by Harry C. Bidigare and wife by Francis P. Duncan and wife, and by Carl Hoeberling and wife against the Mobile Homes Corporation, Inter Urban Land Company and Currier Lumber Company for damages resulting from sales to defendants of houses which were defective as result of inferior materials and workmanship, which were consolidated. From judgments for plaintiffs for $635 in each of the first four cases and $795 in the fifth case, the defendants appeal. Judgments affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Herman v. Mobile Homes Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Where land company and a home corporation were operated as mere departments of a lumber company, and were mere instrumentalities and adjuncts thereof, the parent corporation was liable for breaches of contracts of such subsidiaries, notwithstanding lack of actual fraud.
Document Preview: Separate actions by Ralph J. Herman and wife, by Dale Ownby and wife, by Harry C. Bidigare and wife by Francis P. Duncan and wife, and by Carl Hoeberling and wife against the Mobile Homes Corporation, Inter Urban Land Company and Currier Lumber Company for damages resulting from sales to defendants of houses which were defective as result of inferior materials and workmanship, which were consolidated. From judgments for plaintiffs for $635 in each of the first four cases and $795 in the fifth case, the defendants appeal. Judgments affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Forest Hill Corp. v. Latter & Blum
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Where Alabama corporation which was organized to acquire real estate and construct housing projects, and stock of which was owned by its president and his cousin, contracted with real estate brokerage company to purchase realty for it in Louisiana and company procured the realty for Alabama corporation, but realty was purchased by a business associate of president of Alabama corporation and conveyed to a newly formed Louisiana corporation, most of the stock of which was owned by president of Alabama corporation and his brother, trial court, as trier of facts, properly disregarded fiction of separate corporate identity and held Alabama corporation liable for broker's commission.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Mobile County; Cecil F. Bates, Judge. Action to recover real estate broker's commission by Latter & Blum, Inc., against Forest Hill Corporation. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Robinson v. Chapman Square
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Corporation was not liable for breach of contract made by one, as agent of another, though both principal and agent became officers of corporation subsequently organized to develop the property involved.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Los Angeles County; George A. Dockweiler, Judge. Action by E. S. Robinson and A. J. Chapman, a partnership doing business as Contractors' Sheet Metal Works, against Chapman Square, Inc., a corporation, to recover damages for loss of profits. From a judgment for plaintiffs, defendant appeals. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: L.A. Walden & Co. v. Consolidated Underwriters
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Where individual plaintiff owned all of the stock in corporate plaintiff, and defendant insurance companies dealt indiscriminately with both plaintiffs as agents, although agency contract itself was to individual plaintiff, plaintiffs would be treated as one for purpose of considering the issues in their suit to recover commissions claimed to be due them for acting as agents in selling compensation insurance.
Document Preview: Suit by L. A. Walden & Company and L. A. Walden, individually, against Consolidated Underwriters, T. H. Mastin & Company, a copartnership composed of Henry Burr and others, and others, to recover commissions claimed to be due plaintiffs for acting as agents for defendants in selling compensation insurance, wherein the named defendants filed a set-off and recoupment. From a judgment for defendants and allowing named defendants a recovery on their set-off and recoupment, the plaintiffs appeal. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Muirhead v. Fairlawn Enterprise
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Where sole owner and manager acted for corporation in all matters and alone knew of its dealings and finances, such a unity of interest and ownership existed that separate personalities of owner and corporation no longer existed in reality, and it would be unjust to permit corporation to avoid liability on contract signed in corporate name by owner as treasurer on ground that corporation was not a party to contract and that owner had no authority to bind corporation.
Document Preview: Exceptions from Superior Court, Providence and Bristol Counties; Mortimer A. Sullivan, Judge. Action in assumpsit by James W. Muirhead against Fairlawn Enterprise, Incorporated, to recover damages for breach of a written contract to issue forty shares of stock in defendant corporation. Verdict for plaintiff, defendant's motion for a new trial denied, and defendant brings exceptions. Exceptions overruled and case remitted to superior court for entry of judgment on the verdict.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Bowman v. Reyburn
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, en Banc.
Headnote: Where stockholders and creditor entered into agreement to procure reorganization of apartment corporation and, on completion of reorganization, creditor's surrender of evidences of indebtedness, but reorganization failed and another corporation which was controlled by creditor and which owned second mortgage bonds of apartment corporation filed and secured adoption of plan for redemption from foreclosure of first mortgage, stockholders were not entitled to specific performance of agreement on theory that corporate fiction, used to conceal the creditor's personal ownership of apartment building, should be ignored.
Document Preview: Error to District Court of City and County of Denver; Robert W. Steele, Judge. Suit by Dorothy Bowman and others against Roscoe Reyburn and others for specific performance of a contract. To review an adverse judgment, plaintiffs bring error. Affirmed. BAKKE and BURKE, JJ., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: William Sellers & Co. v. Clarke-Harrison, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where written contract was ambiguous as to formula under which money should be paid to one corporation for managing another corporation and parties to contract for a number of years applied the same formula, construction given the ambiguity by the parties governed, and managed corporation could not recover back alleged overpayment of fees to manager resulting if a different formula were applied after entire stock of managed corporation was acquired by other persons.
Document Preview: Appeals Nos. 185, 187189, January term, 1945, from final decree of Common Pleas No. 2, Philadelphia County, December term, 1943, No. 1785; James Gay Gordon, Jr., President Judge. Action in equity by William Sellers & Company, Inc., against Clarke-Harrison, Inc., Eugene C. Clarke and Chambersburg Engineering Company for an accounting and for the declaration of a constructive trust. From the decree, all parties appeal. On plaintiff's appeal, appeal dismissed and decree affirmed. On defendants' appeals, decree reversed and bill ordered dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Duel v. National Sur. Corp.
Court: District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: In action by insurance company's liquidator to recover on bond indemnifying company against loss resulting from fraudulent acts of company's agent, that the conversion of company's premiums resulted from acts on part of corporation organized by agent did not prevent recovery where the corporation functioned solely as the agent's instrumentality, since the corporate fiction would be ignored to prevent a fraud. St.1943, Wis. §§ 200.08, 200.09 (W.S.A.).
Document Preview: Action by Morvin Duel, Commissioner of Insurance of the State of Wisconsin, as liquidator of the Mid-Continent Mutual Insurance Company, against the National Surety Corporation to recover on a fidelity bond which defendant issued to insure the insurance company against loss which it might sustain through fraudulent acts by its employees. Judgment for plaintiff in accordance with opinion. See, also, 4 F.R.D. 336.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gruenebaum v. Lissauer
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: Fact that New York corporation was controlled by same copartnership as controlled Dutch corporation did not make New York corporation liable for Dutch corporation's contractual obligations.
Document Preview: Action by Arthur Gruenebaum, suing on behalf of himself and all other creditors of N. V. Oxyde Maatschappij Voor Ertsen en Metalen, and of Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation, similarly situated, against Meno Lissauer and another, individually and as members of the firm of M. Lissauer & Cie., N. V. Oxyde Maatschappij Voor Ertsen en Metalen, Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation, and another. On motion of the defendants Meno Lissauer, Walter Rothschild, and Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation to dismiss the complaint pursuant to rule 106 of the Rules of Civil Practice, or, in the alternative, for an order pursuant to rule 103 striking out certain allegations of the complaint upon ground that they are irrelevant and scandalous and for an order pursuant to rule 90 directing the service of an amended complaint separately stating the several causes of action alleged in the complaint. Orders in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Gruenebaum v. Lissauer
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term.
Headnote: Fact that plaintiff used offices of New York corporation which was under same common control as Dutch corporation when working in New York City for Dutch corporation, and that for a period the New York corporation paid plaintiff salary due under his contract with Dutch corporation, did not render New York corporation liable on such contract.
Document Preview: Action by Arthur Gruenebaum, suing on behalf of himself and all other creditors of N. V. Oxyde Maatschappij Voor Ertsen en Metalen, and of Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation, similarly situated, against Meno Lissauer and another, individually and as members of the firm of M. Lissauer & Cie., N. V. Oxyde Maatschappij Voor Ertsen en Metalen, Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation, and another. On motion of the defendants Meno Lissauer, Walter Rothschild, and Associated Metals & Minerals Corporation to dismiss the complaint pursuant to rule 106 of the Rules of Civil Practice, or, in the alternative, for an order pursuant to rule 103 striking out certain allegations of the complaint upon ground that they are irrelevant and scandalous and for an order pursuant to rule 90 directing the service of an amended complaint separately stating the several causes of action alleged in the complaint. Orders in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Eisenbarth v. Equity Mut. Ins. Co.
Court: St. Louis Court of Appeals, Missouri.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence that close affiliation between casualty reciprocal exchange that issued automobile liability policy and defended action against insured and surety company that went on appeal bond was used to accomplish an improper purpose, separate corporate entities would not be disregarded in adjusting the rights of surety company against insured.
Document Preview: Appeal from St. Louis Circuit Court, Robert L. Aronson, Judge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wilson v. Milner Hotels
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Where parent and subsidiary corporations act as one in transaction of business, parent corporation cannot avoid liability under its contract on ground of its assignment of contract to subsidiary corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Second District, Silver Bow County; T. E. Downey, Judge. Action by Mabel M. Wilson and another against the Milner Hotels, Inc., to recover rentals under a lease of hotel property. Judgment for plaintiffs, and defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Whitehurst v. FCX Fruit & Vegetable Service
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation owns all capital stock of another corporation and that members of the board of directors of both corporations are the same is not sufficient to render parent corporation liable for contracts of its subsidiary, in absence of additional circumstances showing fraud, actual or constructive, or agency.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Wayne County; richard D. Dixon, Special Judge. Action by J. J. Whitehurst and another against FCX Fruit and Vegetable Service, Incorporated, and others, to recover balance allegedly due under contract, wherein the named defendant filed a counterclaim. Before the trial a voluntary nonsuit was taken as to the defendant North Carolina Cotton Growers Cooperative Association. From a judgment for plaintiffs, the defendants appeal. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Yost v. Patrick
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A seller of a business who agrees not to engage in similar business may not make use of corporation entity as a means of evading obligation of covenant. Code 1940, Tit. 9, §§ 22-24.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Covington County; Robt. S. Reid, Judge. Bill for injunction by Walter J. Yost and Eva Yost, partners doing business as Pine Plume Lumber Company, against Albert J. Patrick, doing business as McGowin Saw Mill Company.  From a decree denying application for temporary injunction, complainants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U.S. v. Davidson
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Agreement of parent corporation to convey all assets of corporation and its subsidiary was not binding on the subsidiary.
Document Preview: WALLER, Circuit Judge, dissenting. Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Northern District of Texas; James C. Wilson, Judge. Action by the United States of America against Jewell Davidson, individually and as tax assessor-collector of Potter County, Texas, and others, for an injunction wherein the defendants filed a counterclaim.  From a decree for defendants, the plaintiff appeals. Decree modified, and as modified affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: De Stubner v. United Carbon Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: That licensee under patent license agreement had same officers, directors, and general manager as sublicensee did not justify disregarding corporate entities and holding sublicensee liable for payments due under license agreement on theory that licensee was merely an instrumentality of sublicensee, in absence of showing that corporate entities were used to commit a fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: Error to Circuit Court, Kanawha County. Proceeding by notice of motion for judgment by Emile C. deStubner against United Carbon Company, Inc., and Microid Process, Inc., to recover money allegedly due plaintiff under a patent license agreement with Microid Process, Inc., which United Carbon Company, Inc., allegedly obligated itself to pay should licensee not have funds available for the purpose. To review a judgment for plaintiff, defendants bring error. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and appropriate judgment entered. ROSE and FOX, JJ., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Wylie v. Mountain Motors
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Proceedings to recover, under garage liability policy naming two corporations as insured, on a judgment at law rendered against employee of one corporation who was driving automobile owned by other corporation, but which judgment was not rendered against either corporation, did not authorize application of "instrumentality rule" to such corporations.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Greenbrier County. Suit by Anne Lee Wylie against Mountain Motors, Inc., and others, to recover the amount of a judgment secured against an employee of defendant Home Motors, Inc., by reason of his negligence in operating an automobile belonging to defendant Mountain Motors, Inc., both of which defendants were the named insured in a policy issued by defendant Fidelity & Casualty Company of New York. From a judgment dismissing the bill of complaint, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Massachusetts Bonding & Ins. Co. v. Master Laboratories
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Where surety paid release of garnishment bond and individual owning and controlling corporate principal of bond and corporate indemnitor of surety acquiesced in act of his principal agent who, on behalf of indemnitor, had executed special indemnity agreement for surety and individual's instructions to agent were to pay premium of bond and the agreement, indemnitor was not relieved of liability to surety on the agreement on ground that liability thereon was individual's personal liability.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Douglas County; Fitzgerald, Judge. Action by Massachusetts Bonding & Insurance Company against the Master Laboratories, Incorporated, on a special indemnity agreement. Municipal Court judgment was appealed by defendant to the District Court. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micheletti v. Fugitt
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: In action to recover amount deposited in escrow pending consummation of sale of a gambling club, judgment for defendant was not erroneous on ground that trial court found that contract for sale of the club was between plaintiff and defendant and not between plaintiff and a corporation, where evidence showed that corporation was merely a name for defendant's business and that defendant's bookkeeper in signing earnest receipt for the corporation was merely acting for defendant.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Second District, Washoe County; Wm. McKnight, Judge. Action by O. Micheletti against the First National Bank of Nevada for money had and received, wherein defendant disclaimed any interest in the money except as to an escrow fee, and John C. Fugitt was substituted as defendant. Judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appeals from the judgment and from an order denying plaintiff's motion for new trial. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Micheletti v. Fugitt
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Purchaser of a gambling club which was incorporated and which corporation was merely the name under which vendor was doing business, which fact was known to purchaser, and who was not deceived thereby, was not entitled to avoid the contract on ground that transaction was with the corporation and not with the vendor, since, under the circumstances, the court would not strain after technicalities to defeat the intention of the parties but would look to the substance of the transaction.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Second District, Washoe County; Wm. McKnight, Judge. Action by O. Micheletti against the First National Bank of Nevada for money had and received, wherein defendant disclaimed any interest in the money except as to an escrow fee, and John C. Fugitt was substituted as defendant. Judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appeals from the judgment and from an order denying plaintiff's motion for new trial. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Betz v. Tacoma Drug Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Where president of corporation owned only about 20 per cent. of stock, and board of directors of seven members had regular meetings and was not shown to have been dominated by president, corporation's entity would not be disregarded and corporation regarded as agent of owner of substantially all stock, as ground for holding valid a contract for sale of realty made by president without authority from or ratification by board of directors.
Document Preview: Department 1. Action by Harry Betz against the Tacoma Drug Company for breach of real estate option. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendant appeals. Reversed with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: General American Life Ins. Co. v. Anderson
Court: District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: The "sole actor doctrine" is a principle of equity which relieves from rigors of or enforces a binding contract for a party who has dealt with an individual believing individual had authority to speak for corporation and to commit it to the obligation, and such doctrine is invoked solely for purpose of doing equity, and he who relies on it must come into court with clean hands.
Document Preview: Action by General American Life Insurance Company against A. M. Anderson, receiver of the National Bank of Kentucky, to compel payment to plaintiff of a dividend as had been awarded to other creditors of National Bank of Kentucky. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Caldwell v. Gem Packing Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: The alleged fact that two stockholders of corporation which sold packing plant and corporation which purchased packing plant were fully cognizant of contract of corporation selling the plant with partners for slaughter of livestock, with incidental provisions for refrigeration and display of dressed meats, along with limited office space for partners, did not warrant piercing the corporate veil of either corporation and classing both as one, in order to permit partners to recover from the corporation purchasing the plant, for breach of contract.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Los Angeles County; Frank G. Swain, Judge. Action by Harry Caldwell and A. Himmelfarb, doing a wholesale business as the Model Meat Company, against the Gem Packing Company, the Producers Packing Company, and others, for a declaratory judgment and for damages because of plaintiffs' alleged eviction from certain premises. From an adverse judgment, the plaintiffs appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Dregne v. Five Cent Cab Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The mere fact that stockholders in two or more corporations are the same or that one corporation exercises a control over the other through ownership of its stock or through identity of its stockholders, does not make either the "agent" of the other, nor does it "merge" them into one, so as to make a contract with one corporation binding upon the other, where each corporation is separately organized under a distinct charter.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Cook County; John T. Cummings, Judge. Action by Carol Dregne against the Five Cent Cab Company, the Yellow Cab Company, and others, for injuries sustained while the plaintiff was a passenger in a taxicab which ran into the supporting pier of a railroad viaduct. From a judgment in favor of the Yellow Cab Company, the plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Goldberg v. Tri-States Theatre Corporation
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Though equity may in certain situations disregard the artificiality of a corporate structure which is a mere form to shield a fraud, it is not justified in disregarding the entity merely to assist a party to escape a valid contractual obligation into which he has voluntarily and beneficially entered.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the District of Nebraska; James A. Donohoe, Judge. Suit by Tri-States Theatre Corporation against Ralph D. Goldberg and others to enjoin the use of a certain building for theatre purposes by defendants. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: H.G. Fenton Material Co. v. Challet
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: The rule that a stranger to a restrictive covenant not to engage in a competing business can properly be enjoined from engaging in business with a covenanter so as to result in a breach of the covenant applies to corporations, but ordinarily a corporation should not be enjoined from conducting a business independently of the covenanter unless the circumstances are such that the corporation must be regarded as the alter ego of the covenanter or a mere instrumentality by means of which the covenanter seeks to evade the covenant.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, San Diego County; Arthur L. Mundo, Judge. Action by the H. G. Fenton Material Company against Paul Challet and others to enjoin defendants from operating or constructing a certain rock and gravel plant and from selling rock or gravel therefrom. From a judgment granting plaintiff partial injunctive relief, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed. Hearing denied; CURTIS, HOUSER, and CARTER, JJ., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Sineath v. Katzis
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: So far as concerns a corporation organized and supported by one who has covenanted not to engage in a certain business, or with the covenantor's assistance, the corporation should not be enjoined from competing with the covenantee, except where it appears that the corporation is substantially the alter ego of the covenantor.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Wayne County; H. A. Grady, Emergency Judge. Action by W. P. Sineath and A. G. Hearon, partners, trading as the Goldsboro Dry Cleaners & Hatters, and W. P. Sineath and A. G. Hearon, individually, against Nick J. Katzis, Letha White, White's Laundry & Cleaners, Inc., and the Bank of Wayne, trustee, wherein the Mechanics & Farmers Bank and R. L. McDougald, trustee, were later made parties defendant, to restrain Nick J. Katzis from violating a noncompetitive agreement, to restrain Letha White and White's Laundry & Cleaners, Inc., from conspiring or participating with Nick J. Katzis in breach of the agreement, to cancel, because of failure of consideration and breach of contract, certain notes executed by defendants, in which defendants, banks and trustee, claim an interest, and to recover of Nick J. Katzis, Letha White and White's Laundry & Cleaners, Inc., damages for breach of contract, wherein Nick J. Katzis filed a crossaction....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Barr & Creelman Mill & Plumbing Supply Co. v. Zoller
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent corporation, the sole stockholder of subsidiary corporation, caused subsidiary to issue checks payable to the parent's creditor, the will of the parent corporation was the will of the subsidiary, and both corporations were deemed to have ratified the transaction.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Western District of New York. Proceedings in reorganization of Dolomite 3 Corporation, debtor, wherein Barr & Creelman Mill & Plumbing Supply Company sought allowance of a claim secured by lien against property of the debtor in the amount of $11,469.68, to which objection was made, for the allowance of a credit of $6,000, by Frederick W. Zoller, trustee, and Petroleum Heat & Power Co., Incorporated, a creditor of debtor. From an order sustaining the objection and allowing the claim only for a balance above the credit, claimant appeals. Reversed, with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Jones v. Commagere
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Parish of Orleans.
Headnote: Where a judgment debtor is the real owner of a corporation, his "salary" which is subject to garnishment is not the monthly income transferred to him by the corporation, but is the amount of the earnings of the corporation, less a reasonable reserve for emergencies and deducting the $60 exemption allowed by the statute. LSA-R.S. 13:3921 et seq.; Acts No. 183 of 1932.
Document Preview: Appeal from Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans; Wm. H. Byrnes, Jr., Judge. Louis E. Commagere, Jr., and others filed a rule to secure a revision of a former decree of Court of Appeal, 181 So. 198, adjudging that a part of the salary of Louis E. Commagere, Jr., employee of the Commagere Pharmacy, Incorporated, was subject to garnishment by judgment creditors, Misses Gladys and Mina Irma Jones. From a judgment dismissing its rule, the garnishee corporation appeals. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Walsh v. Mankato Oil Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: In action against officer who was in sole control of corporation for breach of contract between plaintiff and officer, to which corporation was a party, for equal division of corporation's net earnings, officer would not be permitted to set up defense that plaintiff's remedy, if any, was against corporation and not against officer in individual capacity, since there was no room for legal fiction of separate corporate personality or for distinction between officer's acts as corporation's officer and acts as individual.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Blue Earth County; A. B. Gislason, Judge. Action by W. R. Walsh against the Mankato Oil Company and E. C. Footh. From an order denying the motion of E. C. Footh for new trial, he appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Watson v. Commonwealth Ins. Co. of N.Y.
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Where plaintiff and another owned substantially all stock of insurance agency corporation, contract executed in name of corporation by such owners for purpose of liquidating corporation's indebtedness to insurance companies for back premiums was properly reformed to impose individual obligation on plaintiff under rule permitting recognition of acts of corporation as being in reality those of individuals.
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by Kenneth Watson against the Commonwealth Insurance Company of New York and others, in which defendants filed cross-complaint. From an adverse judgment, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Lindstrom v. Sauer
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Parish of Orleans.
Headnote: Where good will of corporation which was in fact almost entirely owned by seller was sold along with business, seller held personally bound by agreement between corporation and buyer.
Document Preview: Appeal from Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans; Hugh C. Cage, Judge. Action by Harvey L. Lindstrom against Charles F. Sauer. From an adverse judgment, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hermitage Land & Timber Co. v. Scott's Ex'rs
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Where president and secretary of chair company owned all but three shares of its capital stock and chair corporation owned all but nine shares of capital stock of vendor corporation, president and secretary had authority to execute contract authorizing another to sell vendor corporation's property, since corporate entity could be disregarded. Ky.St. § 883b-3.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Franklin County. Action by Howell P. Scott against the Hermitage Land & Timber Company. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appeals. During the pendency of the appeal, the plaintiff died, and the appeal was revived against his executrices. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Zellerbach Paper Co. v. Virden Pkg. Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: When corporation was not one-man corporation nor under one-man control, in view of nomination of directors through nominating committee, alter ego doctrine held inapplicable, as regards corporation's liability on alleged guaranty bearing corporation's name and seal placed thereon by president.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco; I. L. Harris, Judge. Action by the Zellerbach Paper Company against the Virden Packing Company. Judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appeals. Affirmed. Hearing denied by Supreme Court; SHENK and THOMPSON, JJ., dissenting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Shepherd v. Banking & Trust Co. of Jonesboro
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Identity of stockholders of corporations does not create agency or merger so as to make one corporation's contract binding on the other.
Document Preview: Suit by J. B. Shepherd, trustee in bankruptcy of the Summers Hardware Company, bankrupt, against the Banking & Trust Company of Jonesboro, trustee, and others, in which defendants counterclaimed. From an adverse decree, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Pohlman Inv. Co. v. Virginia City Gold Mining Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Investment corporation of which entire stock was owned by three brothers, two of whom managed and controlled business and owned 90 per cent. of stock, held estopped to question cancellation of contract for sale of stock in mining corporation to which brother owning 50 per cent. of stock in investment corporation assented as trustee and secretary-treasurer of mining corporation, especially where brother owning 40 per cent. of stock in investment corporation participated in sale of stock after cancellation of contract, notwithstanding absence of formal ratification of cancellation by investment corporation.
Document Preview: Department 1. Appeal from Superior Court, Spokane County; John A. Frater, Judge. Suit by the Pohlman Investment Company against the Virginia City Gold Mining Company. Judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Illinois Interior Finish Co. v. Poenie
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District.
Headnote: Where holder of legal title contracted with family corporation, incorporated by herself and other members of her family, for construction of building on property, court in determining effect of no-lien clause in contract, would deal with substance of transaction involved as if the corporate agency did not exist, and as the justice of the case required.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, Illinois Interior Finish Company, filed its bill of complaint in the circuit court to enforce its claim for mechanic's lien as a subcontractor against Ben Poenie, contractor, Tillie H. Novak, the owner of the premises described in the bill of complaint, Charles W. Novak, her husband, the Chicago Title & Trust Company, as trustee under the trust deed on record against the premises and the unknown owners of the indebtedness secured by such trust deed. Answers were filed by Tillie H. Novak, the principal defendant, and the Chicago Title & Trust Company. The other defendants were defaulted. The cause was referred to master in chancery Wm. A. Doyle. He found in his report that plaintiff was not entitled to a mechanic's lien. The chancellor overruled exceptions to the master's report and entered a decree approving said report and dismissing plaintiff's bill of complaint for want of equity. This appeal followed. Plaintiff's bill alleged that the defendant Tillie H....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Strauss v. Dubuque Fire & Marine Ins. Co. of Dubuque, Iowa
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Owners of corporation's capital stock, named as insured in fire policy covering corporation's property, and requiring insured to be unconditional and sole owners, held not entitled to disregard corporate entity to recover on policy.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, City and County of San Francisco; Michael J. Roche, Judge. Action by D. Strauss and others, doing business under and by the corporate name of Allied Box & Excelsior Company, against the Dubuque Fire & Marine Insurance Company of Dubuque, Iowa, and another. Judgment for defendants, and plaintiffs appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Associated Oil Co. v. Seiberling Rubber Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Similarity in names of "Seiberling Rubber Company" and "The Seiberling Rubber Company" and commingling of business of two corporations, held fraud upon plaintiff suing on guaranty contract, entitling plaintiff to treat two corporations as single entity.
Document Preview: Department 2. Appeal from Superior Court, King County; Howard M. Finley, Judge. Action by the Associated Oil Company against The Seiberling Rubber Company. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stanley-Fan-C-Pack Sales Co. v. Fan-C-Pack Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where manufacturers organized corporation as sales agent, one manufacturer, when sued on contract by corporation for contribution to operating costs, could not disregard corporate entity and insist that it was dealing with other manufacturer as real plaintiff.
Document Preview: Suit by the Stanley-Fan-C-Pack Sales Company against the Fan-C-Pack Company, to recover moneys due. From a decree in favor of the defendant, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed, and a new trial ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Stanley-Fan-C-Pack Sales Co. v. Fan-C-Pack Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where manufacturers organized corporation as sales agent, accounts between manufacturers, on theory that contract constituted joint venture, could not be adjusted in suit by corporation against entity and without making other manufacturer a party.
Document Preview: Suit by the Stanley-Fan-C-Pack Sales Company against the Fan-C-Pack Company, to recover moneys due. From a decree in favor of the defendant, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed, and a new trial ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Farnum v. Bankers' & Shippers' Ins. Co. of New York
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: One supposing he is contracting with corporation is not bound by contract, ostensibly of corporation, to individual who owns corporation.
Document Preview: Exceptions from Superior Court, Worcester County; Daniel T. O'Connell, Judge. Suit by Llewellyn G. Farnum against the Bankers' and Shippers' Insurance Company of New York. Verdict for the plaintiff, and the defendant brings exceptions. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Hollywood Cleaning & Pressing Co. v. Hollywood Laundry Service
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: That one corporation owned all stock of another held not to require disregarding corporate entity, so as to bring laundries acquired by parent corporation within subsidiary's contract for giving exclusive benefit of dry cleaning business from its laundries.
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by the Hollywood Cleaning & Pressing Company against the Hollywood Laundry Service, Incorporated. From the portion of the judgment adverse to it, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed. For prior opinion, see 12 P.(2d) 145.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: Loewenthal Securities Co. v. White Paving Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: Ownership largely by one person of two independent corporations, one of which agreed to sell securities received on city contracts, did not justify disregard of corporate entities in suit by buyer where other company procured contract.
Document Preview: Error to Second Branch, Appellate Court, First District, on Appeal from Superior Court, Cook County; Oscar Hebel, Judge. Suit by the Loewenthal Securities Company against the White Paving Company and others. Decree for complainant was affirmed by the Appellate Court (259 Ill. App. 612), and defendants bring certiorari. Decree of trial court and judgment of Appellate Court reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U S Shipping Bd Emergency Fleet Corp v. Tabas
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are not authorized to sign name of sole stockholder to contract.
Document Preview: In Error to the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania; J. Whitaker Thompson, Judge. Action at law by Abraham Tabas and others, partners as the Northern Metals Company, against the United States Shipping Board Emergency Fleet Corporation. Judgment for plaintiffs (9 F.(2d) 648), and defendant brings error. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: U S Shipping Bd Emergency Fleet Corp v. Tabas
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are not authorized to sign name of sole stockholder to contract.
Document Preview: In Error to the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania; J. Whitaker Thompson, Judge. Action at law by Abraham Tabas and others, partners as the Northern Metals Company, against the United States Shipping Board Emergency Fleet Corporation. Judgment for plaintiffs (9 F.(2d) 648), and defendant brings error. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1059 Contracts in general >
Title: O'Brien v. Champlain Construction Co.
Court: Circuit Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: A bill by contractors on a railroad construction contract against the construction company and the railroad company alleged that the former company was a myth representing the railroad company which was sought to be followed. Held that, if these allegations were true, the railroad was liable, and both were proper parties.
Document Preview: In Equity. For former opinion, see 104 Fed. 930.
